We have in place standard operating procedures to handle inflight medical emergencies, including potentially infectious diseases. Any unwell passenger will be attended to by the medical authorities immediately after the aircraft lands. As an added measure, inflight announcements regarding coronavirus will be made on all outbound and inbound flights to Singapore. Surgical masks will also be made available to our crew who operate to affected stations.”In a statement IndiGo airlines, which operates flights to Chengdu and Guangzhou in China, said, “Our crew are taking appropriate precautions. There have been no cases reported yet in our Chinese points, which are around 1,000 km from Wuhan , the centre of the outbreak , nor indeed in India. We are in close touch with the government authorities and will advise of any alterations to our schedule, as and when they occur. Meantime, we have many thousands of forward bookings and are serving those customers as normal.”An airline official said China has stopped all tours of its citizens headed abroad and Cathay Pacific’s subsidiary Cathay Dragon has suspended flights between Wuhan and Hong Kong. “This has come as a relief as it will cut chances of the infection spreading.”Earlier, health minister C Vijayabaskar said airports will continue routine thermal screening of arriving passengers. If patients arriving in Chennai from China show symptoms of flu, they will be taken to the government hospital for treatment. Warning signs for the new strain, like other influenza viruses, includes fever, cough and breathing difficulties, while more advanced cases could lead to pneumonia, kidney failure and death. We always reserve 10 beds in the hospital for quarantine. They will be taken there,” he said.The state has also sent available educational material on the virus to doctors’ bodies to ensure they identify cases early. Tests for the new virus will be sent to National Institute of Virology lab, officials said.

Title: Padma Shri a blessing from women I helped: Sayedbhai
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Sayedbhai

PUNE: For five decades, Sayed Mehboob Shah Qadri — alias Sayedbhai — has worked relentlessly to help Muslim women, abandoned by their husbands under triple talaq, stand on their own feet.

On Saturday, Sayedbhai was conferred the prestigious Padma Shri by the Union government. The octogenarian said the award gives him the impetus to continue working for societal reforms and double his efforts to bring in a uniform civil code. “The award is a result of the blessings of the women from across the country, whom I had the chance to help over the past five decades,” he told TOI on Saturday.

Sayedbhai said he personally saw the effects of triple talaq, when his younger sister was divorced by her husband. “He just said it was ‘Allah’s wish’. I was not convinced and had railed against this. Many people around me made fun of me. I realized much later that I needed to do something different to change people’s mindset,” he said.

In early 1970s, Sayedbhai came in contact with social reformer Hamid Dalwai in Pune. On March 22 the same year, they established the Muslim Satyashodak Mandal here. “I enrolled my sister in tailoring classes. She worked hard and raised her two sons, who went on to get government jobs. She made me realize how difficult it was for divorced women without support,” Sayedbhai said.

“We helped such women by extended financial support and legal assistance to ensure they got their due,” he said.

Over the decade, the mandal established branches in many cities. “With our network, we were able to help many women, who are now self-reliant. This gives me the ultimate satisfaction,” he said.

On January 10, Sayedbhai and his colleagues met PM Narendra Modi in New Delhi and submitted a memorandum on a uniform civil code.

“I hail from Hyderabad, but I am now a Punekar. This city has always supported my work. I dedicate my award to this city,” he said.

Title: Doctor’s body flown to Hyderabad from London
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The body of Dr AK Meena, a neurologist from Nizams Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS), who died of cardiac arrest while attending a conference at London, arrived in the city on Saturday morning and was kept at NIMS. Health minister Eatela Rajender visited the hospital to pay tributes.

The doctor’s death had triggered widespread concern about doctors neglecting their own health and working under extremely stressful conditions. In fact, Dr Meena ’s death was the fourth such case reported in recent times, with two doctors from the city succumbing within 24 hours.

Dr Meena was given cardio pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) immediately after she collapsed while speaking at a neurology conference. She was rushed to St Bartholomew’s Hospital, but all efforts to revive her failed.

Meanwhile, the doctors community have come up with a list of suggestions to follow in order to avoid a similar condition.

Title: Telangana: Couple drowns as car slips into canal
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A couple drowned in Peddapalli district on Saturday evening after their car accidentally fell into Kakatiya canal. The deceased have been identified as M Srinivas (40), a businessman, and his wife M Swaroopa (38).

Peddapalli police said that the couple was travelling to their residence in Sultanabad and at around 5pm they stopped near the canal to buy fish from a vendor. When Srinivas tried to reverse the car, he applied the accelerator instead of brake and the car slipped into the canal.

Based on eyewitness account, Srinivas was speaking to his son on the phone while reversing the car. He managed to inform his son of the accident before communication was lost, Sultanabad police said, adding that the couple tried to open the windows, but they were jammed. The locals who saw the car sinking called up the police.

Meanwhile, the couple’s son rushed to the canal and found them submerged. The police rescue team managed to pull out the car from the canal and recover the bodies.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Power body issues guidelines to discoms
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The Andhra Pradesh Electricity Regulation Commission (APERC) has issued guidelines on feedback and grievance redressal mechanism to power distribution companies in a bid to bring about accountability and transparency in the functioning of discoms.

The APERC has directed discoms to set up complaint boxes at all offices, such that they are visible to consumers. Discoms should print public notices about the complaint boxes in English and in Telugu on the reverse side of electricity bills. The notice should specify that complaints will be addressed by the immediate higher authority on the first of every month.

APERC chairman Justice CV Nagarjuna Reddy said consumers can submit complaints to officials if the complaint falls within the jurisdiction of the same office. Such direct complaints have to be addressed within 48 hours and the complainant be informed of its status through SMS or email and the same be uploaded on the website of the discom. Keys to complaint boxes at subordinate offices must be locked up after complains are collected, the commission directed. All complaints must be uploaded for the concerned authorities and on to the discom’s websire. Separate registers have to be maintained as well on complaints received and complaints addressed.

The commission said discoms should put in place a system in which all field officers upload data on number of complaints received and addressed. They were also directed to display monthly reports about status of complaints.

Title: 17 cops from Andhra Pradesh get President’s medals
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

ViIJAYAWADA: Vigilance and enforcement DG K V Rajendranath Reddy, CM’s chief security officer A Joshi, and Vijayawada west ACP K Sudhakar are among the 17 police personnel from Andhra Pradesh to win the President’s police medals. While Rajendranath Reddy and Sudhakar won in the category of distinguished service, Joshi got the medal for meritorious service.

The other cops from the state in the President’s medals list are C V A Ramakrishna (APSP additional commandant), M Bhaskara Rao (CID DSP), G Vijay Kumar (assault commander, Greyhounds), K John Moses Chiranjeevi (reserve inspector, Vijayawada commissionerate), N Gowri Shankarudu (AR SI, Nellore ), P Victoria Rani (ASI, Anakapalli), K N Kesavan (ASI, Chittoor), S Ramachandraiah (AR SI, Anantapur), Y Chandrasekhar (head constable, Ongole), P Vijay Bhaskar (head constable, Vijayawada), N Ramakrishnaraju (head constable, Vizianagaram), G Ramana (constable, Kurnool), N Suryanarayana (railway constable, Visakhapatnam) and M V Satyanarayana Raju (AR constable, ACB Visakhapatnam). All of them won in the meritorious service category.

Title: Former Tamil Nadu chief secretary TV Antony, champion of family planning, dead
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

CHENNAI: Former Tamil Nadu chief secretary and Padma Bhushan T V Antony , 86, who died on Friday at a city hospital after a brief illness was a champion of family planning .

Antony, who joined the IAS in 1956, was a second-generation civil servant who drew inspiration from his father T V Varghese, an ICS officer, who retired as TN chief secretary in 1965. Years later, Antony had two stints as TN chief secretary, first in 1985-1986 and later for a brief while in 1991. About his removal from the CS post in 1986, Antony once told this correspondent, “People used to say that I was removed as CS because of some miscommunication. MGR, who was bedridden, wanted the TV antenna to be changed. But people around him thought he said ‘change T V Antony’. I was shifted.”

His stint as Thanjavur collector was a turning point in his life, Antony told M Smriti, a student and freelance journalist, in an interview in 2013. To understand the problems of farm labourers, he spent a night in a worker’s house. “The room measured hardly 100 sq ft in which they had to accommodate the father and mother, relatives and their five children. I was given a corner place in the room. At night, there was heavy downpour. The farmer requested me that their buffalo also needed to be brought inside the house. I shared my corner of the hut and slept with the buffalo,” Antony said in the interview.

During a casual conversation years ago, Antony told this correspondent that once his younger son demanded a younger brother to bully because he was getting bullied by his older brother. “I was flummoxed by the demand from the four-year-old kid. It was breakfast time. I asked him how many dosas he was getting for breakfast. He said three. I told him, see, you and your brother are getting three dosas each now. If you have one more brother, six dosas will have to be shared by three kids. I asked him whether he wanted three dosas or two dosas and a younger brother. Pat came the reply that he preferred three dosas,” said Antony.

His commitment and nation-wide campaign for family planning and two-child formula got him the moniker ‘Tubectomy Vasectomy’ Antony, which he accepted with grace. The reward for his decades of campaign for family planning came in 2004 when he was conferred Padma Bhushan.

Antony’s younger brother Thomas Varghese was general manager of Southern Railway. Antony is survived by his wife Molly Varghese and two sons. The funeral service will be held at St Louis Church Gandhi Nagar at 11 am on Monday. DMK president M K Stalin, in a message, said Antony fought for women’s rights.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Six-member gang blackmails businessman with obscene video, arrested
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A six-member gang was arrested on Friday night for extorting a car worth Rs 8 lakh, gold chain weighing five sovereigns and Rs 27,500 cash from a businessman by blackmailing him with a video of him spending intimate moments with a woman. Police have recovered all the valuables from the gang.

An investigation officer said the plan to trap K Vinodhkumar, 32, of Raja Street, was hatched by Sudha, 30, estranged wife of Manikandan from Ammapalayam near Tirupur and her accomplices. Vinodhkumar is a wholesale garment seller.

“He received a phone call from an unknown number on December 26, 2019 and the caller introduced herself as Prema. She soon befriended him. On December 29, she asked Vinodhkumar to meet her at a bakery at Kinathukadavu , which he did. The next day, she called him and requested him to meet her at Masaniamman temple at Anaimalai at 6pm on December 31,” the officer said.

Vinodhkumar met her at the temple and later took her to his farmhouse at Poovalaparuthi near Anaimalai. “Around 12.30am on January 1, a five-member gang entered inside the farmhouse and recorded the intimate moments of the couple by threatening Vinodhkumar. They snatched his gold chain and made him withdraw Rs27,500 from an ATM booth at Ambarampalayam. Later, they dropped him in Pollachi and made away with his car,” the officer said.

A few days later, the officer said, Vinodhkumar received a phone call from one of the gang members, demanding Rs 25 lakh. “He also threatened Vinodhkumar that they would circulate the obscene video on social media, if he failed to meet their demand.”

Following this, Vinodhkumar approached district superintendent of police Sujit Kumar, who formed a special team led by sub inspector Arun to nab the gang.

Preliminary inquiry revealed that the woman was the mastermind behind the crime, and it was she who arranged the gang to enter inside the farmhouse when she was with the businessman.

The team tracked them down and arrested all the six - Sudha and her accomplices M Senthilkumar alias Soda Senthil, 56; K Satheesh, 31; M Kamal, 50; V Prasanth, 24; and C Ajay, 38, all natives of Palakkad district – on Friday night.

The officer said Sudha was separated from her husband and has been living with her mother in Tirupur. She has two children. “She was operating the gang with the help of Senthilkumar. They were planning to extort money from various businessmen.” Senthilkumar, he said, was earlier sentenced to life for murdering his first wife’s lover.

All the six have been lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison under judicial custody.

Title: Coimbatore to host conference on sustainable cities soon
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

COIMBATORE: The city will host a two-day international conference on sustainable cities on Kumaraguru College of Technology and PSG college campuses. The main objectives of the conference are to promote India-Israel research partnership between academic institutions in the area of sustainable cities, bring in the best of Israel’s sustainable cities technologies to India, and identify research opportunities that localizes the research and makes it relevant for Indian stakeholders.

To be held on Tuesday and Wednesday, the event would be attended by 15 delegates from two institutions in Israel, high tech farmers from Kongu region, NGOs and agro researchers, among others. The speakers will include researchers in agriculture and water management domain from Israel and India.

According to Ravi Kandasamy, director of technical services, Kumaraguru College of Technology, the event would be organized jointly by four educational institutions.

The four education institutions are Tel Aviv University in Israel; Agricultural Research Organization , Volcani Center in Israel; Kumaraguru College of Technology; and PSG College of Technology, Coimbatore.

Title: Pesticides in paddy straw may affect milk production in cattle, fear farmers
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The state animal husbandry department is yet to put in place a mechanism to check the presence of chemical fertilisers and pesticides in paddy straw and its effect on cattle and the quality of milk they produce.

Paddy straw is utilised both as green fodder as well as dry fodder. Though considered a source of food for cattle around the year, especially milch cattle, the hay contains remains of pesticides and chemical fertilisers that are used in paddy production. The hay also contains oxalates that affect milk production.

A number of farmers in north-coastal Andhra depend on animal husbandry, and especially milch cattle as a source of daily cash flow and to augment income. Of late, the increasing dependence on readily-available paddy hay has affected milk production in the region.

“Earlier our animals were fed legume straw and would also be taken to common pastures for feeding. However, with the availability of paddy hay on the rise, there has been a shift. Of late we have noticed that animals which feed on green paddy grass and hay have a tendency to become weak. We were informed by experts in the animal husbandry department that this was because of calcium loss due to the presence of oxalates. Now, we are forced to give them calcium additives, while earlier we just fed them naturally and locally-available food,” said Ch Raju, a farmer from Narsipatnam division.

With only two forensic labs in AP and Telangana, one in Hyderabad and the other in Vijayawada, an in-depth study is yet to be carried out. “Usually most pesticides and chemical fertilisers do not have a long-lasting effect,” said B Ramakrishna, joint director of the animal husbandry department, Visakhapatnam.

Title: TN: Cancer survivor, organ donor turns author
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

CHENNAI: She fought many battles to keep her son, a chronic renal failure patient, alive. After surviving breast cancer herself, Vasundhara Raghavan helped her son manage his chronic kidney disease and undergo renal transplants twice. Today, she runs Kidney Warriors Foundation, an organization that helps people with kidney diseases gather information on diet and dialysis through face, besides offering them technical and sometimes financial assistance.

“My son had a problem of bed-wetting. When we took him to the doctor, he told us he will be fine in four or five years. When he wasn’t, I took him again. This time, doctors told us I should have brought him to them at least four years ago. I never recovered from the guilt that I could have prevented my son’s disease,” she said at the 45 minute-talk on ‘The Kidney Warriors - A New Outlook to the Kidney Disease Challenge’ organized by the TANKER Foundation. Behind her the message on the screen was: Kidney disease is not our choice, it just happened.

Two days after she cleared tests to donate a kidney to her then teenaged son, Raghavan was diagnosed with breast cancer, she told TOI. This was followed by surgery and cycles of chemotherapy and radiation that delayed her turning a donor by three years. She finally went back to the hospital as her son’s donor in 1999. The next six-and-a-years held multiple hospital visits for Aditya Raghavan, whose immune system was fighting the new organ . He had to return to dialysis when the new kidney gave up. In 2009, Aditya had his second transplant with his elder brother being the donor. It was a success and ended the bed-wetting.

Aditya completed his masters degree at IIT-Bombay and a PhD in Physics the US while battling the disease. “He now makes cheese. I have written nearly four books (on kidney ailments),” she said. Though based in Dubai, she is campaigning with the government to change organ laws in the country.

Vasundhara Raghavan was presented with an award by Tanker Foundation for her exemplary work in the field. Awards were also given to diabetologists Dr R M Anjana, Dr Prahalathan K K, and Dr C V Krishnaswami, nephrologists Dr M A Muthusethupathi and Dr Nanditha Choudhury.

Title: Three missing boys found in Maharashtra’s Solapur
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Three minor boys, who went missing from Kushaiguda three days ago, were traced in Sholapur on Saturday.

Rachakonda police said that the boys, aged between 15 and 16 years, left their residences without informing their parents. After the police received information that they were travelling on a Mumbai-bound train, the railway police were informed and they were rescued at Sholapur.

During questioning, the boys revealed that they boarded a train from Kachiguda railway station and reached Tirupati.

Later they boarded another train bound to Maharashtra. While they were travelling in an unreserved compartment, one of the boys called up his parents using a co-passenger’s phone. However, he did not speak.

Suspecting that it could be their son, the parents alerted the police and shared the phone number. The police used the number to track their location.

Title: Five Tamil Nadu woodcutters arrested in Tirumala
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: Five woodcutters from Tamil Nadu were nabbed in Tirumala by TTD vigilance and security wing sleuths on Saturday.

According to TTD’s assistant vigilance and security officer Veera Babu, five men were seen moving around suspiciously near Srivari pushkarini, adjacent to the Tirumala temple. Following which the sleuths arrested them. ‘‘We located them near the temple tank with the help of our CCTV cameras and nabbed them”, he said.

On being questioned, they revealed that they are woodcutters from Tiruvannamalai in Tamil Nadu. They were hired by red sanders smugglers and were about to enter the Seshachalam forests to fell and smuggle red sanders away.

An inspection of their belongings, however, did not reveal anything suspicious.

The five were handed over to Tirumala police, who have registered a case.

Title: Boosting health with black alkaline water
Content: Aakash Vaghela, founder & managing director, AV Organics LLPIn the wellness products segment, natural, black alkaline water is a product available across select countries globally. Venturing into this maiden space with an investment of more than $2 million, Vadodara-based startup, AV Organics, recently launched the country’s first natural black alkaline water, Evocus, in Gujarat. Alkaline water is infused with minerals and is known to give better hydration and better detoxification.Past JourneyAfter studying Global Business Management in Macroeconomics from London University, Aakash Vaghela, founder and managing director, AV Organics, took over his family business in the real estate sector. “I came across the concept of alkaline water and its benefits in 2016 but didn’t find any Indian brand offering it. Dr Nobert Chirase later helped us develop the product. Then we took the big leap,” said Vaghela.AV Organics, which was incorporated in August 2018, invested $1 million in the setting up of the plant. The company’s total investment in launching the wellness product will be $2.5 million by the end of March 2020. The latest launch of the product in Gujarat was preceded by its launch in cities like Pune, Chandigarh, Jaipur, Delhi and Gurgaon, among others.Next StepsThe Vadodara-based startup had been recently conferred the ‘Pride of Gujarat’ Award by CM Vijay Rupani in the field of entrepreneurship. Going forward, the company plans to launch products in more Indian cities. “Our plant in Vadodara has an installed capacity of 40 million bottles a year and we plan to retail at least 25,000 cases (bottles) by the end of June 2020,” said Vaghela. AV Organics is also in the process of developing newer products in the wellness segment.ChallengesAlkaline water is black in colour and thus convincing customers and distribution is a major challenge. “Convincing distributors, retailers and customers to try out alkaline water that is black in colour and yet a wellness product, is a challenge. Currently we have 14 super-stockists and 40 distributors who supply our product but getting there has been a challenge,” said Vaghela. “Through constant product innovation and ensuring a better product offering, we are trying to address this challenge,” he further added.Secret to SuccessAccording to Vaghela, finding the right team that understands the product and strives to innovate is something that has always worked. “The uniqueness of the product is what has always worked for us but setting up a good team has steered our journey to success,” he said.

Title: ‘Pocso convicts must be made to give half wealth to victims’
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The fine limit for acts of crime committed under the Pocso Act is not fixed, and the perpetrator could be asked to part with half his wealth to the victim, if the trial is conducted in a proper manner and conviction is awarded, justice T Raja, judge of the Madras high court has said.

Speaking at the inauguration of the special court for exclusive trial of cases under Pocso Act, 2012, in Madurai on Saturday, justice Raja said that advocates should be aware of the facts of the case they are pursuing. Pocso is an Act with severe conditions and the minimum punishment is 20 years while the maximum is death sentence for a crime involving aggravated sexual penetration and assault.

The special court was inaugurated by justice N Nisha Banu , who said that it would help obtain speedy justice for the victims. Many children are violated in today’s society and parents should remember that it is difficult to repair a broken child, and give them extra care accordingly, she said.

Offences against children and women is a social problem, and needs to be addressed with a social concern. Creating awareness among the children is one way in which it could be tackled, said commissioner of police, Madurai, S Davidson Devasirvatham.

He said that 409 Pocso cases have been booked in Madurai so far posing a big challenge to the police. There has been an increase in these cases in recent times. While 33 were registered in 2017, it was 53 in 2018 and 80 in 2019, he said. Police should pursue love affair cases involving minors , which often do not witness conviction rates as the parents’ tend to withdraw the cases. Police should involve in quality investigation and the investigation officer should not compromise on the justice being obtained for a victim, he said. The new court would ensure speedy trial, which would instil confidence among victims of such cases, Devasirvatham said.

IG South Zone, K P Shanmugarajeswaran, said that 7-8 out of 10 cases registered under the Pocso Act were motivated by elders against minors, which are mutually settled later. This delayed the investigation of real cases of violations against children. Awareness is a must at all levels which was being done right from the school level, he added.

Madurai collector Dr T G Vinay said the rise in offences against children was a cause for concern, and that boys in the family should also be educated and sensitized on this issue. Advocate M Theivakani and advocate S Mohankumar stressed on the importance of ensuring moral education in all schools, as the number of minors booked under the Pocso Act for committing crimes, was a matter of concern.

Title: Railway working to introduce Coimbatore-Rameswaram train
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Overwhelmed by the response received to the Coimbatore-Rameswaram special train that was introduced for the Pongal season, the Salem division of Southern Railway is planning to run the train on a trial basis and make it permanent eventually. The division is now working out on the logistics and timings for the same.

It is to be noted that a night train to Rameswaram from the city via Pollachi and Madurai was also one of the requests that MLA and deputy speaker Pollachi V Jayaraman had made to the general manager of Southern Railway on Thursday. He had also pitched for a day train or an intercity express between Coimbatore and Madurai, as that would help businessmen and traders who frequently travel between the two cities.

These two services have been long-pending demands from the residents of Pollachi-Udumalpet belt. Pointing out that the Salem division used to run trains to these two destinations earlier, Coimbatore MP P R Natarajan said the services were stopped when the gauge conversion work began. “Now, it’s only a matter of reintroducing them.”

The Salem division said the requests for the trains were sent to the Southern Railway headquarters, which has forwarded them to the railway board. “We have also submitted all our logistical workings to show the trains’ feasibility. We are constantly trying to improve the logistics to get these trains introduced. We have to keep introducing new trains and it has been awhile since we introduced a new train,” said Subba Rao, divisional railway manager.

Title: TMREIS accused of child labour, video goes viral
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A video allegedly showing students of Telangana Minority Residential School, Moghalpura, assisting with construction work on Saturday went viral on social media on Saturday. While child activists said that the kids were being used as child labourers, officials of Telangana Minorities Residential Educational Institutions Society ( TMREIS ) claimed that the students were being encouraged to keep the campus clean as part of ‘Patashala Pragathi’ programme.

The video allegedly shows students dressed in their school uniforms carrying sand. “TMREIS students are being treated as child labourers. Action should be taken against the principal under the Child Labor Prevention Act and Juvenile Justice Care,” said child rights activist Achyuta Rao.

Meanwhile, speaking to STOI, TMREIS secretary B Shafiullah said that some passers-by recorded the video and shared it on social media without the logo of the programme. “The Patashala Pragathi programme, in line with Palle Pragathi, has been launched in all 204 schools under TMREIS. As part of the programme, different committees consisting of students and teachers were formed to clean the campus,” said Shafiullah.

Title: Workshop for district education officers in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

MADURAI: Around 60 district education officers (DEOs) from across Tamil Nadu took part in a special two-day workshop, which began on Saturday at Pillar Centre near Madurai Kamaraj University .

The workshop was organized by the Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA) mainly for the newly-promoted DEOs to provide training in administrative skills. “The DEOs were trained to better handle administrative-related issues. They were also given a detailed briefing about the projects implemented by SSA and its execution,” said an SSA official who is co-ordinating the programme.

Title: Treat for vegetarians at Green Dot Gourmet Food Fest
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: Vegetarians who feel left out because of shortage of options to gorge on during several food festivals in the city will have the opportunity to feast on some sumptuous and lip-smacking dishes at the exclusively vegetarian Green Dot Gourmet Food Fest.

The one-of-its-kind Green Dot by The Times of India will have delicious vegetarian dishes on offer on February 1 and 2 at Vrindavan Garden in Baner from 11am to 10pm.

With an exciting line-up of restaurants and outlets serving Indian and international cuisines, patrons will be spoilt for choice. Among the cuisines that will be featured at the festival are Biryani, Chaat, Tandoori, Mexican food and Oriental, among others. For those who enjoy guilt-free eating, vegan and keto delicacies will also be a part of the festival.

Several popular restaurants and food trucks from the city, including Marrakesh, Chaat Bazaar, Kolhapuri Tadka, Baan Tao by Hyatt Pune, Mosaic by Crowne Plaza, Pop Tates, Masti Misal and Let’s Baati, will dish out delicacies during the two days.

Apart from the exclusively vegetarian cuisine, the festival will also feature an assortment of other activities to make for a perfect evening outdoors. Live bands will set the stage with soothing music to match the ambience of the venue. Few steps ahead, mixologists will display their flair for innovative and non-alcoholic cocktails. Chefs from renowned hotels and restaurants will take the stage for a masterclass so that you can replicate some delicacies in the comfort of your homes.

A separate cake and pastries chef masterclass will guide the participants through some sumptuous desserts. The two-day contest will also feature a sandwich-making competition during which children will get a chance to show off their culinary skills. The festival will also host a fashion workshop to help patrons dress their best for a party.

The Times of India Green Dot Gourmet Food Fest is powered by VTP Realty and curated by Pune Eat Outs. Girikand Travels and Ranka Jewellers are the associate sponsors.

Title: Chittoor: Conman held for duping unemployed youngster
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: A conman who duped an unemployed youth was arrested by Chittoor district police on Sunday.

Chittoor DSP K Eswar Reddy said the accused, identified as M Hemanth Kumar (32) was residing at Chandragupta Nagar in Chittoor town. He was arrested by Chittoor Two-Town police based on a complaint lodged by one T Lokeshwar of Nagireddypalle in Puthalapattu mandal.

Hemanth Kumar had promised to secure a government job for Lokeshwar and collected Rs 5.14 lakh in cash and a laptop from Lokeshwar. When there was no news from him, Lokeshwar lodged a complaint.

Police nabbed the conman, who confessed to committing similar offences in the district. Chittoor DSP said Hemanth Kumar had duped 12 youth and collected Rs 36.6 lakh in cash from them.

Title: Relief for Dhanori, Lohegaon residents as civic body issues tender for development plan road
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

MLA Sunil Tingre (centre) with civic officials at the proposed DP Road site near Dhanori Jakat Naka.

PUNE: The construction of the much-awaited DP road from Dhanori Jakat Naka to DY Patil College is finally on track with the Pune Municipal Corporation issuing a tender of Rs 6 crore for the project.

This development plan (DP) road will run parallel to Porwal Road and benefit the residents of Lohegaon and Dhanori, who had been pushing for the project for years now.

Lohegaon resident Meenakshi Kadam said residents were forced to battle daily traffic issues and the new road would, hopefully, put an end to their plight. “We appreciate the efforts taken by the local leaders for taking up our demands seriously,” she said.

An active volunteer of ‘Green Run marathon’ held recently for DP road development, Prashant Lage, said, “This area was neglected for years. But, now there is some hope. We have also suggested the local MLA to take up the development of other internal roads in the area.”

The residents said once the DP road was constructed, it would help reduce traffic volume on Porwal Road. “The construction of the DP road will bring much-needed relief to the residents of Dhanori and Lohegaon areas,” Sandeep Lokhande, vice-president of the Lohegaon Residents’ Welfare Association (LRWA), said.

When contacted, MLA Sunil Tingre told TOI, “The road will be of 60-metre wide and about 2.1km long. A majority of the land for the project was acquired between 2012 and 2015, following which about 1km of the road was developed. However, the construction was stopped over land acquisition issues thereafter. The tender for the project was floated on January 17.”

A civic official said a section of the road, about 200 metres, was still facing some issue, for which Section 205 (power to make public road by compulsory acquisition of private land) of the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporation Act, 1949, would be applied.

Aniruddha Pawaskar, head of the civic road department, said, “The residents of Dhanori and Lohegaon, besides the members of LRWA, have been constantly following up for construction of this road. Considering their demands, the tender was floated and once construction begins, it will be ready within six months.”

Title: Scope for specialisation in ENT is vast, say docs
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: “With highly advanced technology now available, the scope of super-specialisation in the field of ENT has vastly increased, some of which include otology, rhinology, cochlear implants, facial plastics, sinusitis, sleep apnoea and phono-surgery,” said renowned rhinology expert and skull base surgeon from Trichy, Dr TN Janakiram, who is in Vizag to attend a live surgical workshop on rhinology and skull base surgery organised by the Government ENT Hospital this weekend.

Around 200 delegates from Telangana, Odisha, Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand and AP are attending the workshop.

Workshop course director Dr S Suryaprakasa Rao and organising secretary Dr K Jeevan Pradeep, principal of Andhra Medical College Dr PV Sudhakar, superintendent of KGH Dr G Arjuna also attended the inaugural on Saturday.

Speaking at the inaugural, Dr Arjuna said modern gadgets like flexible endoscopes and high definition cameras have brought about a technological revolution and several disciplines have emerged from this field.

Dr Janakiram is participating as guest faculty to perform surgeries for various nose, paranasal sinuses and skull base diseases.

Title: Seized plastics sent for road laying in Dindigul
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Corporation commissioner S Visakan inspected three tonnes of plastics seized by the civic body which were sent to a private firm in Dindigul for road laying works on Saturday.

As much as 24 tonnes of plastics have been seized in the city from January 1, 2019, and a total fine of Rs 35 lakh has been collected. The corporation commissioner had said that the seized plastics would be sent to the cement factories and used for road laying by mixing it with tar and bitumen.

City health officer Dr Senthil Kumar, assistant city health officer Vinod Raja, among others were present.

Title: Anti-Sterlite protest: Poor cooperation from government departments for probe, says panel
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Stating that financial relief has also been given to most victims, they have also sought speedy disposal of co... Read More

MADURAI: The one-member retired justice Aruna Jagadeesan commission that is probing the anti-Sterlite protest, riots and police firing that claimed 13 lives on May 22 and 23, 2018, has cited poor cooperation from the government departments and Tuticorin district administration.

Counsel for the commission, Vadivel Murugan told this to reporters in Tuticorin on Saturday on completion of the 18th sitting of the inquiry. “We have asked officials concerned for the places where the 108 ambulances and fire tenders were stationed during the procession on May 22 (2018) but we have not got it so far,” he said. Stating that they have sent reminders to those officials, he added that they have also asked for footage recorded in the CCTV cameras at three places in the Tuticorin collectorate, but are yet to receive it. “We have asked footage for one week before the incident took place,” he said and added that it would be instrumental for continuance of the probe.

Murugan said that employees of Sterlite staying in the places affected during the protest, forensic personnel who submitted the ballistic report, doctors who conducted the autopsy and those who treated the injured will be inquired in the next sitting, which is likely to be held in the third week of February. Apart from police officers who have submitted affidavits to the commission, officers in the rank of DIG, SP, DSP and inspector and police personnel who were present during the turn of events are being identified with the available video footage. The commission on identifying the personnel is summoning them through the police department.

Vadivel said the commission has also written to the Tuticorin district administration to give relevant government jobs based on the education qualification of the kin of those killed in the incident. Stating that financial relief has also been given to most victims, they have also sought speedy disposal of compensation to the few victims who were left out.

Title: Court allows defamation case against DMK president MK Stalin
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

MK Stalin

DHARMAPURI: The district court has allowed a civil defamation suit filed against DMK president M K Stalin for allegedly trying to malign the reputation of chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and deputy chief minister O Pannerselvam .

Principal district judge A Kanthakumar on Friday evening allowed the case filed by public prosecutor Pasupathy and posted it for a hearing on February 24.

Pasupathy, in his petition, said Stalin made ‘totally fallacious and defamatory statements’ against the chief minister and the deputy chief minister at a meeting in the town on November 16, 2019.

“He intentionally tried to malign the leaders and the state government by making false statements during his speech,” he alleged.

The petition was filed under sections 499 and 500 (civil defamation) of the IPC.

Title: Gurugram cops slap Rs 3 lakh cyber fraud charge on duped man
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Ramesh (name changed), who works as a salesman, was shocked when Gurugram Police served notices to him naming him as accused in a cyber fraud case. He was accused of duping people of Rs 3 lakh.

Shaken, Ramesh approached Vijayawada police and requested them to come to his rescue. The cybercrime wing launched an investigation into the issue. It was revealed during the course of investigation that Ramesh shared his Aadhar card, PAN card and bank account details with an unidentified person through Whatsapp. The person claimed to be a representative of his bank and said Ramesh’s debit card was deactivated because it was not linked with his Aadhaar card.

He asked Ramesh to send his debit card number and bank account details along with a photograph of both the PAN and Aadhaar card placing them on a white paper with his signature. After sending the details, his account was debited by Rs 1,750. When Ramesh enquired about the deduction of money, the person replied that the sum would be deposited in two days. Ramesh did not file a complaint as the amount he lost was small and was not willing to go to police.

Cybercrime inspector K Shivaji said the fraudsters first tried to loot Ramesh’s account, but as he was a poor person and did not have much in his account, they created a PayTm account with his credentials. Using the PayTm account, the fraudsters cheated other people, following which Gurugram Police registered a case and came all the way to Vijayawada looking for Ramesh. Vijayawada Police cleared Ramesh’s name .

Title: Fake attendance documents: Bar Council of Tamil Nadu and Puducherry warns 1,000 lawyers of severe action
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Bar Council of Tamil Nadu and Puducherry has warned more than 1,000 lawyers who have enrolled as advocates by producing forged college attendance certificates of severe action unless they surrendered their enrolment certificates immediately.

The issue came to light when Vipin – a retired employee of Southern Railways — approached the council for enrolment. He claimed that he had successfully completed law degree from Smt Basava Rama Tarakam Memorial Law College, Cuddapah, Andhra Pradesh in 2015-18. As per the rules set by the Madras high court , candidates who have secured law degrees from states other than TN must produce attendance certificates from the college. Vipin had produced an attendance certificate , which on verification by the council, was found to be forged and obtained in connivance with the college’s principal Himavantha Kumar. Kumar was arrested subsequently. A preliminary inquiry revealed that more than 1,000 advocates enrolled with the council had obtained such forged certificates from the college.

Briefing reporters, the council’s chairperson P S Amalraj said, “Such people must surrender their enrolment certificates immediately. If not, criminal action will be initiated besides ensuring that pension and other benefits they enjoy are stopped.” Amalraj said a committee is verifying certificates produced by candidates with other state law degrees.

“Certificates of 65,000 advocates have been verified and a timeframe will be fixed to complete the rest. List of advocates eligible to practice will be published on the council’s website once the scrutiny is over,” he added.

Title: Nun rape case: Francofiles discharge petition
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Kottayam: Bishop Franco Mulakkal filed a discharge petition in a court here in the nun rape case on Saturday. His counsel filed the petition before additional district court 1 judge G Gopakumar, pleading to discharge him of the charges without facing trial. His counsel argued that the offences levelled against him won’t stand and the case was based solely on the statement of case witness one who allegedly had a personal grudge against the bishop.

The counsel also argued that most of the prosecution witnesses are not in good terms with the Church. The case was posted for objection and hearing on discharge petition on February 4. The prosecution will raise objection to the discharge petition on that day.

Bishop Mulakkal did not appear before the court. The case was adjourned to Saturday for hearing on the charges against the bishop.

The nun had filed a complaint with the Kottayam police chief about the alleged sexual abuse from 2014 to 2016 on June 27, 2018. The next day, June 28, the statement of the nun was also recorded.

The chargesheet in the case was filed on April 9, 2019. Mulakkal faces charges of wrongful confinement, rape, unnatural sex and criminal intimidation in the case.

Title: College student hospitalised with diphtheria
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

SALEM: A private college student admitted with possible diphtheria symptoms in Salem government Mohan Kumaramangalam medical college hospital (GMKMCH), was diagnosed with it on Friday. She was sent to the government hospital in Coimbatore for further treatment. The student Roja (name changed) was pursuing her bachelor’s degree from a private arts and science college in Ponnammapet area. There, she developed breathing difficulty and throat pain.

The doctors later alerted the district health department following which a team of doctors rushed to the college. “As a precautionary measure, we have administered injections to more than 2500 students of the college,” Dr. Nirmalson, deputy director (DD) of health services department said.

The DD also said that diphtheria had been eradicated from the state about 30 years ago. “It has made a comeback in the district,” he said, assuring that the disease would be eliminated from the district at the earliest.

He appealed those who have difficulty in breathing and swallowing or throat pain, to come to GMKMCH for blood test, and if need be, a treatment. He also warned that timely intervention is essential for diphtheria.

Title: Regional boards may absorb MLC hopefuls if council nixed
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Amaravati: The proposed regional development boards are going to rehabilitate legislative council seat hopefuls from the ruling YSRC if the council is abolished.

Many former legislators and veteran leaders have been dreaming of entering the portals of the legislature through the council since Jaganmohan Reddy took over the reins of the state.

While Jagan himself promised several of them a seat in the council during his poll campaign, a few others loyal to the party supremo for the past decade joined the race after the polls.

The hopes of all such leaders have now been dashed after the chief minister’s threat to abolish the council after failing to pass the capital decentralisation and CRDA repeal bills in the council. The ruling party leaders have now come to the conclusion that abolishing the council is necessary to check opposition TDP.

Many of them feel the party will definitely recognise their services and reward them in the future.

Sources said back room operators of the party were working with smart strategies to handle the situation for the past several months as they were aware of the council’s fate.

The strategists have reportedly devised plans to set up regional development boards to serve multiple purposes including accommodating their party men with protocol status. While the abolishment of the council would leave the TDP without any political say or protocol, the new boards would empower YSRC functionaries to take the lead in implementation of welfare and developmental programmes.

Though the proposed regional boards will have at least four nominated members, the government is likely to increase the berths to 10 after the council is abolished. In such a scenario, at least 40 YSRC leaders will get a place in the boards, which is equivalent to the rank of MLA. Interestingly, YSRC’s strength might not cross 25-30 even if the council exists and it will take at least three years to achieve majority numbers. Getting 40 berths in the regional boards by losing 30 berths in the council will get rid of the TDP, and also accommodate council hopefuls from YSRC.

Title: Khambhat riots: SIT formed to investigate death of man
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Police heighten vigil in the area

VADODARA/ ANAND: A special investigation team (SIT) has been formed to probe the death of the elderly man who died in firing in communal riots that had broke out in the sensitive Akbarpura area of Khambhat town of Anand district on Friday.

Even as the family of the deceased man refused to accept the body till Saturday evening, a SIT was formed to probe whether 65-year-old Vinod Chavda had died due to private firing or government firing.

“Considering the sensitive nature of the death, we have formed the SIT comprising police inspector of Vallabh Vidyanagar and police sub inspectors of Khambolaj and Virsad,” said Anand district superintendent of police Makrand Chauhan.

Demanding that the cops should register a complaint against police inspector of Khambhat in connection to Chavda’s death, family members of the deceased had refused to take possession of the dead body till late Saturday evening.

Chavda was sitting inside an auto rickshaw which he had boarded from Tran Batti area to reach Lal Darwaja area of the town when a bullet hit him resulting in his death.

While the cops have maintained that private firing could have resulted in Chavda’s death, family members allege that he died due to police firing.

Meanwhile, over 50 accused were arrested by the police in connection to the riots in the town that had left around 15 cops injured. Mobs from both the communities had resorted to heavy stone pelting at each other while nearly ten houses and shops were set ablaze and several vehicles vandalized.

Police had fired six rounds in the air and lobbed 25 tear gas shells to quell the mob but the rioters had continued to pelt stones even in the presence of cops.

Markets in and around Akbarpura area of the town remained closed on Saturday as well amidst heavy bandobast that was deployed since Friday to prevent escalation of violence. A complaint has been registered against a mob of 150 persons in connection to the riots.

Title: President medals for two Pune policemen
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: An officer from Maharashtra Anti-Terrorism Squad’s Pune unit and another from the Pune rural police are received the President’s Police Medal for Meritorious Services on the eve of Republic Day.

ATS’s assistant sub-inspector Pradeep Harischandra Jambhale has solved many serious cases and is known for his wide network. He has cracked murder cases, kidnapping and extortion, and dacoity cases. He was a key member of the team that nabbed three men for acting as spies for Pakistan’s notorious ISI agency. Besides, he was also instrumental in the arrests of five Bangladeshi nationals in the city involved in suspicious activities.

Assistant sub-inspector Dashrath Baburao Chinchkar of the Pune rural police is currently posted with the Vadgaon Maval police station. Chinchkar has worked with different police stations and also the state anti-corruption bureau (ACB). He was a key member of the team that solved the infamous case, in which ornaments of Lord Khandoba were stolen.

Title: Any disease spread can be checked: Madurai doctors
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Even as a deadly new strain of coronavirus continues to spread havoc across the world, doctors in Madurai have exuded confidence that the spread of any illness can be prevented, as was done in the case of swine flu. However, they admit that at the moment not much is known about the new virus in terms of its origin, spread, diagnosis, risk population and treatment.Chinese authorities had identified the coronavirus as a family of viruses that causes illnesses including the common cold, Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS). On Wednesday, a symposium on coronavirus was held at Government Rajaji Hospital here. “As researches show, many viruses which were so far dormant in animals have the ability to suddenly mutate and spread illness to human beings. Such instances are increasing which is of concern as it takes time to figure out and treat a new illness,” said Dr Prabhakaran, HOD of thoracic medicine at GRH.

Title: Leopard troubling Yedgaon village trapped in cage
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

The leopard trapped at Yegaon village on Friday.

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: A leopard was trapped in a cage at Yedgaon village on Friday.

SR Katte, RFO, Khodad, confirmed that a leopard has been trapped at Yedgaon village. Naresh Nerkar, sarpanch, Yedgaon village, said, “Leopards were being sighted at Yedgaon village for the past two-three months. A person riding a two-wheeler was attacked by a leopard recently, but no one was injured in the incident. We contacted the forest department officials and they installed a cage two months ago. The cage was shifted after a week to a new location. The leopard was found in the cage on Friday morning.”

He said the leopard was sent to the leopard rescue centre at Manikdoh. “We suspect that there is at least one more leopard roaming around the surrounding areas. So, we have demanded that a cage be installed in the village,” he said.

The forest department installed a cage at Katewadi village in Baramati taluka on Friday following a few incidents of leopard attacks this week.

“We installed a cage at Katewadi on Friday. Leopards have been sighted at Katewadi and Kanhere gram panchayat limits. We have also found pugmarks and are conducting night patrolling in the villages and carrying out public awareness campaigns,” said Rahul Kale, range forest officer (RFO), Indapur, who also holds the additional charge of Baramati. He said the forest department suspects the presence of two leopards in these villages.

A sheep was injured on Monday last in a leopard attack in Katewadi, while a goat was killed and a sheep injured on Thursday in Kanhere village. The incidents created fear among villagers in Kanhere and Katewadi.

Leopards are mostly found in the sugar cane fields of Junnar, Ambegaon and Shirur talukas in the district. “Leopards have been spotted in Daund taluka in the past two years, but not in Baramati taluka. So, we feel that leopards from Daund taluka may have strayed here,” said Kale.

On January 20, a 28-year-old youth was injured in a leopard attack at village Pimpalgaon Siddhnath, 3km ahead of Junnar, following which a cage was installed in the area by the forest department.

Title: Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad to address TISS students
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

File photo of Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad

HYDERABAD: Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad will attend a public meeting at Tata Institute of Social Sciences ( TISS ) at Abdullapurmet on Sunday.

TISS students’ union members said on the occasion of Republic Day, they would be organizing a protest programme against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ), National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NPC), in which the Bhim Army chief would participate.

“Chandrashekhar Azad will address students over CAA along with several other issues that students are facing on campuses across the country,” a student union member said, adding that they would also be reading out the Preamble of the Constitution on Sunday at the public meeting.

While in the city, Azad is also likely to participate in a public meeting being organized by the All India Dalit Muslim Adivasi Progressive Front at Crystal Garden in Mehdipatnam.

Students of various universities in the state have been organizing protest programmes against CAA and police brutality since December.

Title: Interactive session on dementia held
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Alzheimers and Related Disorders Society of India (ARDSI) organised an interactive session on dementia on Saturday at the Visakhapatnam Public Library. Dementia is a progressive, degenerative brain disease affecting a person’s memory, thinking, and the ability to interact socially.

K Sashidhar, co-founder and trustee of ARDSI said, “With the increase in population of elderly people, there will be a proportional rise in people suffering from Alzheimer’s disease , which accounts for 60-80% of dementia cases.” He further said that one in ten people, among people above the age of 65, suffer from dementia.

Bala, another co-founder said, “According to a few studies, the number of people suffering from dementia worldwide will double by 2030.”

Meanwhile, Dr NS Raju, managing trustee of Age Care Foundation said, “Creating awareness about screening, early detection and supportive care is our short-term objective. In the long-term, we seek to look after people with dementia in day care centres.”

Title: IMD forecast rules out El Nino possibility till Sept
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: The possibility of an El Nino, a vital indicator of how monsoon may fare during a year, can be ruled out till September this year.

This was indicated in the latest El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) Bulletin of the India Meteorological Department (IMD).

The update said warm ENSO-neutral conditions were prevailing over equatorial Pacific Ocean currently, but forecasts indicate cooling of sea surface temperatures in the coming season with ENSO-neutral conditions likely to continue for the entire forecast period.

ENSO-neutral conditions mean when there is neither an El Nino nor La Nina, the two factors impacting the Indian monsoon.

Mrutyunjay Mohapatra, director general of meteorology at IMD said, “It is too early to comment on how the monsoon may fare in the absence of an El Nino event as it is one of the factors governing the southwest monsoon, but not the only one.”

The forecast said there was over 65-75% probability of neutral conditions during the monsoon season (June-September 2020).

IMD officials said with the probability of neutral El Nino conditions from May this year, India's summer temperatures in 2020 could be normal or slightly above normal, as they may only be governed by the existing global warming trend and not an El Nino event. Like monsoon, El Nino is also said to impact country's temperatures, leading to higher than normal temperatures.

A senior IMD official told TOI that though ENSO neutral conditions prevailing, sea surface temperatures in equatorial Pacific Ocean were still on the warmer side. “As of now, there is less chance of an El Nino event till September, but we would need to wait and watch for any changes in the situation. Though slightly warmer than normal sea surface temperatures over the equatorial Pacific could prevail at that time, they are unlikely to cross the El Nino threshold,” the official said.

When asked about the Indian Ocean Dipole, which helps monsoon when in a positive phase, the official said a clear picture on this would emerge only in July.

On the likely temperatures during the next few months, the official said, “Right now, we are seeing clouding due to westerly activity and humidity in parts of the country, while maximum temperatures seem to be on the lower side in north India. As of now, we do not expect any immediate changes in temperatures. Since El Nino conditions are unlikely to prevail during the summer, whatever slight rise we may see in the average temperatures during this year’s summer season may only be due to the ongoing climate change situation or global warming.”

Graphic:

El Nino and La Nina are Spanish terms meaning ‘little boy’ and ‘little girl’, respectively

El Nino is a phenomenon of anomalous warming of the central and east equatorial Pacific Ocean with a quasi periodicity of 2-7 years, while La Nina is just the opposite phase of El Nino and is associated with anomalous cooling over the equatorial Pacific Ocean

El Nino events show a propensity to be associated with a weaker than normal summer monsoon rainfall over India

La Niña events show a propensity to be associated with a greater than normal rainfall

Title: Two arrested for robbing hotel owner in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Police have arrested two people after the owner of a popular restaurant at Surveyor Colony was robbed of his car and two mobile phones at his residence on Friday.

The accused have been identified as Venkatesh S, 22, former driver of the restaurant owner and Mahalingam M, 22. The stolen valuables were also recovered from them.

The incident took place when S Jeyaraman, 37, who resides in Sriram Garden in K Pudur had gone for a walk near his house at around 6am on Friday, police said. The two accused went to Jeyaraman’s residence and threatened the workers there with a sword asking for the key to their employer’s car. The two then made off with the car, two mobile phones valued at more than Rs 7 Lakh. The victim came to know of the incident only when one of the workers called him up.

As the workers immediately identified one of the robbers as a former driver who worked for Jeyaraman, the police were able to make arrests.

A case of robbery with the intent to cause injury has been registered at the K Pudur crime police station.

Title: Perfect score for IIM-V in summer internships
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The summer placement season for the fifth batch (PGP class of 2019-21) of the Indian Institute of Management, Visakhapatnam ( IIM-V ) concluded on Saturday with top companies offering summer internships to all participating students. All 121 students in the batch received summer internship offers with the highest stipend clocking Rs 2 lakh.

The average stipend of the top 10% is Rs 1,25,500 and the top quartile is Rs 98,482. The average for the entire batch stood at Rs 51,726. This has broken all previous records of the school.

The sector-wise spread of offers are: Banking, financial services and insurance (28%), consulting (9% ), conglomerate (5%), IT/ITES (25% ), e-commerce ( 6%), fintech (3% ), telecom (5%), logistics (1%), hospitality (3%), technology ( 3%), oil & gas ( 3%), manufacturing(6% ), education (1%), transportation (1%), automobile(1%).

Dominant roles offered in the internships are from: Sales and marketing (50%), strategy & advisory (10%), finance (15%), general management (4%), product management (9%), analytics (4%), HR (2%), operations ( 3%) and project management (3%).

Leading consulting firm Delloite recruited students for the advisory role.

Multinational conglomerate Bosch, L&T and Adani Group offered roles in general management, sales, marketing, HR and product management.

OPPO Mobiles has offered roles in areas of payments and product development. Blue-chip central public sector enterprises IOCL signed up students for the marketing domain.

Rashtriya e-Market Services (P) Ltd., a unified market platform of the Government of Karnataka is a new recruiter that hired the students to work on analytics of digitalised supply chain solutions.

Prof M Chandrasekhar, director, IIM-V said, “Crossing milestones ahead of competition is a way of life at the institute. The successful conclusion of summer placements in January is an exemplification of this fact. It’s also a reflection of our strengths that find an echo in the superior system our students bring to the table.”

Title: No speech by Asaduddin Owaisi at AIMIM meet
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

A protester speaking at Khilawat Ground in Old City on Saturday

HYDERABAD: Absence of a speech by AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi at the party’s protest meeting against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), NRC and NPR at Khilawat Ground in Old City on Saturday did not go unnoticed. The meet had to be ended quickly due to time restrictions imposed by the Telangana High Court.

Residents from Old City thronged the venue holding National Flags and anti-CAA placards. According to police, around 5,000 people attended the event.

This is the first time Asaduddin did not speak at an AIMIM protest led by him. However, he did take a jibe at the halwa ceremony organised by the finance ministry ahead of the budget session as well as the poha remark by Kailash Vijayvargiya.

“We don’t have much time as we have to respect the high court’s orders. If the police allows, we will form a human chain on January 30. So today, you can relax and return home and eat halwa or poha,” Owaisi said.

Poets, singers, JNU students, religious scholars and even a few protesters from Shaheen Bhag attended the meeting and also addressed the gathering.

The party had initially planned to hoist the National Flag at Charminar at midnight, but it was cancelled after a petition was filed in the HC following which the organisers were ordered to change the venue and timing. “We will obey the court’s decision. The high court is supreme, but not infallible,” Owaisi had said in a video, urging people to participate in the Saturday meeting.

Meanwhile, Urdu poet Rahat Indori received applause for his poem which emphasised on secularism.

Title: Bus owner, driver booked for illegally operating vehicle
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: The owner and driver of a private bus were booked on Friday for operating the vehicle without the required legal documents.

Gajanan Gurav (42), an inspector with the Regional Transport Office (RTO), Pune, filed a complaint with the Yerawada police on Friday.

The RTO officers caught the bus driver on December 17 last year at Shastri Chowk in Yerawada, while 27 senior citizens were on board. When the RTO team asked the driver for the vehicle’s documents, he failed to produce them, following which the vehicle was seized, the FIR stated.

An RTO official said the senior citizens had hired the bus for a tour of the city, Shani Shinganapur, Shirdi, Nashik, Thane and back to Pune. The bus operator had taken Rs8,000 from them in hiring charges.

Later, the RTO officials found out that the woman who owned the bus had not registered it with the Pune RTO. She had being doing the business using the temporary registration number, which is given to vehicles for a few days after they are purchased, the FIR stated.

The police said the bus owner had not submitted the registration charges and taxes to the RTO either. The suspects were using a fake number plate. The vehicle did not have the proper insurance documents.

The Yerawada police has registered a case of cheating and forgery against the two suspects.

Title: Over 2,500 take part in Walkathon in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

MADURAI: More than 2,500 school and college students, as well as women from various self-help groups, participated in a massive ‘ Walkathon ’ event in Madurai, organized by the DHAN foundation on Saturday.

The event was flagged off at Mariamman Teppakulam at 8 am by Madurai district collector Dr TG Vinay and corporation commissioner S Visakan. “Every year, we hold events like walkathon. The theme for this year and the previous year was set as women empowerment, something our organization is actively involved in by creating a network of women self-help groups, especially in rural areas,” said MP Vasimalai, executive director, DHAN foundation.

Students from various government schools and colleges, leaders from Vayalagam foundation and Kalanjiam foundation, and women from self-help groups from in and around Madurai city participated in the walkathon enthusiastically. “This kind of event helps us show people that even women from a rural background like us are empowered,” said Nirmala S from a self-help group in Vilangudi.

The walkathon culminated at the Gandhi Museum with a valedictory function. The chief guest Padmashri awardee Chinna Pillai, the woman behind a revolutionary banking system in Tamil Nadu villages that helped stop usury, distributed prizes to the participants of drawing and essay competition.

Various cultural programs were also held as several local women leaders and entrepreneurs shared their experiences. Sendhurnathan, senior divisional manager, LIC, BT Bangera, HiTech Arai and Tulsiraj, Aravind Eye Hospital were also a part of the event.

Title: Salem corporation seizes 870kg banned plastic from shops
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

SALEM: A team of officials from the Salem Municipal Corporation (SMC) seized 870kg of banned plastic materials including carry bags from 120 shops in the city on Saturday.

The officials have also imposed a total fine of Rs 67,000 on shopowners.

The Salem Municipal Corporation officials, led by corporation commissioner R Sadheesh inspected hotels, bakeries, grocery shops to check whether they were using banned plastic items in the city.

The corporation inspection team also closed a few shops for selling banned items.

The commissioner asked shop keepers to follow the state government’s order of using only cloth bags.

“Strict action will be initiated against anyone using plastic carry bags or any other plastic materials in their shops,” SMC commissioner R Sadheesh warned, adding that surprise checks will continue in future.

Title: Licensed revolver, cartridges stolen from businessman’s car at Vasna Road
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A businessman’s licensed revolver and 12 cartridges were stolen from his parked car at Vasna Road on Saturday afternoon.

Ajitsinh Solanki was visiting his lawyer at Pancham Icon complex on Vasna Road when thief broke one of the window panes of his car and stole the revolver and cartridges kept in a leather bag. Solanki said that he kept the bag behind the driver’s seat and went to meet the lawyer around 11.30 am. When he returned after half an hour later, at around 12pm, the rear window glass was broken and the bag containing the weapon was missing. Interestingly, the thief did not touch a laptop which was also kept in the car.

Solanki, who lives at Waghodiya and is a manufacturer of pharmaceutical packaging machines, registered a complaint of theft at Gotri police station. Police said that Solanki had bought the weapon in 2015 after getting a licence to use firearm. He often uses the weapon for practice at Baroda Rifle Club at Manjalpur of which he is also a member.

Cops said that till late in the evening on Saturday they checked CCTV cameras footage but are yet to find any substantial clue.

Title: Mediator among four more arrested in TNPSC scam
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The CB-CID police probing the ‘vanishing ink ’ scam related to the TNPSC Group-IV recruitment examinations on Saturday arrested four more people, three of whom figured in the list of top 100 candidates . A city court later remanded them in judicial custody.

Police identified the arrested as T Venkataramanan, 38, of Avadi; M Thiruvelmurugan, 31, of Ramanathapuram; R Rajasekar, 26, of Panruti in Cuddalore district, and M Kalesha, 29, of Gowripet near Ramanathapuram. Police said Venkataramanan acted as a mediator, collected funds and helped the three arrested and several others clear the exam . Thiruvelmurugan, R Rajasekar, and M Kalesha figured among the top 100 selected candidates.

The CB-CID police teams are conducting inquiries with a few more suspects picked up from Tirunelveli, Ramanathapuram and other parts of the state. Police sources told TOI that more arrests were likely.

Discrepancies in the top 100 candidates list lead to the TNPSC sniffing out the vanishing ink scam, wherein answerscripts of 52 candidates were found to be manipulated. Touts had given candidates pens with special ink that vanished in a few hours. The OMR answerscripts were later filled with the correct answer in collusion with some exam officials, resulting in 39 of the cheating candidates ending up among top 100.

On Saturday, special police teams of the CB-CID units conducted checks in five districts to zero in on brokers and mediators. A police officer privy to the probe said, “There are around 20 others, including candidates and mediators , in the custody of the CB-CID for inquiry.”

Busting of the racket led to several who appeared for exams to recruit sub-inspectors and Grade-II police constables conducted by the Tamil Nadu Uniformed Services Recruitment Board (TNUSRB) crying foul on social media about malpractice in these exams as well. TNUSRB, however, clarified that there was no foul play in its exams.

Title: Animal birth control: AMC mulls new tender
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) is planning to float a new tender to hire a private agency that will use its own infrastructure to carry out the animal birth control (ABC) programme.

The civic body is responsible for carrying out animal birth control programmes and there are guidelines for dog catching, sterilisation, pre- and post-operative procedures and rabies eradication.

Currently, the AMC has engaged the services of Ranchi based HOPE & Animal Trust to implement the programme in the city. According to the AMC, over the past six months, HOPE & Animal Trust has carried out 3,209 sterilisations. According to the contract, the agency isto get Rs 950 for each sterilisation.

However, the problem of stray dogs continues. On January 12, a two-and-a half year old girl was bitten by a stray dog in Padegaon. Last year, a 10 year old boy, a resident of Barudgar Nullah had succumbed to the injuries he got from an attack by a pack of dogs. Residential and commercial areas in Buddi Lane, City Chowk, Roshan Gate, Central Naka, Cidco N-3, N-5, N-9, N-11, Railway Station, Osmanpura and Mukundwadi complain of stray dogs posing a threat.

Bhagwat Naikwade, chief animal husbandry officer of the AMC, said the dog sterilisation programme would require improvement in the infrastructure of the AMC’s dog clinic at Central Naka. “Demolishing the existing operation theatre, OPD rooms and constructing new rooms, dog kennels for the pre- and post-operative care of dogs are required. A proposal was sent for financial approval last year.”

Meanwhile, on Friday, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said the AMC has given ultimatum to the agency for not performing up to the mark.

“In order to the address the problem of the infrastructure, we will issue tenders to invite agencies to use their own infrastructure and carry out the animal birth control programme,” Ghodele said.

The mayor added that the AMC will spend more money to hire such an agency.

Title: Pune: Foreign national attacks pregnant woman, booked
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 35-year-old man, purportedly from Ethiopia, has been booked by the Sangvi police for kicking and punching a pregnant woman from “Uganda” on the afternoon of January 4 at Pimple Gurav here.

The woman developed medical complications following the attack and had to undergo an abortion. She lodged a complaint with the Sangvi police on Thursday.

“The woman is in India on a student’s visa. The man, according to the woman, is from Ethiopia. We are still verifying their credentials,” senior inspector Dnyaneshwar Sabale of Sangvi police told TOI.

Police have sought their passports and other documents to verify their nationality and their stay in the city.

The woman (33) stays in Pimple Saudagar and is pursuing her higher studies from a college in Aundh area. According to the complaint, the man is a close friend of her husband.

However, due to some personal reasons the woman stopped communicating with him since the last six months. But the man kept on following her wherever she went, police said.

According to the FIR, the woman was walking down a road in Pimple Gurav when the man accosted her around 4.30pm. He asked her why she was avoiding him and not speaking to him.

“The woman, however, did not respond and continued to walk. Suddenly, the man grabbed her, kicked and punched her. Though the woman slumped to the ground, he continued to kick her,” the FIR states.

“Later in the night, her husband shifted her to a maternity home after she complained of severe pain. She developed medical complications and the doctors at the hospital decided to abort her pregnancy,” police said.

After being discharged from the hospital on Thursday, she approached the Sangvi police and lodged a complaint. “We will arrest her attacker soon,” a police official said.

Title: Gujarat: Panchmahal school’s ‘kiss video’ goes viral
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

VADODARA: A video of two school students kissing on the last bench of a classroom has gone viral in Panchmahal sparking a major row in its wake. The school has started an inquiry in the matter and has also reported the incident to the district education officials.

The video of Krishikar Secondary School located in Morva Hadaf shows a boy and a girl kissing in the presence of others who were not only egging them on in the act, but also recorded the whole incident on a mobile phone camera. Later the video was circulated widely on social media.

The incident also came to the notice of the school authorities who have started an inquiry in the incident. The inquiry is looking both into the act committed by the two students as well as those who supported, recorded and circulated the video.

Principal of the school Ashwin Patel said that the incident took place on Thursday during recess time. “We have informed the parents of not only the two students, but also two others who had recorded and circulated the video. They have been asked to come for an inquiry,” said Patel. The parents of only one student who had recorded the incident came to meet the principal on Saturday.

Patel said that the district education department was also informed regarding the incident and officials had visited the school. He added that students were not allowed to carry mobile phones to the school. “Mobile phones are seized whenever they are found on any student. We even check bags from time to time. Some phones we had confiscated from the students are still lying with us,” he said.
