The school has also sought an explanation from the supervisor of the section where the incident took place.

Title: President medals for Shivadhar, Akun & 28 others in Telangana, Andhra Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Shivadhar Reddy, Akun Sabharwal

HYDERABAD: Thirty police personnel, including an additional director-general rank officer from Telangana and two officers from AP, were awarded President’s medals by the Union ministry of home affairs (MHA) on Saturday.

MHA, on the eve of the 71st Republic Day, said AP director-general (Vigilance & Enforcement) KV Rajendranath Reddy, Telangana Addl DG (Personnel) B Shivadhar Reddy and AP assistant commissioner of police (West Division) K Sudhakar were awarded President’s Police Medal (PPM).

Twelve policemen from Telangana and 15 personnel from AP were awarded the Indian Police Medal. From Telangana, IPM were awarded to former director enforcement (Prohibition & Excise) Akun Sabharwal, who is now on central deputation, TS Special Police commandant R Venu Gopal, additional deputy commissioner of police (Special Branch) Iqbal Siddiqui, additional commandant P Satyanarayana, Nizamabad assistant commissioner of police D Pratap, Khammam assistant commissioner of police G Venkata Rao, Nalgonda deputy superintendent of police S Jayaram, Rangareddy district reserve inspector S Ravindranath, Warangal assistant sub-inspector K Sudhakar, assistant SI, Police Academy, N Nagalakshmi, Rangareddy district assistant sub-inspector R Anthi Reddy and senior commando D Ramesh Babu.

Similarly from AP, medals were awarded for Vijayawada ASP A Joshi, APSP additional commandant CVA Rama Krishna, CID deputy superintendent of police M Bhaskar Rao, Greyhounds commander G Vijay Kumar, Vijayawada inspector John Moses, Nellore sub-inspector NG Sankarudu, assistant sub-inspector P Victoria Rani, Chittoor assistant sub-inspector KN Kesavan, Anantapur SI S Ramachandraiah, head constable Y Chandrasekhar, head constable P Vijaya Bhaskar, and head constable N Rama Krishna Raju.

Title: Joint rally by Jana Sena, BJP deferred
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Vijayawada: The Jana Sena and Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) have postponed their ‘Kavathu’ (long march), scheduled on February 2 at Amaravati, to an yet-to-be decided date. The decision came after it was found out that the Swaraj Maidan, the venue for the rally , has been booked for a religious meeting on the same date. Andhra Pradesh state BJP leadership in a press release said they are committed to fight against the state government on the Amaravati issue. They clarified that the long march has been postponed due to technical reasons.

Meanwhile, key leaders of Jana Sena and BJP are likely to conduct a few meetings from Sunday and come up with an action plan to fight against the government in support of the Amaravati farmers.

Pawan Kalyan and BJP core leadership are likely to announce the fresh date of their ‘Kavathu’ after a coordination committee meeting on January 28, as per sources.

Both the parties are thinking of changing the route of the Kavathu considering the restrictions put in place by police.

Title: Inquire into previous exams conducted by TNPSC: Vaiko
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

SALEM: Rajya Sabha MP Vaiko on Friday urged the state government to ensure that there were no scams in the conduct of Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission (TNPSC) exams in the past by holding an inquiry with the people, who have cleared the same. He said touts shouldn’t be allowed to be “intruded” into TNPSC. The MDMK general secretary was in the city to attend the party meeting.

Vaiko lamented that, agriculture will be eradicated from delta districts if hydro carbon projects are implemented in southern Tamil Nadu.

“The Central government should not bring those projects in Tamil Nadu,” he said. He also warned that, Tamil Nadu will turn barren if those projects started here.

Citing Mekedatu dam project, Vaiko said that, the Mettur dam, the lifeline of Tamil Nadu, will not get water if that project commences across river Cauvery in Karnataka . The entire state will starve for potable water, he warned, adding that, the state government should raise its voice against these projects.

Asking about actor Rajnikanth’s speech on rationalist Periyar in a magazine’s golden jubilee function, Vaiko replied that, the actor could have avoided his speech on Periyar. “I don’t know, why he remembered that issue, when everyone had forgotten about that rally,” he said.

Title: Local artists steal hearts at 60th state-level art exhibition
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

AURANGABAD: Artists from Aurangabad have put up an impressive show of paintings, sculptures and other art forms in the ongoing art exhibition at the Yashwant Art College in the city.

The 60th state-level art exhibition is organised by the Directorate of Art, Maharashtra State, Mumbai, from January 24 to 29. The exhibition has 892 artworks which are made by students of art colleges from across the state.

Of the 5,300 students who sent in their entries, 800 were selected. The artworks displayed include paintings, sculptures, textile work, woodwork, fibre design, clay models, metal structures and murals. A large number of art lovers, art students and other people have been appreciating the work and effort put in for the exhibition.

Through the artworks, the artists have effectively presented the social scenario, touching upon topics like plastic pollution, water crisis, female foeticide, agriculture crisis, heritage conservation and portrayal of the working class.

City’s Mansi Deshmukh won the first prize in the interior design category for creating a model of a jewellery shop’s interior. Kailash Aade, Piyush Ukharde, Manoj Rathod, Shrutika Dabhade and Pratap Salampure from the city won awards in various categories.

Title: President medals for Shivadhar, Akun & 28 others in Telangana, Andhra Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Shivadhar Reddy, Akun Sabharwal

HYDERABAD: Thirty police personnel, including an additional director-general rank officer from Telangana and two officers from AP, were awarded President’s medals by the Union ministry of home affairs (MHA) on Saturday.

MHA, on the eve of the 71st Republic Day, said AP director-general (Vigilance & Enforcement) KV Rajendranath Reddy, Telangana Addl DG (Personnel) B Shivadhar Reddy and AP assistant commissioner of police (West Division) K Sudhakar were awarded President’s Police Medal (PPM).

Twelve policemen from Telangana and 15 personnel from AP were awarded the Indian Police Medal. From Telangana, IPM were awarded to former director enforcement (Prohibition & Excise) Akun Sabharwal, who is now on central deputation, TS Special Police commandant R Venu Gopal, additional deputy commissioner of police (Special Branch) Iqbal Siddiqui, additional commandant P Satyanarayana, Nizamabad assistant commissioner of police D Pratap, Khammam assistant commissioner of police G Venkata Rao, Nalgonda deputy superintendent of police S Jayaram, Rangareddy district reserve inspector S Ravindranath, Warangal assistant sub-inspector K Sudhakar, assistant SI, Police Academy, N Nagalakshmi, Rangareddy district assistant sub-inspector R Anthi Reddy and senior commando D Ramesh Babu.

Similarly from AP, medals were awarded for Vijayawada ASP A Joshi, APSP additional commandant CVA Rama Krishna, CID deputy superintendent of police M Bhaskar Rao, Greyhounds commander G Vijay Kumar, Vijayawada inspector John Moses, Nellore sub-inspector NG Sankarudu, assistant sub-inspector P Victoria Rani, Chittoor assistant sub-inspector KN Kesavan, Anantapur SI S Ramachandraiah, head constable Y Chandrasekhar, head constable P Vijaya Bhaskar, and head constable N Rama Krishna Raju.

Title: Gujarat’s agrochemical sector going full throttle, raining new projects
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

As many as 20 chemical companies have received a green signal for their projects in Gujarat

AHMEDABAD: If environment clearances (EC) granted to companies for their projects are anything to go by, Gujarat will witness a flurry of fresh investments in the chemicals sector, especially agrochemicals and their intermediates.

As many as 20 chemical companies have received a green signal from Union ministry of environment, forest and climate change (MoEFCC) for their projects in Gujarat over the past three months alone. The estimated cost of these projects is upwards of Rs 3,000 crore.

Companies to have received a go-ahead for their projects include names like Bharat Rasayan Ltd, Cheminova India Ltd, Tagros Chemical India, Neogen Chemicals Ltd, Meghmani Organics Ltd and Insecticides India Ltd to name a few.

Denmark’s Cheminova was granted EC early this month for expanding its pesticides and pesticide specific intermediate manufacturing capacity at its plant located in Panoli, Ankleshwar . According to MoEFCC notification, the cost of project is around Rs 790 crore. Neogen Chemicals Ltd’s Rs 150 crore project for setting up fine chemicals and agro intermediates unit at Vagra in Bharuch also got the go-ahead.

Bharat Rasayan Limited (BRL), the flagship company of agrochemicals major Bharat group, plans to set up a new manufacturing facility for agrochemicals and their intermediates at Sayakha GIDC industrial estate at Vagra in Bharuch district . The project cost is Rs 310 crore.

The expansion and new projects receiving clearances in recent months are for agrochemicals, pesticides, dyes and intermediates and other chemicals. Majority of fresh investment is for expanding existing capacity of pesticides and adding new pesticide products.

“Agrochemicals is one business where there is a lot of supply coming from China to the rest of the world. In the last year or so, more and more European and American companies have begun looking towards India, for active ingredients which go into making insecticides, weedicides, herbicides. The world is now looking a little more on India than depending on China alone,” said Deepak Mehta, chairman, National Chemicals Committee, FICCI.

Industry players opine that the exports of pesticides from India has seen a strong growth over the last few years. Domestic demand too is growing. The gap between demand and availability of agrochemical, pesticide, insecticide, intermediate and formulation is likely to increase over the years. This calls for such projects which can help in bridging the gap.

“Apart from domestic market, there is a sizeable demand for agrochemicals in the international market, which is prompting companies to diversify into this sector,” added Mehta.

“Several companies are ramping up manufacturing capacities for basic chemicals such as sulphuric acid and caustic alkalies. There is a good demand for such products in both domestic and international market,” Shailesh Patwari, past president, Gujarat Chamber of Commerce and Industry (GCCI).

Title: Passengers accuse TNSTC of skipping Srirangam RDO bus stop
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Trichy: Nearly six months after officials of the Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC, Trichy) agreed to halt mofussil buses at the Vannankovil bus stop close to the Srirangam revenue division office (RDO), passengers boarding buses towards Manapparai say that the crew have been refusing to stop the buses there. Due to this, they are forced to disembark at stoppages either before or after Vannankovil.

Vannankovil is situated on the Trichy - Manapparai stretch of the Trichy-Dindigul national highway and connects four major village panchayats including Navalurkottapattu. As the revenue office is situated there, villagers from various parts of Srirangam visit Vannankovil. Following complaints of TNSTC mofussil buses proceeding towards Manapparai skipping the stoppage, a special grievance meet was held at the Srirangam RDO in August 2019.

During the meeting, TNSTC officials agreed to halt the buses at Vannankovil. However, villagers often end up quarrelling with the bus crew as the latter refuse to halt the buses.

“We pointed out the circular issued by the TNSTC GM to halt mofussil buses at Vannankovil, but the bus crew say they are not aware of such instructions. With poor frequency of city buses, we rely on mofussil buses to reach the city,” T Lakshmanan, a resident of Vannankovil told TOI.

While the mofussil buses heading to Manapparai are halting at Dheeran Nagar and Ramji Nagar bus stops located before Vannankovil, villagers questioned the partiality of TNSTC fleet in skipping Vannankovil despite having an RDO office.

“Only the normal fare mofussil buses halt at the Vannankovil stoppage, mofussil (express) fleets do not,” a source in TNSTC said.

Vannankovil residents said that normal fare mofussil buses are very limited in frequency and have sought all services heading to Manapparai except non-stop and point-to-point buses to halt at Vannankovil.

Title: Gold ornaments worth over Rs 4.32 lakh stolen from flat
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: Burglars broke into the unattended apartment of an IT professional in Erandawane sometime between January 19 and 22 and decamped with gold ornaments worth over Rs4.32 lakh.

Aparna Avzinash Nene (42), who resides alone in one of the flats of Pinak Apartment in Erandawane, registered a complaint with the Alankar police in this regard on Friday.

The theft occurred while Nene had gone to visit her ailing mother at her brother’s residence in the city, an officer from the Alankar police said.

“Nene found the lock on her apartment’s main door broken when she returned home on January 23. She entered the house and checked her two cupboards, the locks to which were also picked,” senior inspector Kalpana Jadhav of Alankar police said.

The officer said Nene visited the police station a day later, and reported that gold ornaments worth Rs4,32,500 were missing from her flat. “Our investigation is on,” Jadhav added.

Title: Woman pedestrian dies after car hits her on FC Road
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: A woman security guard posted at the mayor’s bungalow on Ghole Road was killed on Saturday afternoon after a speeding car hit her near the Tukaram Paduka Chowk while she was crossing the Fergusson College Road.

The woman, Bharati Baba Mandalik (25), flung in the air after the car hit her around 12.30pm. She then brushed against a Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) bus and fell on the road. She succumbed to head injuries

Senior police inspector Balasaheb Kopnar of the Shivajinagar police said, “Mandalik was a resident of Pandavnagar, off Senapati Bapat Road. We have booked the car driver for rash and negligent driving, and for causing her death due to negligence.”

Kiran Phadke, an eyewitness to the accident, told TOI, “Just after I parked my autorickshaw at the stand near the Tukaram Paduka temple on the road, the signal turned red. The woman started crossing the road after all the vehicles heading towards the Agriculture College Chowk stopped. She was going towards the Ghole Road from the Fergusson College side.”

He said, “The car that hit the woman had stopped beside the MSRTC bus. The woman had reached the middle of the road when the signal turned green. The car driver accelerated immediately, and his vehicle hit the woman. She brushed against the ST bus and fell down on the road.”

Senior inspector Kopnar said the Mandalik’s head had hit against the road after she fell. Phadke and other autorickshaw drivers had rushed Mandalik to a nearby hospital. “She died of head injuries,” the senior inspector said.

Kopnar said, “We have checked the footage of the CCTV cameras at the chowk. It clearly shows that the car gained speed and hit the pedestrian woman first. The woman then brushed against the bus. We did not find any fault on the part of the MSRTC bus driver in the case.”

He said, “The woman had stepped on the tar when the signal was red. She had walked only a few steps when the signal turned green. The car driver accelerated and hit the woman. It is prima facie assumed that the driver did not see the woman while accelerating.”

Mandalik’s relatives said she was the only earning member in the family of five. She is survived by a seven-year-old son and elderly parents.

“The woman had secured the job in the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) after struggling a lot,” one of her relatives said.

Title: Garrison Engineer graft case: Two more senior officials under scanner
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Dehradun: Two days after CBI arrested an Assistant Garrison Engineer and a Junior Engineer from the Dehradun Garrison Engineer office for accepting a Rs 40,000 bribe from a Delhi-based contractor for clearing his payment of over Rs 20 lakh, two more senior officials have come under lens.

The central investigation agency is now probing the involvement of the two senior engineers in the case.

Sources told TOI that the CBI team recovered Rs 60,000 during raids conducted at the offices and residences of the two erring officials—KK Singhal and Jahangir Ahmed.

“The two engineers worked with Research and Development division which is given sensitive construction work in all Army installations. The investigation has revealed that the two engineers were asking for bribe on behalf of two seniors posted in the same station,” said a senior CBI official.

Notably, the Garrison Engineer office comes under the Military Engineering Services (MES) division of the Army which has the mandate of carrying out construction work across the country.

CBI officials say that the interrogation of the two officials revealed the role of other officials. The two senior officials are expected to join the investigation this week to explain their position.

“Bribery case on engineers, working for a vital installation wing, is a very serious matter and the CBI would be seeking help of Military Engineer Services in Delhi as well,” said another CBI official involved in the investigation.

Title: Green park under Cidco flyover opens for public
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Aurangabad: A park that has been developed and beautified under the Cidco flyover, also known as Veer Savarkar flyover, was inaugurated on Saturday morning.

The 17,000 sqft under the flyover was developed as part of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation’s ‘Let’s Make City Beautiful’ scheme.

In the first phase, Giants Group of Aurangabad Pride, under president Sanjay Jaiswal, had taken up the beautification of the space. As part of its CSR initiative, the Giants Group has built a 6.5ft wide and 700ft long walking track, 6ft wide and 300ft long cycling track, two garden zones with benches over 1,600 sqft area, with seating arrangement for 128 people, and 1,600 sqft area for children to play, which includes a see-saw and swings.

There are more than 200 trees and plants in the park and the area is protected with 6ft high fence on all four sides. A 2,000 litre water tank is provided for watering and washing needs. The columns inside the area have information about famous places in Aurangabad city. A separate parking zone for cycles has been arranged.

In phase II, the Giants Group will be developing another 25,000 sqft which will include a cricket turf, skating track, mural garden, 3D garden and landscape garden, Jaiswal said.

The park was dedicated to the public by former Aurangabad MP Chandrakant Khaire, in the presence of MLA Atul Save, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele and deputy mayor Rajendra Janjal.

The AMC was unable to maintain the gardens, open spaces, places under flyovers, crematoriums, graveyards and traffic islands in the city due to lack of staff and funds. Therefore, it started a scheme under which private parties were invited to beautify these spaces, in exchange for putting up their names for advertisement in that space.

The spaces under Cidco flyover and Mondha Naka flyover were developed under this scheme.

Title: Lost green spaces in focus at Hyderabad Literary Festival
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Storytelling through dance at the Hyderabad Literary Festival on Saturday

HYDERABAD: Providing a rich platform of authors, film directors, poets, painters, and storytellers, the tenth edition of the three-day Hyderabad Literary Festival which began on Friday at Vidyarnanya High School in the city, observed sessions on creativity in the modern age.

The second day of the literary fest saw a high number of environmentally conscious citizens deliberating on increasing urban spaces and saving trees. “We can save a lot of trees by being creative in city planning, but that requires a strong political will and human resources to get the work done,” Radhika Bhogal, an academician and environment activist from Chandanagar.

Talking about rekindling the lost green spaces in India, Bahar Dutt , author of ‘Rewilding: India’s Experiments in Saving Nature’ said, “Rewilding involves protecting green areas through corridors and bringing back lost species. It is an opportunity to set things right.”

“It can play an important role in revitalising our forests, rivers, and wetlands. It is important that we do rewilding to undo the damage we have inflicted on the natural world,” she added.

Young minds from across the country discussed democracy and religion and voiced their opinions on the current state of the country.

“We need to take cognizance of our religion before fighting the views of extremists. We cannot look at India without understanding the nuances of religion,” said Ashutosh, former Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) politician while addressing the session called, ‘Righting the Nation.’ The discussions continued with a large number of school and college students peppering the authors with questions, in the ‘Meet the Author’ area.

Throughout the day, there were workshops, storytelling sessions and photography exhibitions at various locations in the school . A significant number of people attended the creative fiction and novel writing workshop by Australian authors Kim Wilkins and Lisa Heidke.

Title: BJP MLA extends support to traders opposing special traffic plan
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Dehradun: Rajpur Road BJP MLA Khajan Das on Saturday joined traders protesting against the new traffic plan put in place in the city.

The agitating traders were claiming that their sales have gone down by more than 50% due to traffic restrictions. This new traffic plan was put in place on Friday to facilitate the work on various Smart City projects across the city.

As part of the plan, several roads were either blocked or made one-way.

MLA Das told the agitating traders that he will take up the issue with chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat. “The trader community especially in my constituency has been hit hard due to the implementation of the new traffic plan. I will soon meet CM Rawat along with the representatives of the trading community in order to come up with a solution. I will also communicate the inconveniences faced by Doon residents to the police,” said Das.

Meanwhile, Sunil Masson, general secretary of Doon Udyog Vyapar Mandal, told TOI, “This new traffic plan has adversely affected us. We hope that some changes are made to the plan so that our sales don’t take a furtherhit.”

Notably, the new traffic plan will stay put till Monday.

Title: 205 children take part in district-level chess tournament
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Trichy: The district-level chess tournament for children under-15 years commenced at the ER higher secondary school in Melachinthamani with the participation of 205 children from various parts of the district on Saturday.

The two-day tournament, organised by the Yarish School of Chess and approved by the district chess association, is being held under four categories - below 7, 9, 13 and 15 ages separately for boys and girls. Winners of under-7 and under-13 age groups will represent Trichy district in the Tamil Nadu State Chess Championship 2020 for children. 80 children are competing in the under-13 group to grab the top two spots in boys and girls categories.

As many as six rounds of games pursuing the pairing method as insisted by Fide (International Chess Federation) will be held for under 9 and 15 age categories and seven rounds for the other two categories. “The participation of children was overwhelming. There were parents accompanying the kids all the way from Thuraiyur, Musiri and Manapparai towns in the district,” said V Senthil Prabu, organiser of the tournament.

A player will get 1 point for winning a game and half-a-point for stalemate. The winners in each category will be awarded prizes on Sunday. All the participants shall be given participation certificates, organisers added. The district-level tournament is supervised by an arbiter recognised by Fide.

Title: Temghar dam almost empty, geophysical tests start
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: The water stock of Temghar dam dipped to 0.31 TMC (8.3%) on Saturday, giving the state irrigation department an opportunity to expedite its pending repair works.

The irrigation department has started the grouting work on the outer side of the dam’s wall. A similar work in the upstream area at the bottom and the inner side of the wall will begin in March, after the water-level drops further. The filling of cement in critical portions near the spillway will be done in April. The entire grouting work is expected to get over by June.

The stock of Temghar, an important water source for the city, was 100% at the end of monsoon. The storage was brought down on priority in the past three months. The dam’s water was released in the Khadakwasla dam.

An official from the state irrigation department said a plan had been chalked out to complete the work before monsoon. “Though we have been able to arrest 90% of the seepages as of now, the cementing work in the critical portions is still pending. We are targeting to fix these points near the spillway at the earliest. We have also constructed a bridge on the wall to place the machinery on the top of the spillway,” the official said.

A technical advisory committee of experts appointed by the state government has started inspecting the dam to propose long-term measures. The geophysical tests of the dam are being conducted for a detailed technical analysis of its status. The inspections will throw light on the density of structures, design and any improvements if required. The inspection will continue for another month.

The state government had allotted Rs105 crore for repairing the dam. The expenses are likely to climb up to Rs130 crore, considering inflation and other factors.

The irrigation department said it had tabled a proposal before the state government to allot Rs100 crore for the long-term measures that the experts’ committee would recommend.

Title: Woman attendant in school buses a must
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad city police have issued a directive to schools making it mandatory for them to deploy a women attendant in all school buses and vans.

The communication was issued in the aftermath of the recent incident of a school van driver — and two of his accomplices — molesting a nine-year-old child with learning disability.

An offence in this regard was registered with the Satara area police station after the video of the incident (recorded by one of the suspects) went viral.

Aurangabad commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad said, “The incident brought to our notice the fact that there are schools that are not following the child safety guidelines that are mandatory for every school management.”

The officer, while issuing the directive, maintained that the police may soon carry out surprise inspections of school buses.

“Those found flouting the norms will face stringent action,” said Prasad.

The police said that they expect the school managements to stringently following the Maharashtra Motor Vehicles (Regulations for School Buses), Rules 2011.

As per the guidelines, the transport contractor shall employ woman attendants for girls and co-educational schools and male attendants/cleaners for boys schools. A distinct uniform shall be prescribed for the driver, the lady attendant and the male attendant/cleaner for identification. Identity cards must be issued by the operator and they should be displayed by all on-duty staff.

In addition, the transporter must inform the school about any changes in the bus service schedule in the case of bandh/traffic jams/accidents/breakdowns/road blockages immediately. Also, no eatables or drinks shall be offered to the children in buses by the staff unless provided by the school.

City police have asked school authorities to ensure that the character verification of their staffers, especially bus drivers, cleaners and attendants is done before they are hired.

Title: Experts stress accident a wake-up call for cops, PMC
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Traffic and road safety activists on Saturday stressed that the Pune Municipal Corporation and the city traffic police should treat the accident on Fergusson College Road as a wake-up call.

The convener of PedestriansFIRST , Prashant Inamdar, said, “The authorities have made smart footpaths, but have been unable to properly design pedestrian crossings. The PMC (Pune Municipal Corporation) is working on aesthetic elements but not on safety elements like Zebra Crossings on arterial roads. Speeding on FC Road and JM Road, and no safe crossing are a potent combination for accidents.”

The director of Save Pune Traffic Movement, Harshad Abhyankar, said two to three generations in the city had grown without proper pedestrian infrastructure and signals. “People have not seen functional pedestrian signals. If they are there, the signals are not programmed properly. Indiscipline is also ingrained in people. Only stringent enforcement, coupled with hefty fines, can provide a proper outcome,” he said.

Abhyankar was hopeful that the new municipal commissioner would set aside funds for pedestrian signals in the upcoming budget.

Title: Talks on for air link to Dubai, Bangkok & Colombo
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Aurangabad: Aurangabad Tourism Development Foundation (ATDF) has said that talks were on with operators for flights to Dubai, Singapore, Bangkok and Colombo.

The announcement was made at an event held in city to mark the National Tourism Day on January 25.

Over 11 months, flight operations at Aurangabad Airport have increased from six to 30. Much of this increase has been credited to the efforts of hotelier Sunit Kothari, ATDF president Jaswant Singh, president of the Indian Association of Tour Operators (IATO) Pranob Sarkar, IATO vice-president Rajeev Mehra, and Aurangabad airport director D G Salve.

There was a widespread impact on travel to the region following the grounding of Jet Airways flights in March last year. Subsequently, the team was responsible for continued follow-ups with airlines and the ministry of civil aviation. Currently, Aurangabad Airport hosts Air India, Trujet, Indigo and Spicejet flights. It is linked to Delhi, Mumbai, Udaipur, Hyderabad, Ahmedabad and Bengaluru.

On Saturday, the team was felicitated.

AAI Aurangabad director DG Salve said a proposal has been made for an immigration counter at the airport. “We are following up with the home ministry. This would make way for international flights from Aurangabad,” he said. Kothari said talks are on with airline operators to secure flights to Dubai, Bangkok, Colombo and Singapore.

French investors to visit city

Next month, a delegation of 150 investors from France will be visiting Aurangabad, ATDF president Jaswant Singh said. They will be visiting the Auric city under the Delhi-Mumbai Industrial Corridor, he said.

Title: NHAI told to get rid of traffic island at Dwarka junction
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nashik: District guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal on Saturday instructed senior officials of the National Highways Authority of India ( NHAI ) in Nashik to do away with the traffic island at the Dwarka junction and set up a signal to get rid of the everyday traffic chaos.

Bhujbal held a meeting with NHAI officials and took stock of various problems pertaining to the Mumbai-Agra highway passing through the city.

Despite various measures taken in the past, the problem of traffic congestion at the Dwarka junction continues. The traffic island sitting in centre of the junction has been reduced on several occasions in the past, but has failed to ease the everyday traffic snarls in the area.

Bhujbal said that the Haji Ali junction in Mumbai faced similar problem due to the traffic island at the centre of the junction. Once the island was removed and a signal was set up, there was no problem of traffic congestion at that junction. On the same lines, at Dwarka, too, the traffic island should be removed and replaced with a signal.

Meanwhile, he also instructed the NHAI officials to prepare a detailed project report (DPR) of the proposed flyover between Sarda Circle to Nashik Road and present it to the government for perusal.

Recently, the NHAI has shot of a letter to the state public works department (PWD NH Division) to prepare the DPR of the proposed flyover as it was not in the position to construct it due to financial constraints.

The four-lane elevated corridor between Sarda Circle and Nashik Road is planned at a cost of Rs 1,000 crore.

Among other things, Bhujbal also said that the subway at Dwarka should be brought to use for pedestrians and movement of autorickshaws, motorcycles and other smaller vehicles. He said that a down ramp should be constructed on the flyover over the Mumbai-Agra highway near Aurangabad so that motorists from the Mumbai side can descend from the flyover at the Aurangabad road junction instead of driving all the way ahead from the flyover, descending from it and then taking a U-turn to move towards Aurangabad road. He also said that steps should be taken to solve the problem of Indiranagar underpass, converting the existing four-lane Mumbai-Agra highway between Ghoti and Pimpri Sado into a six-lane one.

Senior NHAI officials said that they will study all the instructions by Bhujbal, conduct a meeting with the concerned stakeholders and subsequently speak to their higher authorities about the implementation of the same.

Title: HC bench upholds life term given to man by trial court for killing relative
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Aurangabad:The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay High Court recently upheld the verdict of a trial court that sentenced a man to life imprisonment for murdering an autorickshaw driver (Afroz) over suspicion of having illicit relations with the former’s wife in October 2011.

The accused, Shaikh Shafi Shaikh Mustafa (27), a worker from Chikhli (Bk), in Kinwat taluka of Nanded district had approached the HC challenging his sentence of life imprisonment by the trial court, citing some disparities and some witnesses turning hostile

The accused and the deceased were relatives.

According to the prosecution, while waiting for passengers at the Ghanapur Phata in Kinwat taluka, both of them were sitting in an autorickshaw on October 18, 2011, and listening to music. Suddenly, an eyewitness noticed the accused stabbed Afroz in the abdomen with a dagger. Shaikh pulled Afroz out of rickshaw after stabbing him multiple times and slitting his throat while threatening other autorickshaw drivers not to intervene. Later, he sped away on his motorcycle.

The Kinwat police had registered an offence following a complaint by Shaikh Mehboob, the father of the deceased, who had also said Shafi was suspicious of the deceased having an illicit relationship with his wife and murdered him over that.

While dismissing the appeal, the bench comprising Justices T V Nalawade and M G Sewlikar observed: “There are many circumstances which give corroboration to the evidence of the eye witness who has wholeheartedly supported the case of the prosecution.’’ The bench said: “There are circumstances like evidence on the spot panchanama, motive, presence of human blood on the clothes of the accused and presence of blood of the deceased on the weapon which was recovered from the person of the accused. Thus, there is corroboration to the version of the eye witness of all possible nature and due to these circumstances also the circumstance that the police statements were recorded late, on the next day is not sufficient to discard the evidence of the eye witness.’’

The high court also observed “This Court holds that the trial court has not committed any error in believing the eye witness. This Court has discussed the other evidence and even of the hostile witnesses which can be used against the accused in the present matter. Thus, the evidence as available under section 3 of the Evidence Act is more than sufficient to bring home the guilt to the accused. This Court sees no reason to interfere in the decision given by the trial court.’’

Title: 300 investors in Jetpur lose Rs 9 crore in Ponzi scam
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: In yet another Ponzi scam , a fraudster lured unsuspecting investors with a lucky draw scheme and after duping people of eight to nine crores of rupees, shut shop and fled from Jetpur of Rajkot district .

Cops booked Kishor Thumar under sections 420 and 406 of Indian Penal Code on Saturday and said that Thumar had floated a lucky draw scheme under the name of Deep Group Mitra Mandal.

“Under the scheme, a person was supposed to pay Rs 1,000 every month for 50 months. In the monthly draw, the person was supposed to get prizes ranging from bike, colour TV, refrigerator and moped. And if a person did not win any prize, he would get his Rs 50,000 investment back with Rs 5,000 interest,” explained an official from Jetpur police station.

Though Thumar gave away prizes to winners every month, he decamped with the money of those who did not win any prize and whose time period of 50 months was about to be over.

According to the police, about 3,000 people had invested in the scheme and were expecting to get back their investments back at the end of the term, were cheated. When the investors went to the accused’s office to pay the last installments last week, they found the office locked. Thumar apparently had shut shop and decamped with their money.

Of the victims, 300 made a representation before cabinet minister Jayesh Radadia, who advised the duped investors to approach the police while assuring them of a proper inquiry against accused Thumar.

Title: Telangana civic elections: New crop of young, educated first-time councillors
Content:
(From left to right) B Srividya, Dhanaraj Yadav, Naveen A, S Surya Kala and K Jyotsana Devi.

HYDERABAD: Sharing the winner’s dais with seasoned politicians, on Thursday, was a host of debutantes - many of them armed with fancy degrees and swank corporate jobs. The average age of the new crop of councillors hovered in the 30 to 40-years bracket, a clear shift from the trend observed in earlier polls.Among them was B Srividya, a MSc graduate who won from Ward 5 in Kompally municipality on a Congress ticket. She secured 614 votes against her nearest rival TRS candidate, S Sathamma who got 299 votes. “People elected me not based on my education qualification. They need dedication and determination to resolve local issues. That is what I will do,” said the 30-year-old.Also making it to the finish line, as the new councillor of Nizampet’s Ward 28 was 30-year-old Dhanaraj Yadav who was drawn to politics right from his days as a student. Speaking to TOI post his victory he said, “I wanted to join active politics to be able to serve people for a longer duration...It’s better to begin early if we want to bring about many changes,” the businessman-turned-politician said. Yadav’s aim is to improve basic facilities such as roads and water supply in the Nizampet area.Better roads is on the agenda of 38-year-old Naveen Alashyam too — the BJP candidate from Manikonda’s Ward 8 who met with success on his maiden run. Alashyam recently quit his IT job (he is serving his notice period) to contest the municipal polls. “The lack of proper water supply is the issue I will be tackling first. Besides this, I will follow-up on road works, especially on Road No 25 and Road No 1, both of which are in a poor condition,” said the software engineer.Another techie, S Surya Kala, who earlier worked as project assistant director with an MNC took on the role of a neta, on Saturday, by winning the Kompally civic polls from Ward 7 on a BJP ticket. Surya Kala who pursued her MSc in Mathematics worked as an IT professional for three years. “Though I have two kids, I assure my voters that I will resolve major civic issues such as water, drainage and roads on priority basis,” she said.Similar promises were made by MCA graduate, K Jyotsna Devi (39) who won Ward 11, Kompally municipality and Deepika Reddy (42), an MBA graduate won the civic polls from Ward 20 in Medchal municipality on a TRS ticket. Several candidates emphasised the need for more younger people in politics so that they could better connect with voters and also address issues.They said that the young lot were politically aware and had the drive to address the issues that were affecting the general public.Many of them have also decided to connect with members of their wards through social media applications to identify and solve grievances without delay or confusion.

Title: 44 special trains arranged by SCR to clear passenger rush
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: South Central Railway ( SCR ) will be running 44 special trains between Secunderabad - Machilipatnam, Narsapur - Hyderabad, Hyderabad - Vijayawada and Secunderabad - Barauni in February and March to clear extra rush of passengers.

As per an official release by SCR, nine special trains will run between Hyderabad and Vijaywada on February 3, 10, 17, and 24 and March 2, 9, 23, and 30, consisting of one AC II tier, three AC III tier, seven sleeper class and five general second class coaches.

Title: Pune: Woman held for extortion attempt
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 20-year-woman was arrested on Saturday on the charges of threatening the HR manager of a private firm with fake molestation complaint and trying to extort Rs 7 lakh from him.

The HR manager, who works with a Kharadi-based firm, lodged a complaint with the police, after which the anti-extortion cell of the Pune police nabbed the woman from the Chandannagar area.

“The woman, who studied till HSC, is a resident of Parner in Ahmednagar district and was unemployed for last six months,” sub-inspector Nileshkumar Mahadik said.

The Chandannagar police said the woman was working with a company at Ranjangaon MIDC area earlier. After losing her job, she would read advertisements pasted on the walls and other public places and call up the HR managers for jobs.

“Most of these advertisements used to be for walk-in interviews. After calling the HR managers for jobs, she used to talk to them regularly, before threatening them with fake complaints to extort money from them,” ,” an officer of the Chandannagar police said.

“In the instant case also, she followed the same modus and managed to extract Rs 45,000 from him. However, she continued to threaten him for Rs 6.55 lakh more, prompting the HR manager to lodge a complaint,” the officer said.

The police said she was arrested Section 383 of the IPC, among others. He accomplice has been booked too, the officer added.

Title: Hyderabad: 6 DMart outlets fined Rs 13.4 lakh for violations
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

SECUNDERABAD: The legal metrology department slapped a fine of Rs 2.25 lakh on Kushaiguda branch of supermarket chain, DMart for various violations following a complaint filed by a consumer.

Following a complaint by the consumer Srikhande Umesh Kumar, the legal metrology department inspected six branches of DMart in Rangareddy and Medchal-Malkajgiri districts – Kushaiguda, Kompally, Sanathnagar, Moosapet, Kukatpally and Ramanthapur during the inspections between April 2019 and November 2019.

During inspections, the DMart outlets were found to have replaced the MRP labels by the manufacturers.

During the inspection at Kushaiguda, the inspectors seized rice, casuals, toy cars, electric music guns for various violations under the Legal Metrology Act, 2009.

Overall, the department has slapped a total fine of Rs 13.4 lakh on six outlets of DMart, which include Vanasthalipuram, Ramanthapur, Sanath Nagar, Champapet, Kukatpally and Kushaiguda branches.

Title: ‘Telangana Assembly will pass resolution against CAA’
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao and his son KT Rama Rao share a light moment while interacting with the med... Read More

HYDERABAD: Immediately after TRS swept the civic elections in Telangana on Saturday, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao told reporters at the party headquarters that his government would pass a resolution against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) in the state assembly. This would make Telangana the fourth state to pass such a resolution after Kerala, Punjab and Rajasthan.

He also revived talk of a federal front and said both the Congress and BJP had failed the country.

“It may not happen immediately, but I believe that the front will form the next government at the Centre.” He added that he supported abrogation of Article 370 and opposed the CAA in the interest of the nation. TRS had voted against CAA in Parliament.

Stressing that CAA was “100% a big mistake”, he said that he would mobilise support of like-minded regional party leaders and the 15-odd chief ministers, who are against CAA, and hold a conference in Hyderabad soon. “If required a public meeting with 10 lakh people will be organized in the city,” he added.

KCR also said that in his view, the Supreme Court should take up CAA suo moto and scrap it. “I request the prime ministers to withdraw CAA as it is against the preamble of the Constitution,” he said. “The image of our country is at stake globally.”

“Instead of focussing on the important issues like recession, literacy and poverty, the government was raking up the Hindu-Muslim issue,” he said. “Is it good if you send Muslims out of the country? What happens if Hindus living in outside India are asked to leave? Besides, BJP is already losing one states after another. It lost Jharkhand recently and reports indicate that AAP may win Delhi,” the chief minister said.

The TRS supremo blamed the Centre for the economic slowdown in the country. “Economists have been expressing concern over the recession and millions of people have lost their jobs. The states too were suffering because of the economic slowdown.”

He added that the NDA government has not released Rs 34,000 crore to states towards GST relief and other devolution of funds. “The state government is yet to release Rs 1,131 crore and another Rs 2,812 crore towards IGST. I will write a letter to the Prime Minister to release the amount apart from sending a delegation to New Delhi to build pressure on the Centre,” the CM said.

Title: IOB sanctions Rs 26 crore loan during outreach programme
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Trichy: The Indian Overseas Bank (IOB), Trichy district, conducted a Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME) credit support and outreach programme at Kalaiarangam wedding hall here on Saturday. During the day-long event, various branches of IOB in Trichy district sanctioned loans to the tune of Rs 26 crore to 259 beneficiaries in the MSME segment. IOB said that the outreach programme was conducted to stimulate awareness among aspiring entrepreneurs among the general public and the target group such as existing entrepreneurs to avail financial support and scale up their operations. In the financial year, IOB branches in Trichy district have disbursed loans to the tune of Rs 101.42 crore so far.

As many as 7,423 beneficiaries were benefitted by the financial support disbursed through various government schemes such as SME easy, Standup India and Mudra. Karnam Sekar managing director and CEO of IOB while inaugurating the event said, “Through the rural self-employment training institute (RESTI) of IOB, we have trained 78,000 people across the country of which 50,000 beneficiaries were women. Further, we have planned to provide self-employment training to two lakh people in the state for promoting entrepreneurship.”

“By providing documents as sought by the bank, aspiring entrepreneurs can secure loans at ease. With the District Industries Centre (DIC) guiding the aspiring entrepreneurs, the schemes provided by government for the development of the MSME sector should be utilised to generate employment,” district collector S Sivarasu said.tnn

Title: Five booked for Rs 22 crore land fraud in Jamnagar
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Five fraudsters were booked on Friday night for allegedly usurping 154 bigha land of a farmer worth Rs 22 crore in Changa village on the outskirts of Jamnagar .

Police said the accused, identified as Bharat Dav, Savdas Chawda, Kishor Maharaj, Kripal Sinh and Haresh Chhaiya , allegedly usurped the land belonging to Parshottam Virani by using bogus and forged documents.

According to the police, the accused had approached Virani in July last year. After convincing Virani to sell off the land, they obtained the 7/12 documents of the property, in which apart from Virani, his uncles - Govind Virani, Mansukh Virani, Gordhan Virani and Mawji Virani- and his wife Rasila Virani had been listed as co-owners.

On July 22 last year, the accused met the victims to clinch the deal at the factory belonging to Parshottam’s cousin Magan Virani. The victims had demanded Rs 15 lakh per bigha and the deal was finally clinched at Rs 14.51 lakh per bigha.

In the meeting, the accused asked the victims to hand them over the copies of their PAN, Aadhar card along with their photographs, saying that they wanted to publish a notice in newspaper about the deal.

The accused paid each one of the victims Rs 51,000 as token amount. The accused said they would be paying the 33% of the amount at the end of the notice period to be published in the newspaper and the remaining amount at the time of documentation.

“However, when the accused did not approach the victims after the end of the notice period, the victims decided to cancel the deal and published a notice in a newspaper in that regard. A day after the notice was published, the victim came to know that Dav had filed a claim in a local court of Jamnagar, declaring that the Virani family had sold away their land to them. Realizing the fraud, the victims approached the police with a complaint,” said K K Gohil, sub-inspector with Jamnagar local crime branch.

Title: Cousin rapes 11-year-old girl in Aravali

This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

Title: GHMC plans new railway overbridge at RK Puram to ease traffic, DPR being finalised
Content: SECUNDERABAD: Traffic on the RK Puram flyover is set to ease as the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) has proposed to construct a two-lane railway overbridge (ROB) parallel to the existing ROB at the RK Puram railway gate.In an RTI response to an application filed by a Sainikpuri resident, the GHMC has stated that the new ROB is included in the comprehensive development of roads from ECIL X roads to Trimulgherry X roads under Strategic Road Development Plan (SRDP) phase-4. “Detailed project report for the corridor from ECIL X roads to Trimulgherry is under finalization,” read the RTI response.The GHMC has also approached the South Central Railway (SCR) to furnish a feasibility report for taking up the proposal to construct the ROB. The feasibility report from the SCR is awaited. Based on the feasibility report, the GHMC will be able to frame the draft project report following which necessary funds can be sought from the state government.“The RK Puram flyover was constructed 19 years ago to manage traffic. Today, the need for an alternative ROB is mandatory to ease the traffic. The growing number of residents in the area and surrounding areas is a clear indication that traffic conditions are likely to turn worse,” said Robin Zaccheus, the RTI activist who filed the application with the GHMC.The RTI applicant had also sought information on break-up of the year-wise expenditure on the repair work on the ROB and safety & stability inspections conducted since the time it was constructed, among others. However, the GHMC did not furnish details of the same.The Ramakrishnapuram railway station level crossing gate 252 was closed in 2001 following construction of the existing ROB. While the GHMC has proposed to construct a parallel ROB, residents of the neighbouring areas who used the existing ROB regularly have sought reopening of the underpass, which has been closed for years now.“A wall has been constructed by the local Army authorities under the ROB, which restricts vehicular movement. Until the new ROB is constructed, the underpass can be used by commuters,” said Anand Vijayan, a resident of Vayupuri.

Title: Driver held for harassing minor girl in Thiruvanaikovil

This story is from January 26, 2020

Title: Cinema dependent on literature: Adoor
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Hyderabad: The 10th edition of the Hyderabad Literary Festival opened in the city on Friday with a keynote address by acclaimed filmmaker Adoor Gopalakrishnan who traced the evolution of literature and how it continues to be the guiding light for cinema. “Literature has been in evolution for hundreds of years; cinema is just a century old. Hence, cinema is dependent on literature for its study and understanding…it uses tools from literature,” he said.

The inaugural event was attended by a host of national and international authors, readers and literary enthusiasts. Gopalakrishnan also highlighted the seldom acknowledged fact about influence of cinema on literature and how it has given rise to a new genre of writing – the anti-novel. TNN

Title: Another pink tsunami, TRS sweeps 90% urban civic bodies
Content:
K Chandrasekhar Rao addressing the winners of the municipal elections at TRS Bhavan on Monday.

HYDERABAD: There were no surprises in Telangana’s urban local body elections results declared on Saturday. The ruling TRS wiped out the opposition and won more than 90% of the municipalities and almost 80% of the municipal corporations.Of the 120 municipalities and nine municipal corporations for which polls were held, the pink party secured 110 municipalities and seven municipal corporations. The Congress secured six municipalities while BJP won three.Asaduddin Owaisi’s AIMIM for the first time got two municipalities – Bhainsa and Jalpally. Communally sensitive Bhainsa in Nirmal district had seen a clash between two communities on January 12. Interestingly, TRS drew a blank in the town, making it a direct fight between AIMIM and BJP. Of the 32 districts in the state, TRS swept 27 by securing all the municipalities. Congress, BJP and AIMIM got municipal chairperson’s post in five districts.Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao , said parties never get one-side victories in consecutive elections especially in urban local bodies, but TRS has registered victories in all elections held for the past six years. “For other parties, elections are a game, but for TRS, it is a task which is accomplished,” he said.The extent of TRS’s win can be gauged from the fact the party won more than 1,600 of the 2,727 wards. Congress finished a distant second with 508 and BJP got 240. AIMIM won 79 wards and is likely to get Nizamabad municipal corporation with the help of TRS.Independents and candidates who contested on tickets of registered parties won in 258 places. Their support will be crucial in places like Meerpet corporation for mayor’s post.In some municipalities, like Bheemgal in Nizamabad, all 12 wards went to TRS and none of the opposition parties could not get a single seat. In Nizampet, TRS candidate Kasani Sirisha got highest majority of 1,577 votes even as seven independents won here.Voters in the surrounding municipalities of Hyderabad gave different verdicts, especially in Ranga Reddy and Medchal-Malkajgiri districts. Municipal corporations like Nizampet, Jawaharnagar, Boduppal, Peerzagidud and Bandlaguda, and municipalities like Pocharam, Ghatkesar, Kompally went in favour of TRS. BJP gave close fight in Meerpet and Badangpet corporations along with other municipalities like Amangal, Tukkugda and Maktal.In municipal corporations, BJP is trying to secure the mayor’s post with the help of independents. In select municipalities outside Hyderabad, Congress gave a tough fight to TRS. In Nalgonda municipality, TRS and Congress got 20 wards each of 48. In Neredcherla, TRS and Congress got seven seats each and in Dharmapuri, Congress got seven while TRS secured eight seats.

Title: Two arrested for Rs 7.52 lakh theft from showroom in Rajkot
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Two thieves who are part of a three-member Rajasthani gang, were arrested on Saturday for their alleged involvement in Rs 7.52 lakh cash theft from a garment showroom on Dharmendra Road in Rajkot two weeks ago.

Police said the accused, identified as Udailal Charpota (23), Bapulal Ninama (30) and Bhuralal Mahida (31), had broken into Dresswala Showroom on the night of January 8 and had stolen Rs 7.52 lakh cash from the drawer of the cash counter.

The faces of the accused could not be captured on the CCTV camera installed in the showroom, as they were wearing masks. However, when the cops checked the footages of the CCTVs installed along the route to the showroom, they found the car had been parked by the accused near Shastri Maidan .

“On the basis of the registration number of the car, we traced the vehicle to Banswara in Rajasthan. We sent a team of officials to Banswara to find out the owner of the car. Our investigation led us to Charpota and Ninama, subsequent of which we arrested them,” said H M Gadhvi, inspector with Rajkot detection of crime branch.

However, the police are yet to arrest Mahida for the crime.

Title: Telangana civic elections: Rebels slow down TRS’s march in polls
Content:
K Chandrasekhar Rao addressing winners of the municipal elections at TRS Bhavan on Saturday.

HYDERABAD: Rebel trouble dented the ruling party’s march towards a near improbable cent per cent victory in the elections.Rebels derailed the party’s prospects in municipalities like Mahbubnagar, Gajwel and Sircilla where they either contested as independents or on the All India Forward Bloc ticket. In Kollapur municipality in Nagarkurnool district, as many as 11 TRS rebel candidates won on Forward Bloc ticket.Reliable sources confirmed to STOI that rebel candidates were fielded by former minister Jupally Krishna Rao,who lost Kollapur in the 2018 assembly elections. Both Kollapur MLA B Harshawardhan Reddy and Krishna Rao have been at loggerheads ever since the former joined the ruling TRS after winning on a Congress ticket and quitting the party after the assembly elections. Harshawardhan even complained to the party leadership against Krishna Rao. In Ieeja municipality in Jogulamba-Gadwal district, 10 independents won on Forwawrd bloc ticket.Though there were hundreds of rebel candidates in the fray, they dented TRS party’s prospects in half a dozen municipalities. For instance, in Sircilla municipality, which is represented by TRS working president KT Rama Rao, 12 independent candidates emerged victorious. Since TRS won the required majority seats of 22, there would not be any impact on bagging the municipal chairperson post.Even in chief minister KCR’s Gajwel constituency, 78 rebels filed their nominations in erstwhile Medak district and 36 of them went on to win as independents. In Dubbak municipality, rebels won 10 wards — more than any political party. TRS bagged nine wards there.Party rebels who won in the elections are now evincing interest to join the ruling party, it is learnt.In Khammam district, two councillors joined TRS in presence of district minister Puvvada Ajay Kumar. The party is likely to take rebels’ help in Kollapur and Ieeja to secure municipal chairperson posts, sources said.

Title: Smart Rd not yet complete, inaugurated on Sunday
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nashik: The city’s maiden smart road between Trimbak Naka and Ashok Stambh will be inaugurated and thrown open for vehicular traffic on Sunday.

Ahead of the inauguration day, the labourers were seen working aggressively on the stretch to make it ready for Sunday.

On the other hand, the senior police officers expressed their concerns about the road being thrown open for vehicular traffic, even when the road is not fully complete.

The officers said that they will have to deploy additional manpower to monitor the streamflow of traffic.

On Saturday, the labourers were seen working on paver blocks, a couple of feet away from the footpath to create a cycle track. The road was also dug up at a couple of spots for setting up other facilities. The painting work of the road dividers and the traffic island was seen on the stretch.

The stretch all set to become one of the best streets in the city, commuters are complaining about the decreased width of the road and huge bumps in between. While the footpaths are appreciated, currently many motorists are seen parking their vehicles on them.

Gopal Paripurna, an executive working at a private firm on the MG Road said that the cycle track adjacent to the footpath is a waste of money. “All along the footpath, there is a beeline of illegally parked vehicles. Once the road is thrown open for traffic, the cycle track would be under the illegally parked vehicles,” he said.

Police officer, who didn’t wish to be named, said that they feared that once the signals are set operational the traffic at the CBS junction mainly will become chaotic. People coming from the Trimbak Naka side and moving towards Sharanpur Road will not get a clear free left, which will further to the chaos. “On the same junction, the free left for vehicles has been done away. Thus to take a left, motorists will have to wait for the signal to go green,” said the officer.

Many traders, who have their establishments at Ashok Stambh junction said that the road was already falling short for the heavy traffic and now after the smart road work, the width of the road has been further reduced. Senior traffic officials said that they would observe the flow of traffic after the inauguration near Ashok Stambh. If problems occur, the junction will be closed until construction work is fully complete.

Title: Police swing lathis at Congress supporters at counting centre
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

HYDERABAD: Congress MLA Komatireddy Raj Gopal Reddy (Munugode) entered into a heated argument with cops at a counting centre in Bhuvanagiri on Saturday when they refused to allow him into the centre. When the situation got out of control, police resorted to mild lathicharge.

On coming to know that TRS MLA G Sunitha (Alair) had reached the centre to talk to an independent candidate, Raj Gopal rushed there. When cops denied him entry, his supporters entered into an argument with police and jostled with them. By this time, Sunitha left the counting centre.

Police brought the situation under control by resorting to a lathicharge to disperse the angry supporters.

Title: Civic win tightens KT Rama Rao's grip on party
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: During his presser, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao was effusive in his praise of party cadre and leaders and even took the name of his son, party working president KT Rama Rao for ensuring a stupendous victory for the party in the elections. KTR , who sat beside his father, was grinning from ear to ear, after earning a rare accolade from his party supremo.

Senior political analysts said KCR ’s acknowledgement was a trigger for bigger role for KTR anytime soon — a fact corroborated by KTR himself when he said Saturday’s win certainly enhanced his role as municipal administration minister with bigger tasks ahead. Party sources said after the outcome, the demand to anoint KTR as chief minister may get shriller.

Several ministers and MLAs have already started raising pitch for KTR as future CM. V Srinivas Goud, Errabelli Dayakar Rao, T Srinivas Yadav and Koppula Eshwar, on several occasions, have openly said KTR will take over the reins of India’s youngest state. What adds to ongoing rumours is KCR’s assertion on playing a bigger role at national level on issues like CAA, NRC and cobbling together a federal front against BJP and Congress-led alliances.

Party sources said the results have not only proved the strength of TRS in both urban and rural areas, but also tightened grip of KTR on TRS. “As he proved his ability to handle both party affairs and in government administration, it will certainly pave the way for his elevation as CM,” a party leader said.

However, KTR himself has been dismissing these speculations. He made it clear that KCR would continue as Telangana CM for the next 10 years. Before appointing KTR as TRS working president a year ago, KCR gave him the responsibility of talking to MLA aspirants and working out strategies for campaigning. KCR also made KTR talk to rebel candidates to withdraw from the fray.

After he assumed charge, KTR successfully took TRS to victory in gram panchayat, Lok Sabha, zilla parishad elections and Huzurnagar bypolls. Except for attending a couple of meetings with ministers, MLAs and MPs, KCR allowed KTR to handle entire poll exercise. This made party leaders and MLAs happy as KTR was accessible to them in Telangana Bhavan.

Title: Clean sweep that wasn’t meant to be
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Hyderabad: TRS may have swept the elections, but its show in Gajwel and Sircilla municipalities was below expectations. Gajwel and Sircilla municipalities fall under assembly constituencies represented by chief minister KCR and his son KT Rama Rao respectively.

Though TRS was expecting a clean sweep in all 20 wards in Gajwel, Congress opened its account by winning one ward. Six independents — all TRS rebels — won leaving the party with victory in only 13 wards. In Sircilla, of the total 39 wards, TRS managed win in 22 wards. BJP secured three and Congress two. Independents (all TRS rebels) emerged victorious in 12 wards.

Taking a dig at KTR , who had predicted that TRS will sweep the elections, BJP state president K Laxman said: “The dismal performance of TRS in KTR’s own constituency of Sircilla shows all is not well with the party. BJP won three seats and independents have fared reasonably well.”

TPCC working president A Revanth Reddy said the fact that 12 TRS rebel candidates contested in Sircilla against the wishes of KTR and another six TRS rebels winning in Gajwel was a testimony to KCR and KTR losing their hold on party members. “TRS ship is overloaded with outsiders and is bound to sink soon,” he said.

Polls were not held for Siddipet municipality, part of Siddipet assembly constituency, represented by Harish Rao.

Title: With distinct style, Konkan Kanyas cast a magic spell
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

The programme organized by GH Raisoni Sports and Cultural Foundation was held at Chitnavis Centre

Nagpur: With their distinct style, Konkan Kanya lived up to their billing as a top entertaining band, by presenting a lively show at Chitnavis Centre in Civil Lines, on Friday. The show was organized by GH Raisoni Sports and Cultural Foundation.

The famous Konkan Kanyas were Nikita Ghate, Arundhati Tendulkar, Duhita Kunkavlekar, Arti Satyapal, Rasika Borkar and Sneha Ayare who doubled up as the host. The band is managed by Raviraj Vijay while Vishal Sutar handles the beats and rhythms. Mrunalini Naik welcomed the band. Chairman of Raisoni group Sunil Raisoni was present.

They girls introduced themselves by their famous song ‘We are Konkan Kanya’ but began their stage show with a devotional song ‘Vakratunda Mahahakaya’.

Gradually they upped the tempo with numbers like ‘Dil hai chhotasa’, ‘Badmash dil’, ‘I love you’ and ‘Tum jo aaye zindagi mein’. Their next four back-to-back songs ‘Navrai Majhi’, ‘Nachde ne saare’, ‘He subharambh’ and ‘London Thumakda’ took the audience to an altogether different plane.

The contestants of ‘Raising Stars’, then tried to slow down the proceedings a bit with ‘Dekha ek khwaab’, ‘Dil ka bhanwar kare pukar’, ‘Sawaar loon’ and ‘Pari hun main’.

In between Sneha Ayare kept tickling the funny bones with humorous shayaris and jokes. The band concluded the show with ‘Jeev Rangala’.

(Reporting by Rushabh Rathod)

Title: Chandrayaan missions renewed world interest in Moon: Scientist
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

TRICHY: India’s Chandrayaan missions have triggered renewed interest among other countries towards the Moon, space scientist Mylswamy Annadurai has said. “While Chandrayaan II mission was much discussed the world over, the US has planned to land on Moon again by 2025. Other countries are likely to follow suit,” he said here on Saturday while addressing the valedictory event of the 124th foundation year celebration of Srirangam Educational Society .

The scientist said the rationale behind India’s plan for a manned mission to space is that if countries decide to set up a research centre on Moon, India will very much be part of it. On Chandrayaan – 2, he said the orbiter is still functioning properly and Isro is planning successive missions.

Lauding the achievements of previous Isro missions of which he was an integral part, Mylswamy, who is vice-president of Tamil Nadu State Council for Science and Technology (TNSCST), said they could find water on Moon and send satellite to Mars in the first attempt in the most economic manner. “Now that we are gearing up for the first manned mission to Moon, a half humanoid will be sent in the first stage. Moon’s surface is very uncertain, therefore Isro is sending a machine before sending humans,” he said. On the opportunities in science and research, he said there was a time when questions were raised about sending satellites to the space in the country but now there is so much anticipation on successive Isro space missions.

“Students need to develop skills to match the requirement. Apart from academic learning, they need to be innovative and develop research temperament,” he said and asked students to not just think about a job but about starting their own ventures. “Tamil Nadu produces an equal number of engineers as by the whole of USA. However, they need to be engineers rather than be graduates,” he said.

Title: Telangana municipal elections: In Kompally, just 1 vote makes all the difference
Content:
Representative image

KOMPALLY: It all boiled down to just one vote, which separated the winner from the loser. S Srisailam Yadav of TRS literally snatched victory from the jaws of a defeat in ward No. 3 in Kompally municipality and the sore loser was A Mohan Reddy, who contested the seat on a BJP ticket.A former sarpanch of Kompally, which was a gram panchayat before, Yadav set a unique record in scoring one of the extremely wafer-thin margins of victories in the election. Curtain for the high-voltage three-hour drama was raised by returning officer T Shanker when he announced Yadav as the winner after recounting after both the candidates secured 356 votes each.Recounting was taken up at the Kompally MPP office in the presence of agents of TRS and BJP after the candidates made a demand. “We did recounting twice on secured votes and found that one vote extra was secured by the TRS candidate. We intimated the result to the district election authority, Medchal-Malkajgiri district, and took his consent before declaring the winner,” Shanker told newsmen at the counting centre.“Based on the instructions, rules and regulations prescribed in the election handbook regarding decision of vote which voters affixed seal on the ballot paper, the TRS candidate has secured one extra vote. We declared him as the winner,” he said.However, Mohan was livid and alleged that Kompally municipality election authorities were partisan towards Yadav. Mohan staged a protest along with his followers. A mild tension prevailed at the counting centre. Soon, police entered the scene and forcibly shifted Mohan and his followers from there.When STOI contacted assistant district election authority and Kompally municipal commissioner MNR Jyothi, he said: “The candidate who raised an objection on Yadav winning the ward can appeal to the district election authority.”Yadav’s wife S Kavitha, who has also entered the race from ward No. 2, however, lost the fight.

Title: Nashik cops trace kin of a dead man who left home 40 years ago
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: A discharge slip from the Nashik Civil Hospital found in the trouser pocket of an unidentified deceased person helped the city police to track down his family to Ozar, about 22 km from Nashik city. Incidentally, the deceased person, who was eventually identified as 65-year-old Pralhad Narayan Bachkar, had abandoned his family four decades ago — and had been missing since.

After the police were able to find the family, Bachkar’s son performed his last rites on Wednesday.

An unidentified body was found near the market yard area of Panchavati in the city on January 21. During the course of the investigation, the police found a discharge slip issued by the Nashik Civil Hospital in the trouser pocket of the deceased person. This helped ascertain his identity.

“From the appearance of the deceased, it appeared that he was living the life of a wanderer. He may have been living on alms,” said Ashok Bhagat, the senior police inspector of Panchavati police station. “From the hospital discharge slip, we could ascertain his name and the place he belonged to. We started looking for his family the same day,” Bhagat said.

Police naik Ananda Chaudhary said, “When a body of an unidentified person is found, we send a message with the description of the deceased person across the district. If personnel of any police station feel that the description matches anyone missing in their jurisdiction, their family members are contacted to ascertain the identity.”

In this case, police naik Chaudhary and police constable Arun Gaikwad spread the message about the deceased person on various social media groups of Ozar residents. By Wednesday morning, the police investigation led to one name — Hiraman Pralhad Bachkar, the 48-year-old son of the deceased. When the two constables contacted Hiraman, they learned that Pralhad Bachkar had left his home about 40 years ago.

Hiraman too was in a state of shock. “Hiraman’s mother (Pralhad’s wife) is no more. He said he barely remembered his father as he was too young when his father left them. Identifying his father’s body was, therefore, out of the question for him. However, some elder members of the family were able to identify the deceased man and the body was handed over to them.”

Hiraman said that while he had no hopes of ever meeting his father, he was grateful that he could at least perform his last rites.

Title: Election results point to BJP’s ascent in Telangana
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

BJP supporters celebrate the victory of their candidate outside the counting centre in Himayathsagar on Saturd... Read More

HYDERABAD: The urban local body elections on Saturday clearly indicate that the political graph of BJP is on the ascent in Telangana with the saffron party winning nearly 240 municipal wards and divisions. The saffron party has improved its performance and tally not only in the municipalities and corporations in the state, but gained significantly in urban local bodies on the periphery of Greater Hyderabad.

BJP won three municipalities — Amangal, Tukkuguda and Makthal — and emerged as single largest party in Nizamabad municipal corporation and a couple of other local bodies.

Though BJP finished at third place behind TRS and Congress, which were first and second respectively, the results of the 2020 municipal polls is no mean achievement for BJP, which had managed to win just 167 wards and divisions in the 2014 ULB polls, that too after contesting the elections in alliance with TDP then. This time BJP went alone.

Even though BJP did not have candidates in 700-odd of the 3,052 wards that went to polls, the saffron party not only improved its tally, but has managed to get representation in over 60% of the total 129 municipalities and municipal corporations which went to the polls on January 22.

In the Meerpet municipal corporation, BJP emerged as the second largest party, winning 16 wards as against 19 by TRS and three by Congress. In the Badangpet corporation, the saffron party was runner-up with 10 seats against 13 by TRS and seven by Congress.

However, BJP leaders, including its state president K Laxman, who have been claiming that BJP has emerged as an alternative to the ruling TRS and is the main opposition party in Telangana, was no match to TRS. Also, BJP secured 50% less wards than the Congress.

Title: Songs on ‘Kapoors’ liven up the atmosphere
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nagpur: Hit songs related to the famous ‘Kapoor Khandan’ kept the listeners engrossed during Swargandha-presented musical programme titled ‘Ek Shaam Kapoor Ke Naam’ at Scientific Society Hall, Laxmi Nagar, on Friday.

A total of 28 songs were presented by 15 singers. Vijay Dhawale’s ‘Main shayar to nahin’ started the programme on the right note followed by Surendra Sharma’s ‘Badan pe sitaare’.

Anchor Shweta Shelgaonkar, in her calm and composed style, threw light on the famous Kapoor family, often referred to as ‘First family of Bollywood’. She said, “It is not easy to be picked as the best, the title needs to be earned. Indeed, their youngest generation have kept the legacy of fame and popularism of the family intact.”

Singers Sharad Jodh, Sanjay Patil, Jayraj Markand, Kumar Kelkar, Apurv Masodkar, Abhay Vyas, Arun Ojharkar, Nina Bagal, Anuja Joshi, Sujata Patil, Pragya Shiras, Vandana Umredkar and Sangeeta Bhagat participated to make the programme a success.

Other songs like ‘Hoga tumse pyara kaun’, ‘Jane kahan gaye woh din’, ‘Yeh jawaani yeh deewani’, ‘Yeh mera dil pyar ka deewana’, ‘Mujhko hui naa khabar’, ‘Yun toh humne lakh haseen dekhe’, ‘Akele akele kahan jaa rahe ho’, ‘Aaye ho meri zindagi mein’, ‘Yeh ishq haaye, baithe bithaaye’ and many more were highly appreciated by the audience.

Entertaining duets like ‘Gum hai kisike pyar mein’ by Vandana and Kumar, ‘Tum ko mere dil ne pukara’ sung by Arun and Anuja, ‘Pyar hua ikrar hua’ by Abay and Sujata, ‘Aaja sanam madhur chandni’ presented by Nina and Apurv and other songs were well performed by the singers.

‘Khilte hain gul yahan’ from the movie ‘Sharmeelee’ and sung by Kumar was the concluding song of the evening. The programme was conceptualized by Arun Ojharkar and organized by Ashwini Ojharkar. Prashant Nagmote was the sound director.
