Title: Lotus blooming, says Laxman
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Hyderabad: BJP Telangana president K Laxman said lotus is blooming as vote share of the party increased considerably in 2020 municipal elections compared to 2014 urban local body polls. “We contested municipal elections on our own and got 40% votes across the state. In 2014, we had contested municipal election in alliance with TDP,” he said.

Stating that BJP’s vote percentage increased to 40% this time as against 20% in 2019 Lok Sabha polls, he said despite large-scale malpractices, including distribution of money and misuse of official machinery by TRS, BJP’s performance is a good sign for party’s growth. Laxman alleged the polls were most expensive with TRS candidates luring voters by doling out Rs 30,000 per vote in some wards. “In some cases, TRS candidates spent Rs 1 crore in each ward,” he alleged. TNN

Title: Kin plead to rescue MBBS students stranded in Wuhan
Content:
Shoppers wearing face masks at a supermarket in Wuhan in central China's Hubei province on Saturday

Among the several Indian students stranded at Wuhan city in China due to the coronavirus are Manisankar and Robin Raj of Tamil Nadu , both final year MBBS students there. A worried Paneerselvam, Manisankar’s father, said the Indian government is yet to wake up to the severity of the problem.“It has been a week since my son Manisankar is stuck in Wuhan. The fact remains that he is not infected with coronavirus. But there has not been any effort from the Indian government to bring him back,” rues the 55-year-old man from Pudukottai district. A house surgeon in one of the hospitals, Manisankar, 22, is on the verge of completing his five-year MBBS course in Wuhan University. “Confined within the four walls over the last one week, they don’t even have food for the next two days and fear to move out due to the outbreak,” said Paneerselvam who is in touch with his son over phone.On Friday, Paneerselvam approached collector P Uma Maheswari and gave a petition seeking help to get his son back along with his fellow classmate Robin Raj of Nagapatinnam. The collector has forwarded the letter to the ministry of external affairs and the Indian embassy in China for necessary steps. Paneerselvam says his son received a call from the Indian embassy on Friday but there has not been any steps since then. Delaying the rescue of his son as well as the other Indian students will make them vulnerable to infection, says he.Manisankar is staying outside the university along with Robin Raj. He had come to his native place at Anthanur village in Gandharvakottai in September last year to attend a family function. He returned and chose not to come again during his scheduled vacation from December 16 to January 3.

Title: Telangana municipal elections: It’s all in the family! Spouses, siblings impress voters, win big
Content:
Sibling revelry: Santosh Kumari & Rajender Reddy

Gorla Venkatesh Yadav & Aruna Jyothi

HYDERABAD: The 2020 municipal polls saw husband-wife and brother-sister duos successfully campaigning and bagging seats in a few wards.In Nizampet, Pranaya Yadav, 28, won the seat at Ward 31 while her husband, Dhanaraj Yadav, 30, won the seat at Ward 28. The duo, both first time contestants, are affiliated to TRS. Interestingly, Dhanaraj’s mother Prameela Sailu Yadav is an ex-sarpanch and the couple drew inspiration from her to take the plunge into politics.Power couple:The couple who have been married for nine years, went about campaigning hand in hand.“My husband has been a youth leader but this is the first time we both decided to contest. We are overwhelmed at the results and are now going from door to door to thank residents,” said Pranaya. They now intend to take the work done by Dhanaraj’s mother forward and have set themselves the target of developing a graveyard in the area and beautifying parks.Similarly, husband-wife duo, Gorla Venkatesh Yadav, 47, and Aruna Jyothi, 41, won from Narsingi municipality. Supporters gathered as they emerged from the centre, to celebrate the win.Speaking to TOI, Jyothi who won from Ward 7 with a 95-vote majority, said, “This is a victory for women. I will put in all my efforts to provide amenities to people. Many youngsters put in a huge effort to help me win, I cannot forget their contribution.” Her sentiments were echoed by Yadav, who won from Ward 16 with a 44-vote majority. The couple is affiliated to TRS.Siblings Santosh Kumari, 39, and Rajender Reddy, 34, both from TRS, won from Bandlaguda Ward 3 and Ward 15 respectively.Santosh Kumari won with a 215 majority and Rajender had a 280 majority. Santosh Kumari said, “This is a big moment for our family. We will work to ensure every resident gets necessary amenities..”

Title: AIMIM bags 87 of 276 seats across Telangana
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: Of the 3,535 wards and divisions in 120 municipalities and nine municipal corporations, the All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen (AIMIM) contested from 276 seats and bagged 87 of them. In Bhainsa municipality out of the total AIMIM bagged 15 wards and BJP bagged 9 seats. Only two seats were bagged by other parties.

Bhainsa is the only municipality where TRS did not win a seat. The party did well in Jalpally municipality too by bagging 15 seats out of 28, the main opponent to AIMIM in Jalpally municipality was Telangana Rashtra Samithi(TRS). In Nizamabad municipal corporation too from where AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi said he will fight the upcoming assembly elections, the party won 16 seats.

As on today, both assembly segments, Nizambad Rural and Urban are TRS seats. Sangareddy (2), Adilabad (4), Tandur (3), Nirmal(2) and Sadashivpet (2) are the other places where the AIMIM won seats in the municipal elections.

In the communally-sensitive Bhainsa town, counting was taken up amid high security due to a histroy of clashes. The contest in Bhainsa was primarily between MIM and BJP. Security personnel were deployed in every nook and corner of Bhainsa following the recent communal clash.

Meanwhile, officials and police claimed that except for sporadic incidents, the counting exercise was completed peacefully.

Title: MIM walks away with Bhainsa, TRS draws a blank
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Less than a fortnight ago, Bhainsa town was rocked by communal violence that left 19 persons, including eight ... Read More

HYDERABAD: The TRS juggernaut was nowhere visible in Bhainsa in Nirmal district as the ruling party drew a blank and AIMIM bagged Bhainsa municipality by emerging victorious in 15 wards. There are 26 wards in all. BJP came second by winning nine wards, while independents secured the remaining two. Congress failed to win even a single ward.

Less than a fortnight ago, Bhainsa town was rocked by communal violence that left 19 persons, including eight cops, injured. Analysts said MIM and BJP leaders could succeed in polarising the voters, going by the result on Saturday. This is the second urban local body won by MIM on its own in Telangana. The Majlis party contested, in all, 276 wards and divisions.

BJP, on the other hand, charged the TRS with fielding dummy candidates and indirectly helping its friendly ally, AIMIM, win the municipality.

On January 12, a trivial issue took violent and communal turn when members belonging to two communities clashed late in the night. Next day, members from both sides clashed again and stones were pelted. Fourteen houses were damaged and 30 vehicles burnt. Following the arson and violence, 13 cases were registered and 61 persons from both the communities arrested.

Title: New policy for Telangana NRIs gets thumbs up
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

HYDERABAD: With TRS coming up trumps in the municipal polls, the TRS NRI wing said government’s initiative to come out with an NRI policy will benefit many from Telangana , especially migrant workers in the Gulf countries.

NRI TRS founder-president Anil Kurmachalam, based in London, thanked voters for giving TRS a landslide victory and strengthening CM K Chandrasekhar Rao’s leadership.

Anil said it was heartening that the CM announced that the NRI policy would be implemented. He thanked former Nizamabad MP Kavitha Kalvakuntla and IT minister KT Rama Rao for their efforts in getting the new NRI policy drafted.

Title: Audience enjoy hits of Shammi, Dev Anand
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nagpur: The magic of two of the greatest actors of Bollywood Shammi Kapoor and Dev Anand was relived as Child Adoption For Education (CAFE) organized a musical programme titled ‘Yahoo! Gaata Rahe Mera Dil’, on Friday. The show was presented by Niranjan Bobde at Vasantrao Deshpande Hall, Civil Lines.

The event was staged by CAFE to raise awareness among people about their mission and invite participation in large numbers for donating educational kits to needy children. Chief managing director of Inventys, Deepak Birewar, was the chief guest.

Singers Amit Ganvir and Parvathi Nair started off with the title song 'Gaata rahe mera dil' which met with a thunderous applause. Their performance was followed by Anil Guhane's rendition of the melodious number ‘Phoolon ke rang se’. Bobde gave a classical music touch to ‘Cham cham baje re payaliya’.

Audience members were seen shaking a leg to the song 'Aasman se aaya farishta' as Bobde raised the tempo with this peppy number originally sung by Mohammed Rafi. He went on to sing ‘Aise na mujhe tum dekho’, ‘Khoya khoya chaand’, ‘Yun toh humne lakh haseen dekhe’ and ‘Yeh chaand sa roshan chehra’ among others.

Kajal Kate joined Bobde to present the dynamic song ‘O haseena zulfon wali’. Naman Gharpure made the audience tap their feet to the tunes of ‘Baar baar dekho’ and ‘Dil deke dekho’.

The singers were accompanied by Mahendra Dhole (keyboard), Shivlal Yadav (saxophone and flute), Gaurav Tanksale (guitar), Pankaj Yadav (tabla), Deepak Kamble (dholak) and Subhash Wankhede (drums and octopod). Anchor Mona Desai kept the listeners engaged with shayaris and trivia behind the songs.

Desai introduced the office bearers and members of CAFE on stage while executive member Sanjay Trivedi briefed the audience regarding the workings of the organization. He informed that the institution has set foot in its 13th year and nearly 13,000 students were helped with their specially designed educational kits consisting of basic necessities of school.

Title: Corporation primary school launches roller skating training
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

TRICHY: In yet another initiative to develop sports in the district, the authorities of corporation primary school in Edamalaipatti , Pudur has lauched roller skating training in a bid to nurture the skills of students. The government school is the first in the district to launch such an initiative for students. The students of the school are already offered free training in disciplines like Silambam , Karate, Taekwondo, by professional trainers.

Around 50 students have expressed their interest to join the roller skating training offered by the school after a demo by trained children from outside. The idea occured to the school authorities after a former student named Abirami, now in college, won medals in national-level roller skating.The school has decided to crowdfund through social media platforms to meet expenses for providing training and for the kit. “Affordability is a key reason for many to join government schools. But we want to ensure that children get better facilities and opportunities here than in private schools,” school headmistress P Jayanthi said. “Poverty shouldn’t be a barrier for these young minds to chase their dreams. This time we have offered roller skating training. If a few students find their dream on wheels, we want to ensure that they are realise their dream,” said assistant teacher H Pushpalatha from the school. The strength of the school known for its exemplary practises had crossed 400 in the beginning of the ongoing academic year after admitting roughly 150 new students.

Title: Telangana municipal elections: MIM retains Dabeerpura by over 9,000 votes
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The AIMIM retained the Dabeerpura seat (Ward 30) by a margin of 9,240 votes. The seat was the only one falling under GHMC limits to have gone for elections.

The counting was held at a centre located in Amberpet. AIMIM’s Basit Ali won the seat with 10,465 votes, while BJP’s Mirza Akhil Afandi came second with 1,225 votes). Congress candidate Mirza Askar Ali Baig got 950 votes, Raza Ali Mirza of TRS got 620 votes and TDP candidate Mohammed Ahmed secured 147 votes.

Soon after MIM was declared as the winner, Basit collected the certificate from returning officer and met party leaders at MIM head office in Darussalam. “Though the polling percentage was low, we were confident that deposits of opposition parties would be forfeited,” said Syed Ikram, a MIM worker.

Title: Discom staff strike after AGM ‘hostage’ drama
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

BHOPAL: Amid allegations that a senior power distribution company official was held captive for three hours at Morena ’s Kotwali police station, discom officials on Saturday refrained from work and observed strike in the district. They demanded that the in-charge of the police station where the official was allegedly held captive be suspended.

Around 200 personnel of the power distribution company did not go for work. However, the complaint redressal teams of the discom were kept away from the strike on the first day to ensure that common people do not suffer.

Speaking to TOI, RS Bhadoria, the in-charge of Kotwali police station where the assistant general manager ( AGM ) of the discom’s Morena city circle was allegedly manhandled, said, “Apart from those responsible for addressing faults and complaints, around 200 employees of the discom were on strike.”

According to sources, the employees of the discom plan to continue their strike and would cover the entire Morena district in the next phase.

“As per our plan, it was decided to go on full-fledged strike on second day. But as it is the Republic Day, we have rescheduled it for Monday,” said VKS Parihar, the convener of Madhya Pradesh United Forum for Power Engineers and Employees, an organization of several employee unions working in power sector.

It is noteworthy that the power discom officials and policemen are at loggerheads in Morena town after the AGM was summoned to the Kotwali police station on Wednesday this week and was allegedly held captive for over three hours and pressured to waive off electricity bill worth Rs 1.47 lakh.

After the AGM apprised senor officials, the managing director of the discom Vishesh Gadphale wrote to the state’s director general of police (DGP) while the power engineers’ association met the DGP on Friday following which a strike call was given in Morena.

Title: IMA Agra to open OPD on Feb 1, charge Rs 10 from each patient
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Agra: India Medical Association (IMA) in Agra is planning to open a charitable clinic wherein economically poor patients will be able to consult a doctor by paying just Rs 10 as fee. The clinic will start operating from February 1 at IMA Bhavan, Tota Ka Taal. Here doctors, including specialists, associated with the IMAwill provide their services.

As many as 1,200 doctors with private practice are associated with the IMA in Agra. The association is preparing a roster for doctors who will voluntarily provide their services free at the charitable clinic.

Giving details, president of IMA, Agra, Dr Ravi Mohan Pachori said, “We are going to start a charitable clinic for people who are financially weak. The out-patient department (OPD) at the IMA Bhavan will start operating from February 1. The doctors will see patients from Monday to Saturday between 10:30 am to 2:30 pm. Patients will be prescribed generic medicines. Besides, pathology labs will provide concessions to patients coming for tests from the IMA’s OPD.”

According to the IMA sources, every day, around five to six doctors, including at one specialist, will attend the OPD. This means that each doctor’s turn will come probably once in a month, when he or she can take time out of his/her busy schedule.

The IMA Agra also plans to help patients who are advised at the OPD to undergo a surgery to get it done in a private hospital at a concessional rate. Similarly, the IMA is in touch with private pathology labs to conduct tests of patients referred by its OPD at concessional rates.

Besides, operating the charitable clinic, IMA will also be launching an awareness campaign against diabetes and cancer. Schools and colleges will be incorporated in the campaign.

Title: Private bus operators call for strike on February 4
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Thrissur: The private bus operators in Kerala have called for an indefinite strike from February 4.

The private bus operators’ co-ordination committee said that all 13 private bus associations will be a part of the strike.

The co-ordination committee has raised various demands, including hike in bus fare and revision in student’s concessions. It was in November that the transport minister assured to conduct talks before December 5 and solve the issues. But after one month, the government failed to conduct talks, said Kerala state private bus operators’ federation general secretary, Lawrence Babu.

“We have demanded a rise in minimum charge from Rs 8 to Rs 10. The government should implement KSRTC model concession system to students. We will not agree to the fare hike without rise of student’s concession. Only 50% concession can be allowed for students. In the future, we will not give concession to self-financing college students,” said all Kerala Bus operator’s organization general secretary, K Gopinathan.

The bus fare was hiked in March 2018 when the diesel price was Rs 62. Now the diesel prices have increased to Rs 73. It is difficult to operate bus services without fare revision. In 2011, there were 34,000 private buses plying in the state and now it has been reduced to just 12,000. If the present situation continues, we can’t manage the private bus industry, said co-ordination committee leaders.

“Our demand is that the government should raise student’s concession to Rs 5 per student. The parallel KSRTC chain service in the same routes as private operators is also affecting the private bus industry," said Gopinathan.

Title: Gujarat: Video of woman holding barn owl goes viral, probe ordered
Content:
Kirti Patel holding barn owl

RAJKOT/AHMEDABAD: Video of a Tik Tok star identified as Kirti Patel , holding barn owl, went viral on the social media triggering a major controversy on Saturday.The state forest department has ordered a probe considering the act of holding the endangered species an offence amounting to its harassment. Barn owls are protected under the Schedule IV of the Wildlife Protection Act.The video was uploaded by Patel, who according to her Facebook account, is a freelance fashion designer based in Ahmedabad.In the video Patel compares human beings with owls and states that the night bird is better than human beings. “Owls can see only at night and they don’t see negative things. But humans, who can see 24 hours, are busy culling out negative points in others,” Patel is heard saying in the video, all the while holding the owl in one hand.Conservator of forests, north Gujarat , S K Pandit said that a probe has been ordered into the video.“We are tracing the whereabouts of the video and where it had been shot. Primarily, it appears to be an offence. Will take action once the woman in traced and questioned,” said Pandit.Sources in the forest department said that the video might have been recorded at a bird rescue centre, where the owl might have been brought for treatment. “If it is established that the video was shot at any of the rescue centres, then action will be taken against the NGO or the forest officer in-charge of the the centre, apart from the Tik Tok star herself,” the officer added.Environment activists from Amreli, Himanshu Bhatt, said that barn owls are rare and cannot be spotted easily. “It is a Schedule I species and anybody found doing mischief with such a species is punishable by law. Holding the owl also amounts to cruelty. The government should take action against the woman in the video for breaking the law,” said Bhatt.In Video: Gujarat: Video of woman holding barn owl goes viral, probe ordered

Title: Man who saved lives of 23 bus passengers on Yamuna eway to be honoured on R-day
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Agra: On 71st Republic Day, on Sunday, Agra police will confer ‘prashasti patra’ (citation letter) to 27-year-old Nihal Singh who saved the lives of 23 passengers on Yamuna expressway last July after an ill-fated UPSRTC bus fell from a bridge and plunged into a narrow drain, killing 29 passengers.

Resident of Chaugan Baghel Ki Thar village of Etmadpur police jurisdiction, Singh, on the morning of July 8, witnessed the bus accident and rushed to save passengers, while he was working at his farm field. His prompt action helped save many lives.

Speaking to TOI on Saturday, Singh said, “I’m happy for the award. But, if the government can build a road for my village and help me get a job then that will be more useful to me and for my family.”

Last year, the then district magistrate N G Ravi Kumar of Agra assured Singh of getting a job.

“Due to poverty I could study only till eighth class, but don’t want the same fate for my children. I want to provide them education so that they could live a respectful life and become self-reliant. My qualifications are low, but not my ambition. I’m a hard working farmer, I just need a little help from the government,” said Singh, father of four children, including twin daughters Payal (4) and Pari (4). His two sons Krishna (8) and Tarun (6) are students of local government primary school.

Singh added, “Our village has a government primary school as well as electricity connection in every household, but local villagers travel for nearly one km on the unmetalled road to reach the highway in order to travel to the city. Things become very difficult for us in monsoon season. I hope the award ceremony will give me a platform to put forward the villagers’ demands.”

Ram Singh and Ramkali, parents of Nihal Singh, also expressed their happiness over the honour bestowed on their youngest son for his courage. Singh is among a total of six siblings, including two sisters.

“Since childhood, Nihal Singh has been a humble and shy man. He has a stammer issue. But last year, he showed enough courage and presence of mind to save many lives. Since he had no mobile, he requested an injured passenger to give his phone so that he could call the expressway rescue team for help. Initially, the passenger was hesitant, but Nihal convinced him that he won’t steal his phone, rather help him and others,” said Ram Singh, the braveheart’s father.

Rakesh Singh, gram pradhan of Chaugan, said, “Nihal has made the entire village proud. We hope the district administration will pay heed to his demand.” While speaking to TOI, Asutosh Dubey, personal assistant of Agra DM Prabhu Narain Singh, said, “We are aware of Nihal Singh’s request and will do the needful.”

Title: Bengaluru: Three held for running Ponzi scheme
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Three people have been arrested by Tilaknagar police on charges of running a Ponzi scheme through which they had collected around Rs 77 crore from more than 2,000 customers in the past four years.

The arrested are Manjunath, 31, from Vishveshwaraiah Layout in Devarachikkanahalli, and Habibulla Shareef, 37 and Masiullah Shareef, 32, from Doddakammanahalli. Police said the accused ran a firm called Tiforp Trading Services Pvt Ltd in Jayanagar 9th Block since 2015 and promised a monthly return of around 10 per cent on investments.

They held events in and around Jayanagar and promoted their scheme on Facebook and other social media platforms to attract customers. For a few months, investors got the promised interest, but it stopped subsequently.

Trouble began in November 2018 after the firm stopped giving interest to investors. Though people made several rounds to the company, the owners failed to keep their word and instead, requested customers not to approach police. In May 2019, after the I Monetary Advisory (IMA) scam made headlines, the trio closed the firm and fled. The investors later formed a group and started negotiating with the firm owners. When that didn’t yield any result, they began to file police complaints January 14 onwards.

Police said the accused led a lavish life, which included foreign trips. A BMW car, Hyundai Tucson, Toyota Innova and two bikes were seized from the trio, who have immovable properties worth over Rs three crore.

Sources said the accused collected money claiming they were in real estate and foreign currency exchange businesses. Efforts are on to trace some others involved in the scam who fled with the money.

Title: MP demands stoppage at Niphad and Lasalgaon for Rajya Rani
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: Dindori MP Bharti Pawar has written to the Bhusawal divisional railway manager seeking additional stoppages to Rajya Rani Express and also additional coaches for the train.

In a letter dated January 21, she has demanded additional facilities in the train for the convenience of passengers travelling from Nashik region towards Mumbai by the train. The train that originally ran between Manmad Junction (Nashik) and Mumbai, was extended recently up till Nanded.

Daily travellers of the Rajya Rani Express had opposed the extension of the train. Claiming that the regular travellers and monthly season ticket holders hardly find space to sit in the train now, Pawar has asked for more coaches.

‘Since the commuters don’t find seats and have to travel standing for three to four hours, the railways should take measures to ensure they travel comfortably. The railways should therefore arrange for at least two additional coaches,’ MP Dindori wrote in the letter.

The MP also underlined the need for more stoppages for the train to accommodate people from the region. ‘The Railways also should consider stoppage for the train at Niphad and Lasalgaon railway stations. Residents of these two towns do not have any train in the early hours to travel to Mumbai. Adding these two stoppages would cut down the hardships of the people,’ Pawar said in the letter.

Box : Spl train for feast of Infant Jesus shrine

The Central Railway has decided to run special train from Dadar to Nashik Road on February 8 to enable travellers from Mumbai to reach the Infant Jesus Shrine for the annual feast. The Annual Feast is held on second Sunday of February and the train will leave Dadar station at 7.50 am to reach Nashik Road at 11.10 am. The train will start its return journey at 7.45 pm to reach Dadar at 11.45 pm on the same night. The Railway officials said that people willing to travel by the train could book their tickets for the travel in advance.

Title: Mercury dips to 6.2 degrees Celsius, Agra shivers
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Agra: The mercury level in Agra on Saturday dropped to 6.4 degrees Celsius, 1.2 degrees Celsius less compared to Friday. Besides, the maximum temperature was recorded at 21.3 degrees Celsius which was two degrees less than normal.

While, moderate fog was witnessed till 9am, it became sunny towards the afternoon.

Besides Agra, cold wave also swept across Firozabad, Mathura, Etah, Aligarh and Mainpuri. In Aligarh maximum temperature was recorded at 19.6 degrees Celsius, one degrees Celsius below normal. Here minimum temperature remained 5.8 degrees Celsius.

According to the metrological department, the temperature is likely to increase next week.

Title: Sanjay Place traders form human chain to protest against parking fee
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Agra: There seems to be no let-up in the protests being staged by the traders of Sanjay Place here against Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) administration for charging parking fee at 44 places in the market. On Saturday, more than 250 traders formed a human chain as a mark of protest. They claimed that the parking fee violates norms as they had already paid a fee for parking at the time of purchasing the property.

The traders have been staging protests since January 14. So far, no official of the civic body or any public representative has come to meet the traders.

Claiming that the parking fee is illegal, the traders have been using the public address system to urge vehicle owners not to pay for parking.

On their part, the parking contractors have said they have been authorized by the AMC administration to charge a parking fee.

Meanwhile, police on Friday, following a complaint of a parking contractor, registered an FIR against leaders of the protesters -- Hiren Agarwal, Vinay Mittal, KN Agnihotri, Komal Surana and 20-25 unidentified people.

The FIR has been registered under IPC section 147 (punishment for rioting), 323 (punishment for voluntarily causing hurt), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace), 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation), 352 (punishment for assault or criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation).

The dispute over parking fee between traders of Sanjay Place and AMC) is sub judice. The traders want AMC to cancel the parking contracts till the court delivers its final orders in the matter.

KN Agnihotri, president of the Sanjay Place Market Association, said, “Not able to face the traders raising genuine questions, AMC administration has got a fake FIR registered against the peaceful protestors. We will continue our fight against the extortion in the name of parking fee.”

Hiren Agarwal, secretary of the market association, said, “The AMC administration is trying to exploit traders by illegally charging the parking fee. We have already paid for the parking space. To muzzle the voice of the traders, a fake FIR has been registered. We will continue our fight against the parking mafia.”

Association’s treasurer Vinay Mittal alleged that despite the ongoing case at the sessions court, the AMC administration had issued parking contracts for three years to people associated with BJP. “AMC officials also get a share of the parking fee illegally collected from the market. We will not withdraw our protest till the AMC rolls back its decision,” he said.

Title: Bhuj: 390kg spurious ghee worth Rs 9 lakh seized
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A total of 390 kg spurious ghee packed in 26 cans on which labels of prominent ghee brands were pasted was seized from a godown on Mundra Road in Bhuj on Saturday. Police first arrested Abdul Sanghar with five cans of spurious ghee that he had uploaded on his truck.

“During interrogation, the accused said that more such ghee cans were stored in Dhimant Thakkar’s godown, following which we raided the godown and effected the seizure,” said R N Barot, inspector with Bhuj B division police station, adding that the police had launched a manhunt for Thakkar.

Title: Bengaluru woman loses Rs 5 crore to man who claimed to have Rs 2,400 crore in US
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: An MBA graduate and civil services aspirant has knocked on the doors of police alleging she was cheated of Rs 5 crore by a fifty-year-old man who claimed to have hoarded $343 million (Rs 2,400 crore) in a bank in the US.

The woman, Radhika Reddy (name changed on request), is a resident of Kalyannagar and belongs to a family that owns huge tracts of land in Bengaluru. She has filed a complaint with Hebbagodi police against Krishnegowda , a resident of Kolar, his wife Kavitha K Gowda, their son Dheeraj and friend Manjunath.

Radhika was introduced to him by a police officer currently working in Bengaluru Rural district and an assistant conservator of forests in March 2018. Police said Krishnegowda allegedly claimed he had worked in Dubai for 18 years and ran a paper factory along with other businesses. He maintained he returned to India after working abroad and had earned over Rs 2,400 crore. However, there were procedural complications in bringing the money stashed in the US.

A smooth-talking Krishnegowda said he required a huge amount of money to pay taxes and other fee to get his money. He assured Radhika he would give her a large share if she provided funds to retrieve the money. The woman took her family into confidence stating their chances of striking a jackpot were high by helping Krishnegowda. Since June 2018, Krishnegowda succeeded in taking lakhs of rupees from Radhika stating he wanted to get a clearance certificate from Reserve Bank of India (RBI), insurance certificate and cited other trivial reasons.

Radhika sold 2.5kg gold and a vacant site, worth Rs two crore, in Ramamurthynagar to pay Krishnegowda. However, she soon realised that even her relatives were paying him hoping to become rich quickly and all of them were being taken for a ride. Radhika told STOI she used to meet Krishnegowda every day for many months but he stopped meeting her and switched off his mobile.

Police said Radhika’s ancestral property was sold and pledged as her family also supported her. Preliminary probe suggested several cheating complaints were registered against Krishnegowda in Bengaluru where he lured people and siphoned off their money.

Hebbagodi police said Krishnegowda portrayed he had enough money and wanted to give it to people he ‘loved’ and ‘cared for’. While on one hand he spoke to his victims emotionally, on the other he took advantage of their greed to cheat them, police said. "We have basic information about his whereabouts," police said.

Title: Govt offices to get trained officers
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Thrissur: For the first time in the country , government offices in Thrissur district will extend a helping hand to people with disabilities.

The district administration will appoint sign language trained officers in the front offices of each government offices soon. In the first phase, officials trained in sign language will be appointed in the revenue department. The initiative to appoint the sign language trained officials in the government offices was started by district collector S Shanavas.

A special training will be given to selected 50 revenue officials at Thalappilly taluk office on Sunday at 10am. In the first phase, the sign language trained officials will be appointed in the offices in the first week of February, said officials.

“As per the primary data there are nearly 5,000 hearing and speech impaired people in the district. Many of them visit various government offices every day. But the officials can’t provide proper service to them, due to them not knowing sign language. The special initiatives aim to provide a helping hand to them”, district collector S Shanavas told TOI.

“The NGOs will be giving sign language training to selected revenue officials. In the first phase the trained officials will be appointed to the revenue offices like village and taluk offices. In the second and third phase we aim to appoint sign language trained officials to banks, panchayat, police and other offices. We plan to appoint sign language trained officials in all government offices in the district soon,” said the collector.

“If sign language trained officials are appointed in government offices hearing and speech impaired individuals can share their complaints and requests to the officials in their own language. By knowing the actual details through sign language, the officials can provide proper service to them. As part of the initiative we also aim to give sign language training to auto, taxi and bus drivers,” said the collector.

Title: Consumer forum orders insurance firm to settle claim
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik District Consumer Disputes Redressal Forum has ordered the Oriental Insurance Company to settle a claim of Rs 5 lakh that was raised by a city resident following the death of his mother due to injury in 2017.

Complainant Dheeraj Sevakramani had insured his family members in 2009 and renewed their policies regularly.

On July 17, 2017, Sevakramani’s mother was admitted to a hospital because of illness. When she was about to be discharged on July 31, she suffered a fall in the bathroom of the hospital and on October 21, succumbed to head injuries that had also left her paralysed.

Sevakramani filed for a claim of Rs 5 lakh from Oriental Insurance. But the company rejected the death claim on December 20, 2017, on the grounds that the death was caused not by accident, but illness. The company also claimed that Sevakramani had concealed certain details related to his mother’s illness at the time of getting the policy.

“The mother of the complainant was suffering from several diseases which have been mentioned in the death certificated issued for the deceased. Besides, the certificate also mentions these diseases as the cause of death along with the fall. This violates the terms and conditions of the insurance,” company counsel SS Purnapatre had claimed.

But counsel for the complainant, P R Chandrakor, pointed out that hospital had mentioned several diseases as the ‘antecedent cause’ in the ‘cause of death certificate’ but at the same time, the ‘immediate cause of death’ was attributed to ‘Cerebrovascular Accident’ which meant injury to brain.

The three-member redressal forum, headed by president Milind Sonawane, said the insurance company had erred on rejecting the claim of the complainant without any valid reason and hence amounted to deficiency in services. The forum said the insurance company had not come up with proof to counter the claim of the medical certificate mentioning the ‘immediate cause of death’ as head injury. It then ordered the company to settle the claim of Rs 5 lakh along at a 9% rate of interest from December 20, 2017, when the case was rejected.

The forum also ordered Rs 7,000 as compensation for mental harassment of the consumer and Rs 5,000 as compensation for costs incurred.

Title: To help tourists, CM launches SDRF app
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Dehradun: To help tourists and pilgrims who get stranded in remote Himalayan areas where internet connectivity is poor or missing, the State Disaster Response Force ( SDRF ) has come up with a mobile app , which will work offline also.

Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Saturday launched the app ‘Meri Yatra’, which will give users health tips, updates of hotels,weather information and navigation support.

SDRF commandant Tripti Bhatt said that more features will be added in the app soon. While launching the app, the CM lauded the efforts of the SDRF for coming up with the useful app which has been created in a budget of Rs 2.4 lakh. “The year 2019 saw a record turnout of pilgrims to the Char Dham Yatra and we expect the number to be higher this year. This application will be extremely useful for the devotees as well as adventure sport lovers who come to Uttarakhand,” the CM said.

Sharing more information, SDRF IG Sanjay Gunjyal said that it can be downloaded through Google store. “Trekkers and adventure sport lovers go to remote areas, which are often not connected with internet. In case of any calamity or accident, it becomes difficult to track and rescue them. Therefore, this app has been designed in a manner that it can also work in the absence of internet,” Gunjyal said.

He added that through the app, tourists can also get weather updates. “We will inform the tourists about the do and don’t’s of a particular area, health tips, required medicines, places of stay, clothes to wear and travel connectivity,” Gunjyal said.

Besides, emergency numbers, cellphone numbers of senior state officers, details of district disaster management team, Char Dham route map and location of nearest SDRF post would be mentioned in the app, the official said.

He added that in order to aid those coming for water sports, kayaking, rock climbing, mountain biking, bungee jumping and camping in the Himalayan state, details of suitable time to plan the trip as well as particulars of agencies involved in the activity, would also be available in the app.

Title: 21 officers felicitated for good governance
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Dehradun: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Saturday felicitated 21 officers for their work in contributing towards good governance. The officers, including IAS and officers of Provincial Civil Services (PCS), were honoured with CM’s Excellence and Good Governance award in a function at the secretariat.

Among those felicitated included district magistrate (DM) of Rudraprayag Mangesh Ghildiyal, senior IAS Bhupinder Aulakh, PCS officer Lalit Narayan Mishra, Mussoorie Dehradun Development Authority (MDDA) vice-chairman (VC) Ashish Kumar Srivastava and Indian Forest Service officer PK Patro.

The DM of Rudraprayag was awarded for his contribution to the development of Kedarnath, whereas Mishra was felicitated for his efforts in projects related to the cleanliness of Ganga river. Aulakh was honoured for her work on women empowerment and social welfare, and also in the education sector, Ashish Srivastava for the work done in creating a smart infrastructure for Dehradun and PK Patro for the efforts in developing Dehradun zoo.

Speaking on the occasion, CM Rawat said, “Those who are doing innovative work should be shown appreciation. The awards are meant as an inspiration for others as well.”

The CM announced that a fund will be set up to promote innovation in the state. “There are many people who have innovative ideas but they can’t proceed further because of fund crunch. We will try and help them.”

Title: Odisha: Ex-sarpanch offers to keep Biju Patnaik’s Dakota
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

KORAPUT: A former sarpanch of the tribal-dominated Koraput district has offered two acres of land in the district to keep Biju Patnaik’s Dakota aircraft and develop it into a heritage site. The state government recently wrote to the Airports Authority of India (AAI), requesting it to bring back the abandoned aircraft from Kolkata.

Dakota (VT-AUI) aircraft belongs to the erstwhile Kalinga airlines, which was founded by former chief minister Biju Patnaik. With the help of this aircraft, he had flown out Sultan Sjahrir, the Prime Minister of Indonesia, from a jungle hideout and had reached India on July 24, 1947, on the instructions of then Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru. The family of former sarpanch ( Dumuriput ) Uttarkabat Apparao Choudhury submitted a proposal to district collector Madhusudan Mishra in this regard.

“Biju Patnaik’s contribution in establishing the engine division of Hindustan Aeronautics Limited (HAL) at Sunabeda in the mid 60s was huge. Our region received national importance because of his contribution. HAL has strengthened the tribal economy of the region,” Loknath Choudhury, son of the former sarpanch, said.

“To honour and acknowledge his role in developing the area, the family has decided to donate two acres of land at Dumuriput mouza,” he added. Dumuriput, which is 5 km from the HAL’s engine division at Sunabeda on NH-26, was the first adopted village of the navratna PSU.

“As HAL is involved in manufacturing the fighter aircraft for the Indian Air Force, we are hopeful that the state government will agree on our proposal,” Loknath said.

“It was for Biju Patnaik that a unit of HAL could be established in the district. The family deciding to offer two acres of prime land to keep Dakota aircraft is praiseworthy. If the government accepts the proposal and develop the place into a heritage site, it will be a sacred place for Biju lovers. It will boost tourism in the district,” former district collector Gadadhar Parida said.

Title: ACM raids unearth rampant corruption in revenue offices
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Vijayawada: Friday’s surprise raids by the anti-corruption bureau (ACB) at the offices of 21 mandal revenue officers (tahsildars) in all 13 districts have revealed the extent of the rot in revenue offices.

A common trend across all tahsildar offices, ACB officials noted, was the presence of undistributed pattadar passbooks and unaccounted cash. Officials also noticed private persons were engaged by some tehsildars to carry out official work.

With the public dependent on revenue offices to procure caste certificates and address proof, several petitioners complained of being harassed by tahsildars in order to get their official work done. Land-related issues, however, are the major source of corruption for revenue officials.

Over the years, the revenue department has faced criticism from farmers in delay in issuance of pattadar passbooks and making changes to ownership of land records in cases of mutation or sale of land. Extending bribes to officials to get pattadar passbooks, even when records are in order, have become a norm in the state.

ACB officials said the modus operandi of revenue officials was to hold back pattadar passbooks in order to collect money from farmers. Causing intentional delays in rendering services beyond the service level agreement (SLA) period would force farmers to extend bribes.

Speaking to STOI, director general of the ACB, PSR Anjaneyulu said they have identified irregularities ranging from rejection of certificates to the presence of unaccounted money. “We also suspect that revenue officials are in nexus with Meeseva centres, which will be established in further investigation,” he said.

Additionally, the raids revealed the presence of private persons at government offices collecting money from the public on behalf of officials. Anjaneyulu said some officials reject genuine applications without citing valid reasons in order to exact bribes. “We are digging deeper into the issues and erring officials will be booked,” said Anjaneyulu.

Title: Telangana municipal elections: Supporters climb walls, reveal result to partymen
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Husband of Congress candidate Geetha R who won Ward 1 in Shamshabad gets into an argument with police after be... Read More

HYDERABAD: In a video footage captured by STOI, some unknown persons were seen revealing number of votes and other details of election results to party workers at Aurora’s Technological and Research Institute, the counting centre for Peerzadiguda Municipal Corporation. The incident came to light after a supporter of an independent candidate informed media personnel about the issue.

The individuals in the video can be seen shouting out results from one of the windows in the building’s top floor while counting of votes was still in progress. “They are shouting the results from the counting hall. There is not even a single policeman guarding the area behind the counting centre. This is completely against the model code of conduct. The authorities have completely failed in making arrangements,” said Ravi Kishore, a supporter.

When questioned about the security arrangements in the area behind the counting centre, the police official at the front of the counting centre said: “We are sending our officials. No one is allowed to go behind the building.”

Elsewhere, at the Lords Institute of Engineering & Technology in Himayathsagar where counting for Narsingi, Manikonda and Shamshabad municipalities along with Bandlaguda Municipal Corporation, police personnel armed with only batons had a hard time keeping away crowds from entering the premises. There had been no arrangements made by police for barricades and many were seen trying to get in by jumping the wall.

Inside the premises, a heated argument broke out when the winning candidate for Shamshabad Ward 1, Congress ’ Geetha R and her husband were coming out of the premises. Seeing a crowd build up around them, the police is said to have pushed them towards the media and infuriating them in the process. “They should not have pushed us this way,” Geetha said but later acknowledged that “such incidents happen in the moment.” Rajendranagar ACP K Chakravarthy also said that such incidents are expected with large turnouts.

Title: K Chandrasekhar Rao’s ‘sack’ warning to ministers, MLAs did the trick
Content:
Supporters celebrate the party’s win outside TRS Bhavan on Saturday.

While in Janagaon TRS supporters greeted each other by smearing themselves with pink colour, at TRS Bhavan in Hyderabad, workers celebrated the party’s victory by distributing sweets, breaking out into a victory dance and playing drums and other musical instruments.

HYDERABAD: Has TRS president, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao’s gambit of making ministers and MLAs accountable for ensuring party candidates’ win in the elections paid off? It appears so.Of 32 districts (except Hyderabad) that went to polls, the ruling party swept to victory in 27 districts. In five others — Jogulamba-Gadwal, Wanaparthy, Nagarkurnool, Nalgonda and Rangareddy, the opposition Congress and BJP secured municipalities and more number of wards.While Mahbubnagar is ministers S Niranjan Reddy and V Srinivas Goud’s turf, G Jagadish Reddy is from Nalgonda and Sabita Indra Reddy hails from Rangareddy.Some time before the elections, the chief minister warned that he would not hesitate to drop ministers if they fail to get him the desired result. He also warned them against encouraging groupism and indiscipline in the party.Sources said the party leadership this time gave powers to ministers and MLAs to select candidates and issue form-Bs to declare them as official candidates. They were also involved in the exercice to convince the rebels to withdraw from the fray with a promise to get them nominated or co-option posts.With this assurance, ministers and MLAs not only toured and campaigned in respective municipalities but also went to the rebel candidates’ houses to bring them back into party’s fold. In Peerzadiguda municipal corporation, Medchal incharge minister Ch Malla Reddy went to house of a senior leader, who joined Congress, and brought him back into the party within hours. Similarly, a ruling party leader in CM’s Gajwel constituency succeeded in bringing back a worker from Congress to TRS fold on the same day.Despite party leadership’s efforts, some municipalities, however, were bagged by Congress and BJP. “If there are any special conditions and reasons for failure , the party may not view it seriously. Congress and BJP won in the districts, which were earlier dominated by Congress. Also, Congress has more MLAs from these districts,” a TRS politburo member explained.

Title: Ganja worth Rs 3 lakh seized in Odisha
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

BERHAMPUR: Around 82 kg of ganja worth Rs 3 lakh was seized while being transported in an ambulance near Kuduraha village under Kandhamal’s Phiringia police station limits. The owner-cum-driver of the ambulance, Ajay Kumar Pradhan of Ratnamati under Jankia police station limits in Khurda district was arrested for illegally transporting the consignment, said sub-divisional police officer (Phulbani Sadar) M N Murmu.

The contraband was seized based on specific information received by police that a huge ganja consignment was being trafficked from the district towards Bhubaneswar in an ambulance, said inspector-in-charge of Phiringia police station P.Shyam Sundar Rao .

After police stopped the vehicle, the driver tried to flee but police managed to capture him. During search, they found marijuana packed in two sacks in the vehicle, police sources said. Preliminary probe revealed that the narcotic item was being transported from Kuduraha village to Khurda, police added. “We will also probe if the vehicle is an ambulance or a vehicle has been converted into an ambulance,” police said.

Title: More boys than girls reported ‘bad touch’ in Goa’s rural areas: Study
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Class 10 boy hangs self after dad’s rap for neglecting studies
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: A Class X student hanged himself at his school premises at Srikakulam village in Krishna district in the early hours of Saturday, allegedly, after his father scolded him.

Tammanaboyina Deepak Manikanta Sai (15) left home in the evening after his father scolded him for playing video games on his mobile phone, Ghantasala police said.

People found his body the next morning hanging from a hook in the ceiling of one of the classrooms. They called in the police who sent his body for post-mortem.

Police said his parents could not come up with a reason for the suicide . They, however said that his father had shouted at him for playing games and neglecting studies. A case under section 174 of CrPC has been booked.

Title: ‘CAA may put national security under threat’
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Firdos Mirza

Along with Delhi and rest of the country, the state’s second capital is also witnessing large-scale protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC). Leading the charge are primarily the youngsters, besides Muslims — most of whom believe that the new legislation targets their community. However, many are unaware of the minutiae of the amended law, according to noted lawyer Firdos Mirza.

An expert in matters pertaining to the Constitution, Mirza says that the law is not only discriminatory towards Muslims, but works against all citizens who do not have “valid” documents to prove their place of birth. In an exclusive tête-à-tête with TOI, he tries to correct many misconceptions about the new legislation. Excerpts...

Q. Please explain CAA.

A. The law prescribes grant of citizenship to illegal migrants belonging to the Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist, Jain, Parsi and Christian communities from Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan, who entered India on or before December 31, 2014, without any verification.

Q. Which documents are required to prove citizenship?

A. If the media is to be believed, documents like Aadhaar, voter ID, PAN card or passport would not be sufficient for proving citizenship. However, there is no clarity on the documents (apart from the birth certificate) actually required to prove that someone is an Indian citizen. A UNICEF report states that only 58% births are registered in India, which means that the remaining 42% go undocumented every year.

Q. It is perceived that CAA is against the Muslim community.

A. Not only Muslims, the law is against the entire country; and its implementation may put national security under threat. Its provision of granting citizenship to those from neighbouring countries threatens national security, as the entry of undesired elements cannot be ruled out. Even hardened criminals and terrorists can become citizens of India and pose dangers to the nation’s peace and tranquillity.

Q. Why are Muslims agitated?

A. Muslims are the most law-abiding citizens of India. The spirit of Indian Constitution is brotherhood, equality and justice; but the linking of religion to citizenship in CAA breaches that spirit. The community considers it a direct assault on the constitutional set-up of the country, which may have far-reaching repercussions. Right now, the Act is leading to religious discrimination against the five lakh Muslims who were left out in NRC in Assam. Since everyone needs to get registered under NRC, the onus of proving that they are not foreigners will fall on all individuals. This entire exercise could lead to a huge humanitarian crisis.

Q. There is a lot of talk about National Population Register (NPR).

A. The Citizenship Act, 1955, does not prescribe the preparation of NPR or any such register by the central government. The reference to the population register is made through a subordinate legislation, i.e. the Citizenship (Registration of Citizens and Issue of National Identity Cards) Rules, 2003.

Q. How are NPR and NRC related?

A. Both are part of same process. NPR contains details of persons residing in various parts of India, and is prepared by collecting information related to them by the local registrar. For NRC, the local registrars need to verify and scrutinize the information collected in NPR. It would be on their discretion to declare any citizen as dubious. Such persons then need to satisfy the taluka registrar or sub-district registrar about them being Indian citizens. Thereafter, a draft NRC would be registered, inviting objections on the inclusion of any name. After consideration of such objections, the NRC would be published. Those who are left out could make an appeal to the district registrar, whose order would be final.

Q. There are speculations that orphans would suffer the most after CAA and NRC.

A. Section 3 of Citizenship Act deals with ‘Citizenship by Birth’. Accordingly, if CAA is implemented, then the children born to illegal migrants belonging to the Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist, Jain, Parsi or Christian community from Afghanistan, Bangladesh or Pakistan, who entered into India on or before December 31, 2014, would be Indian citizens.

Children born after December 3, 2004 to Muslim parents, and to all others after December 31, 2014 whose parent(s) fail to prove their citizenship would not be treated as Indian citizens, and would be deemed as stateless persons born in India with no other country to go to. Orphans would suffer the same fate, as they would not be able to prove who their parents are.

Q. What about transgenders, destitutes, homeless and aged people, sannyasis, monks and persons with mentally disabilities?

A. Only if they have a record of their parents, would they be treated as Indian citizens.

Q. Isn’t NRC good, as the country would have a list of all citizens and infiltrators would be filtered out?

A. NRC was introduced in Assam upon allegations of demographical changes, based on a survey. It stated that the 1 crore infiltrators staying there were converting the state’s ethnic population into a minority. After a gigantic exercise by 52,000 officials for around eight years, at the cost of over Rs1,600 crore, only 19 lakh persons were identified to not be a part of NRC, and of them only around five lakh are Muslims. Even family members of most of the five lakh people are included in NRC.

By implementing CAA, the illegal migrants would be granted citizenship based on their religion. Later, through NRC, all the existing residents would be forced to prove their citizenship by submitting documents while standing in serpentine queues, and thereafter through appeals and finally, facing the foreign tribunals. The road ultimately ends at detention camps.

Is the problem of illegal migrants so gigantic that we are making every Indian stand in a queue?

Q. Why are people talking about detention centres?

A. In CAA, a reference has been made to the British-made law ‘The Foreigners Act, 1946’, which is made applicable to the entire country, except Assam. This Act provides for detention of those who are found to be foreigners, until they are themselves able to prove that they are not. Till that time, they would be placed in detention centres. Once a person is declared to not be a citizen of India, s/he loses rights under the Constitution and other laws, including voting rights.

Q. Why are minorities opposing CAA when it is meant to provide justice to the persecuted minorities?

A. CAA nowhere mentions the word ‘persecution’, nor does it elaborate what is meant by it. There is no data available or case reported to be pending in international courts about the persecution of minorities. The proven persecution is of Tamil Hindus in Sri Lanka and Rohingya Hindus in Myanmar, but they are conspicuously left out for no reason. The Ahmadiyya community and Shias of Indian origin are two of the most persecuted minorities in Pakistan, and they are also left out.

This Act seems to be malicious, and prima facie contrary to the provisions of Articles 14 and 21 of the Constitution of India — which guarantee equality before law and right to life.

Title: Telangana civic elections: Congress wins in over 500 wards but loses in Uttam & Revanth backyards
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Gandhi Bhavan wore a deserted look on Saturday. Congress is said to have performed below its expectations

HYDERABAD: With victories in over 500 wards and divisions in the elections to the 129 urban local bodies, the Congress has cemented its position as the main opposition in the state. The party’s tally is second highest after the ruling TRS which won in over 1,500 wards and divisions. Earlier, Congress was only second to TRS in the elections to gram panchayats, MPTCs and ZPTCs.

The Congress had won four and was leading in two urban local bodies (at the time of this report) — Adibhatla, Pedda Amberpet, Turkayamjal, Waddepalli, Chandur and Haliya — as against three won by BJP.

It stood second in a majority of the 120 municipalities that went to polls. Though the Congress finished in second place in six of the total nine municipal corporations the results for which were announced on Saturday, it was the BJP that won more number of divisions than Congress when it came to municipal corporations.

The BJP won 65 municipal divisions as against 40 by the Congress. They finished second in Ramagundam, Bandlaguda Jagir, Boduppal, Peerzadiguda and Jawaharnagar municipal corporations.

However, Congress’ performance is below its own expectations with the party failing to secure a majority in the urban local bodies in Nalgonda and Malkajgiri parliamentary constituencies, strongholds represented by state party president chief N Uttam Kumar Reddy and TPCC working president A Revanth Reddy.

The only solace was winning a few urban local bodies falling in the jurisdiction of Bhuvanagiri parliamentary constituency represented by former minister Komatireddy Venkat Reddy of Congress. In 2014 municipal elections, the Congress had won 19 urban local bodies.

TPCC working president A Revanth Reddy attributed TRS’ victory to alleged misuse of official machinery and distribution of cash and liquor by ruling party.

Title: JNU student booked for sedition by UP, Assam police
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

AGRA/GUWAHATI: Aligarh police on Saturday booked Jawaharlal Nehru University student Sharjeel Imam for sedition days after the purported video of a speech he had delivered at Aligarh Muslim University on January 16 against the Citizenship Amendment Act and NRC went viral on social media.

In the video, Imam, a software engineer who studies modern Indian history at JNU and was a teaching assistant at IIT Bombay , can be heard saying that if he can organise five lakh people, it would be possible to “permanently cut off Assam with the rest of India...if not permanently, then at least for a few months... only then will the government hear our voice”.

Imam, who lives in Delhi, has been booked under sections 124 A (sedition), 153 A (provocation with intent to cause riots), 153 B (causing disharmony) and 505 (2) of the IPC at the Civil Lines police station.

DIG (Aligarh) Akash Kulhary said, “During investigations, it was found that the purported video, in which the suspect made some anti-national statements, was shot on the AMU campus when he was addressing protesting students.” He added that Imam will be arrested soon.

This came even as the Assam Police followed suit and filed an FIR against Imam under similar charges. In the video, Imam is further heard saying: “The model of the Shaheen Bagh protest is that of road blockade, rest is secondary. Understand the difference between chakka jam and dharna. Protest in every city, tell the people about chakka jam, prepare and then sit on national highways.”

BJP's national spokesperson Sambit Patra shared the video on Twitter and later at a press conference, organised at the party's headquarters in Delhi, called it an “open call for jihad and finishing the sovereignty of the country.” He first said the speech was made at Shaheen Bagh but later when it became clear that it was at AMU, Patra said the new fact did not make the issue "less grave".

However, a statement released by the women of Shaheen Bagh on their official twitter account while reacting to talk on social media that Imam had made the comments as "organiser" of Shaheen Bagh said: "No one person, whether Sharjeel Imam or someone else, can be termed as the sole organiser of the protest. The protest has been led by the women of Shaheen Bagh and it is unfair to associate their voice with any distorted media narrative... We urge everyone to not be influenced by ...claims made of representing this non-partisan citizen's movement."

Imam, who was involved with the Shahen Bagh protests in the early days, is a computer science postgraduate from IIT Bombay and is originally from Patna. He did his schooling from DPS Vasant Kunj in Delhi and even worked as IT programmer at the University of Copenhagen before coming to JNU.

Title: Get ready to pay more tax, says Revanth Reddy
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Telangana Congress working president Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy

HYDERABAD: Telangana Congress working president , Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy on Saturday said TRS’s victory would mean that people of Telangana should brace up to pay more taxes. “With all the elections over except GHMC, CM K Chandrasekhar Rao will now hike the taxes on various fronts, punching a hole in the pockets of the citizens,” he said.

Stating that TRS had failed to win 50% of the wards in nearly 25 municipalities, Revanth said the ruling party won the elections by distributing money and liquor. “Congress has tasted numerous victories and defeats. As such, it only strengthens our resolve to win the hearts of the people in every coming election,” he said.

Asserting that TRS had resorted to blackmailing with KCR himself threatening his ministers, MPs, MLCs andd MLAs if they fail to ensure a TRS victory, he alleged that TRS leaders implicated Congress candidates in police cases so as to win the polls. He thanked the Congress workers for working hard to ensure party’s victory.

Title: Delayed again! February 29 new deadline for Kanaka Durga flyover completion
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

VIJAYAWADA: The Kanaka Durga flyover is likely to miss the deadline, again. Officials who promised to complete the project by January 31, has now extended the deadline to February 29.

Although chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy had directed the officials to complete the flyover project by December 2019, the contracting agency has cited interruptions due to Dasara celebrations and Bhavani Deeksha Viramana for failing to complete the project by January 1. Krishna district collector A MD Imtiaz who inspected the work, extended the deadline by a month. Officials have claimed that around 90% of the project work has already been completed.

Meanwhile, Vijayawada MP Kesineni Nani and Vijayawada East legislator Gadde Ramamohana Rao, accompanied by TDP supporters, inspected the ongoing works of Benz Circle flyover.

Kesineni Nani said the vision of former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu helped Vijayawada get a new look with the support of central funds. “I thank Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari for supporting us and giving funds for key flyover projects in the city. This project will help reduce traffic. We hope other projects in the city will be completed soon,” he said.

Title: Telangana municipal elections: BJP emerges as largest party in Nizamabad
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

The BJP office in city was mostly empty on Saturday. BJP stood third in the overall tally, behind TRS and Cong... Read More

HYDERABAD: It was a close call for the Bhartiya Janta Party (BJP) in the elections for the Nizamabad Municipal Corporation in which the party won 28 seats. It did emerge as the single largest party with the TRS and AIMIM winning 12 and 17 respectively, taking their combined number to 29. The Congress managed to win two while one division was bagged by an independent. The BJP had only managed to win six divisions in the 2014 elections.

The TRS will bank heavily on bagging the support of the two Congress and one independent winners to take the total rally to 32. The magic figure to get the mayoral post is 31.With elections for the mayor’s post scheduled for January 27, all eyes are now on whether the TRS-AIMIM combine would once again bag the post or whether the BJP can manage to emerge victorious but from where can it get the desired number remains a big question.

Despite three BJP MPs getting elected in the 2019 Lok Sabha elections in the districts, the party’s performance in the municipal elections did not match the projections it had made for itself. In the results declared for 120 municipalities on Saturday, the BJP could bag only two municipalities. In nine municipal corporations, BJP emerged in the second position in the number of wards it won but overall in the state, including in municipalities, it came third after as Congress bagged second position in number of wards won. BJP won 223 seats, while Congress got 495 and the TRS won from more than 1,000 wards. Elections were held for 2,727 wards.

Nizamabad MP Arvind Dharmapuri, while thanking the people of ‘Induru’, said he was dedicating the win to Prime Minister Narendra Modi. He alleged that in Division 21, a recounting was done unnecessarily and the TRS candidate was declared elected. The MP said that in Ward 1 too the ballot box seal was found opened but counting was still taken up by officials. He demanded a re-poll in both Wards 1 and 21. “People voted against the AIMIM and it is clear. In many divisions, BJP candidates won by a margin of over 1,000 votes,” Dharmapuri said.

For the MP, what could be encouraging is that the party’s tally of six in the 2014 election, has gone up to 28 in this election. The BJP which dreamt of capturing the mayoral post will be disheartened if it does not. Both Arvind Dharmapuri and also Goshamahal MLA Raja Singh who campaigned relentlessly announced that the name of Nizamabad would be changed to Induru if it came to power. The corporation has 60 divisions.

BJP state president K Laxman said the results demonstrated that the BJP was the only alternative to the TRS in the state. “We will analyse the results and take measures to strengthen the party further for the next general elections,” he said. In the 2014 elections, the TRS had bagged 10, MIM 16, the Congress 16, BJP 6 and independents 2. Taking the support of AIMIM, TRS candidate Akula Sujatha won the mayoral post. This time, she lost in the election. The AIMIM’s Nizamabad district president Fayeem also lost in the polls.

The BJP did not win any municipality in erstwhile Nizamabad, Karimnagar and Adilabad, though BJP MPs got elected from the constituencies in the Lok Sabha elections in 2019. Results of the Karimnagar municipal corporation will be out on January 27 when counting will be taken up. In Adilabad municipality, the BJP won from 11 wards, while TRS got 24 and Congress 5. The MIM also got 5 and others got four. It is clear even here the TRS will gets its chairperson elected.

The run-up to the polls, especially in Nizamabad and Karimnagar was a vitriolic campaign by parties. BJP MPs charged the police with taking the side of the ruling TRS party. The TRS criticised BJP MPs for allegedly raking up communal issues to secure votes.

Title: Officials face flak as counting for Boduppal is delayed by over 2 hrs
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Counting at Boduppal Municipal Corporation’s counting centre in Maa Gardens began after a delay of almost two-and-a-half-hours on Saturday morning. Even as serious allegations were levelled against election officials for the delay, candidates, party workers and journalists were kept in the dark despite several requests seeking explanations.

“We have been waiting for the counting to begin for the past two hours,” said Ramana Reddy, an Independent candidate (Ward 19). “The ballot boxes were brought from the strong room, and they were opened by 8am, but they did not start counting them till 10.45am. I think it is due to lack of proper arrangement, but there was no word from the counting officials about why there was a delay,” Reddy said

Mild tension prevailed outside the centre after party workers and journalists demanded an explanation. Journalists waiting outside the centre sat on a protest and raised slogans against the authorities for restricting entry into the counting centre and refusing to give an explanation for the delay.

A few party workers, who were waiting patiently for the results outside the barricades installed about 200 metres from the counting centre, suspected foul play in the delay. “How can it be that the counting for the remaining 119 municipalities and nine corporations in Telangana began at 8am and not here,” said Raghu Yadav, a party worker. “We understand if there is a delay of half an hour or an hour, but this is not acceptable. It is all part of the plan.”

However, when contacted, an official overseeing the arrangements at the counting centre said: “The delay is because the officials have decided to stack the votes and separate them according to the wards before they start counting. Other counting centres have started counting the votes directly without separating them. This is time consuming, but they are doing this to avoid any confusion.”

Title: TRS not resting on laurels, trying to win independents
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Hyderabad: Independents and candidates of other parties such as the All India Forward Bloc have become crucial in order to secure chairperson and mayor posts across urban local bodies in Telangana. A majority of these independents are said to be TRS rebels and the ruling party immediately began their efforts to bring them back to the party.

This, as voters threw a hung verdict in Ramagundam, Meerpet, Badangpet and Nizamabad municipal corporations and in municipalities including Nereducherla, Bhongir, Jangaon, Yadagirigutta, Manikonda, Narsingi, Bhootpur, Amarchinta, Kalwakurthy Chityal and Nalgonda among others.

The hung verdict has also raised curtains on camp politics and alleged horse-trading. Neither the TRS nor Congress nor BJP have got a clear majority in these urban local bodies.

The ruling TRS was swift to shift several independents to an undisclosed location. Meanwhile, the Congress lodged a complaint with the state election commission against the TRS for allegedly indulging in camp politics and confining elected independent ward members. The Congress also complained that even the police had taken in several independents from the wards that got hung verdict.

On the other hand, Congress and BJP are taking measures to safeguard their respective elected ward members from hung urban local bodies from being contacted by other political parties particularly the ruling party.

Though the ruling TRS has an advantage of having nearly over 140 ex-officio members in the form of MPs, MLCs, MLAs who would have the voting right to elect mayors and chairpersons in the urban local body they opt for, it is not taking chances and is getting in touch with party rebels who won and other independents too.

The elections to the post of mayor and chairpersons is on January 27. In all 225 independents won and another 48 candidates from other political parties such as Forward Bloc, CPI, CPM, TJS won some of the municipal wards.

In Kollapur municipality, Forward Bloc party candidates won more seats than the ruling TRS. These candidates are said be TRS rebels and belong to former minister Jupalli Krishna Rao’s group.

Title: Electoral roll enrolment is voters’ duty: Rajaram Mane
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nashik: Participating in elections form the base of democracy, hence, it is the duty of all eligible voters to register their names on the electoral roll , said Rajaram Mane, the divisional commissioner of Nashik.

Mane made the comments on Saturday, at an event organised at the collectorate to mark the National Voters’ Day. Those present included Nashik district collector Suraj Mandhare; deputy commissioner Dileep Swami; additional district collector Nilesh Sagar; assistant district collector Kumar Ashirwad; deputy district election officer Kundan Sonawane; sub-divisional officer Nilesh Shringi; tahsildar Prashant Patil; and brand ambassador for voters with disabilities Jayshree Toche.

District collector Mandhare said voters should have a positive approach towards the democratic process as this, in turn, would lead to qualitative change in the country. He added that booth level officers (BLOs) and NGOs play a pivotal part in the process.

Deputy commissioner Dilip Swami said voter participation is key because in a democracy, it’s the government that comes to the people asking them to halp elect representatives.

Students from various schools performed a skit to mark the day in an appeal to people enroll their names in the voters’ rolls.

The administration also presented voter ID cards to newly registered voters. Children who were part of essay writing and drawing competitions on the election process were felicitated by authorities at the event.

Title: Nashik: Lakhs attend 53rd Nirankari Sant Samagam
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

The programme began with a colourful procession at 11 am on Friday, followed by a message by Satguru Mata Sudi... Read More

NASHIK: Over two lakh devotees from across the world have gathered for the three-day congregation of Nirankari Sant Samagam , which started in the city on Friday.

The programme began with a colourful procession at 11 am on Friday, followed by a message by Satguru Mata Sudiksha. On all three days, the discourse by Satguru Mata Sudiksha will be organised at 9 pm. The programme will conclude on Sunday, January 26, followed by a mass marriage ceremony on January 27.

On Saturday, there was a sewadal rally where the devotees displayed yoga, aerobics, pyramid formations and karate and also performed skits. The devotees also participated in the congregation for the whole day where they recited hymns, psalms and prayers and shared experiences in Marathi, Hindi, English, Gujarati, Ahirani, Kannada, Sindhi, Banjara, Bhojpuri, Punjabi, Bengali and Nepali.

The community has also put up a large exhibition called “Nirankari Exhibition” as well as a “Bal Pradarshini”, which is an exhibition for children.

The community has made preparations for the boarding and lodging of the devotees at the venue. They have also put up the temporary kitchen facility to arrange for their food. The area has a big parking space apart from administrative stalls secured by close circuit cameras. Sant Nirankari Mission has competed 90 years in 2019.

Title: Vijayawada doctors conduct rare surgery
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image
