VIJAYAWADA: Doctors of Andhra Hospitals, Vijayawada, performed a complicated non-invasive transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) in an 80-year-old patient on Saturday. The patient had suffered recurrent ventricular tachycardia and cardiogenic shock before having a cardiac failure.

Explaining the details of the case, Dr Srimannarayana, head of the cardiac wing of Andhra Hospitals, said “She is a known case of severe calcific aortic stenosis for the last five years. Open heart surgery is a common treatment for such a case. But attendants hesitated to go ahead with the procedure considering the post-operative care risks. We chose TAVR as the best option as there is a chance of fast recovery,” Srimannarayana said. tnn

Title: Green roar of delight: CM taking side of tigers, forests welcomed
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nagpur: Greens are gaga over chief minister Uddhav Thackeray openly coming out in support of tigers and forests. On Friday, while shooting down a proposal for Human dam in Chandrapur district, he made it clear that irrigation projects cannot hamper wildlife corridors.

The dam was to be constructed 3.5km from Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve. It would have resulted in the diversion of 1.950 hectare dense forest and the felling of 1.50 lakh trees.

“To rise above vote bank politics and look at a brighter future for our planet, which we tend to overlook for short term gains, is to be applauded no end. I’m so happy that Uddhavji has taken a stand and lived up to our expectations. I hope all leaders can take inspiration from this and save the people from the environmental disaster we seem to be running towards. This should set a precedent keeping environment above politics and party lines. It is also important to revisit previously built projects, executed without much emphasis on environment and correct them with mitigation measures,” said actor Randeep Hooda.

Deepak Apte, director, Bombay Natural History Society said that it was heartening to see “CM taking firm stand” on one of the most “critical conservation issues”. “The Human dam would have caused irreversible damage to the wildlife corridor between Tadoba and other Central Indian tiger landscape,” he said.

Congratulating the CM, Apte said, “He also has ensured that water requirement needs are addressed by finding an alternate site. There are opportunities to create such win-win situation models, efforts must be taken for the same.”

Nitin Desai, director of Wildlife Protection Society of India Central India, was delighted that top political bosses are taking the side of tigers. “Chandrapur is already facing a space crunch for tigers. Given the non-committal approach of the irrigation department about either shifting the project upstream or adhering to mitigation measures suggested by NTCA, the CM directing authorities to revisit the proposal is wonderful news. Hope this spirit gets applied in other projects as well where wildlife generally ends up paying the price of development,” he said.

Wildlife photographer Sarosh Lodhi said, “When an elected representative gives more weight to saving environment, one knows that our forests and its animals are in the right hands.” This move will not only save our tigers in the proposed landscape but will also set the course for all other linear development projects that may bring harm to forests.”

“Special thanks to CM for a clear vision about environmental responsibility,” said conservationist Prafulla Bhamburkar.

According to him, this is the first time government has shown sensibility towards forest and tiger protection. “Every other project going to state wildlife board (SWBL) is cleared or kept pending if politicians do not want it. The proposal for Kanhargaon sanctuary in Chandrapur is a classic example,” said Bhamburkar.

Dr Jerryl Banait, who has PILs for wildlife protection, welcomed the CM decision. “If the project is shifted upstream, the dam can also come up and dispersing Tadoba tigers can also be saved. Thackeray has taken a very sensitive stand,” he said.

CM TO TOI

While considering irrigation projects and other proposals near forest areas, we need to also look into it that such projects do not prove hurdle to corridors. Development is a must but it should not be at the cost of environmental damage. Irrigation officials need to study if the project can be shifted 5km upstream

Uddhav Thackeray

Title: Bengaluru: Techie loses Rs 4 lakh to dating scam
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: The desire to date young girls proved costly for a 47-year-old senior software developer , who lost Rs 4 lakh to an organised dating scam .

Nishant (name changed) has approached Bommanahalli police for help. His tryst with the racketeers began on December 20 last year when he received a message on his mobile from what claimed to be a global dating web service , which claimed to have a database of young women who were willing to date.

Nishant said he called the number mentioned in the SMS out of curiosity and spoke to a person who introduced herself as Payal. She told him he must register by paying Rs 2,000 to continue using the dating service. “I initially gave some money, after which they started sending photos of the women on WhatsApp claiming they were in Bengaluru and I could meet them,” Nishant said.

They continued to demand money for various reasons over the next 10 days. The scamsters would send him photos of a woman and tell him he could meet her in the next one hour if he transferred the amount. “Every time, they would set a deadline and ask me to transfer money for various reasons like booking a hotel to meet the woman, get medical certificate clearance and what not. For 11 days, I transferred money at least three or four times every day through e-wallets and online banking,” he added.

On 31 December 2019, when they demanded Rs 1 lakh, Nishant realised he’d been taken for a ride. By then, he had ended up paying Rs 4.2 lakh. “I approached police as there could be many who would’ve been robbed of their money by such dating sites,” he said.

Title: Bengaluru: Septic tank cleaner suffocates to death
Content:
Siddanna (above) had entered the 20-ft deep tank on Infantry Road to clean it

BENGALURU: A 18-year-old labourer suffocated to death and his colleague was shifted to hospital after they stepped into a septic tank on Infantry Road on Saturday to clean it.Siddanna, a resident of HBR Layout and from Siraguppa taluk in Ballari, got into the tank in the Ganesh Bagh Jain Sthanak premises and died there, police said.“The tank is around 20ft deep and covered with an iron grill. Using an electric motor, Siddanna and contractor Muniyanna pumped out the water in the morning. Then, they stepped inside to clean it. Siddanna went first and fell unconscious. Not realising there was no oxygen inside, Muniyanna stepped in and he too fell unconscious. Office-bearers of Ganesh Bagh pulled them out,” police said.Before they could be shifted to Bowring hospital, Siddanna had died. Doctors said there was sewage in Muniyanna’s lungs and he has been shifted to ICU. “This is a typical case of asphyxiation, oxygen deprivation during septic tank cleaning. He has seizures, is unconscious and on ventilator in ICU,” said Dr CM Muralidhar, resident medical officer, Bowring hospital.Based on a complaint by Siddanna’s family, police booked a criminal case against office-bearers of Ganesh Bagh under IPC Section 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) and under Prohibition of Employment as Manual Scavengers and their Rehabilitation Act-2013. Siddanna’s sisters Gangamma and Mangamma said he had left home at 6am. “Six of us worked for Muniyanna for the past three weeks and he had to pay us Rs 30,000. Siddanna went to collect the money,” said Mangamma, adding Siddanna was paid Rs 450-Rs 600 per day depending on work.When STOI visited the spot, there were vehicles parked on top of the septic tank covered by a grill. The entire space was washed. However, a rope, used by labourers to enter the tank, was around. Ganesh Bagh representatives were not available for comment.

Title: Pakistani man’s son seeks to stay in India with ailing mother
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Sheik Noora with his parents at Railway Kodur police station on Saturday.

TIRUPATI: A family drama across countries unfolded in Railway Kodur, in Kadapa district, on Saturday when a youth born to a Pakistani father and Indian mother pleaded with the police to allow him to stay in India with his mother.

Railway Kodur police said Sheik Noora, a local resident, had relocated to Kuwait in search of employment 22 years ago. While in Kuwait, she got married to Pakistani national Jaffer Sahid in 1997. The couple gave birth to a son , Valid Jaffer, in Kuwait. A year ago, Jaffer Sahid deserted Noora and moved back to Pakistan with his son, while the woman returned to her hometown Railway Kodur.

Noora later learnt that Valid was unhappy living with his father in Pakistan and decided to meet her son. On January 17, Valid arrived in India on a tourist visa and was reunited with his mother. On learning that a visitor from Pakistan was staying in the town, local police summoned Valid and his family to the police station as part of a routine enquiry.

During the enquiry, Valid pleaded with the police to let him continue living with his mother, who is in poor health, but police clarified that the tourist visa is valid for only a period of 45 days, following which he has to leave the country. Kadapa SP KKN Anburajan told STOI that the police will a keep a tab on Valid’s movements during his stay.

Title: Padma awards for George, Vashishtha & six others from state
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Patna: Veteran socialist leader and former defence minister George Fernandes (posthumously) is among the seven prominent personalities to be awarded Padma Vibhushan this year.

Fernandes, who was elected to Lok Sabha from Muzaffarpur from behind the bars in 1977, represented the seat five times before shifting his constituency to Nalanda. He was one of the founder members of erstwhile Samta Party following the split of Janata Dal in 1996.

Besides George, seven persons from Bihar were selected for Padma Shri awards. The most prominent among them is eminent mathematician Vashishtha Narayan Singh (posthumously) for his contribution in the field of science and engineering. Vashishta, who had challenged Albert Einstein’s theory of relativity, died after prolonged illness on November 14 last year. He was suffering from schizophrenia for nearly four decades.

Dr Shanti Roy, a Patna-based gynaecologist, has been selected for Padma Shri award for her outstanding work in the field of medicine. The others selected in this category of Padma awards are Ramjee Singh (social work), Shyam Sunder Sharma (art), Shanti Jain (art), Bimal Kumar Jain (social work) and Sujoy K Guha (science and engineering).

Chief minister Nitish Kumar expressed delight over the conferment of Padma Vibhushan to late George Fernandes and late BJP stalwarts Sushma Swaraj and Arun Jaitely as well as Padma Shri to late Vashishtha Narayan. In a statement issued by the CM office late on Saturday evening, Nitish congratulated all seven Padma Shri award winners from Bihar.

Governor Phagu Chauhan also congratulated the recipients of the coveted awards.

Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi also expressed delight over conferment of the Padma awards to people of state from different fields. He congratulating Bimal Kumar Jain for Padma Shri award. SuMo said Jain is credited with contributing to organ donation movement in the state and providing artificial limbs to more than 30,000 persons with disabilities.

Title: Cong top leaders wanted NIT’s dissolution: Fadnavis
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nagpur: Former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis has jumped into the battle as the BJP attempts to thwart Congress minister Nitin Raut’s bid to revive the ‘dissolved’ Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT).

Fadnavis claimed that Raut was going against his party’s national leadership by not sticking to his government’s decision to dissolve NIT. “The top leadership had written a letter to the then chief minister Sushilkumar Shinde seeking scrapping of NIT. According to them existence of NIT was against the principles of 74th constitutional amendment which was done by Rajiv Gandhi government. The amendment aimed to make urban local bodies more powerful. He should not insult his party leaders and change his stand,” said the BJP leader.

Mayor Sandip Joshi has convened a general body meeting on Monday to pass a resolution against guardian minister Raut’s proposal to strengthen NIT. The guardian minister has reacted saying the state government will not be affected and will take its own decision.

Fadnavis, now the leader of opposition, said that the Congress-NCP did not dissolve NIT for over ten years when it was in power. “Finally it was the BJP government, which took steps in this direction. I fail to understand Congress leaders’ love for NIT,” he added.

On Friday, he had told TOI that no city in India except Nagpur had two civic authorities having same area of jurisdiction. “Nagpur has suffered due to conflict of jurisdiction. It would not be advisable to do it again,” he had said.

Fadnavis had filed a public interest litigation (PIL) in Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court a few years ago and had annexed the Congress high command letter with it. Another activist Anil Wadpalliwar, who too had filed a PIL against NIT, confirmed the existence of the letter. “I too had submitted the letter to the HC,” he said demanding dissolution of NIT.

Former state home minister Shrikant Jichkar had lobbied with the Congress-ruled state government in 1994 to abolish NIT. In 2002 he had written an open letter to media on his views.

City BJP leaders are now keen to produce this letter in the general body meeting to corner Congress. The opposition in NMC is yet to decide on its stand.

Congress corporators had demanded NIT’s abolition several times in the past. Now they will find it difficult to support Raut’s proposal. The letter if produced by BJP will make their position even more difficult.

NIT would have not been in existence today had the Fadnavis government not dilly-dallied on the issue. He decided to scrap the agency in December 2016, over two years after coming to power. A committee was formed to oversee transfer of NIT property to NMC by December 31, 2017. As the committee comprising an IAS officer did little to achieve the objective, the date for dissolution had to be postponed.

At the fag end of his tenure, Fadnavis cabinet again cleared dissolution of NIT and urban development department (UDD) issued a preliminary notification in this regard. However, assembly elections were announced before the final notification could be issued.

Title: Now, apply online for Maharashtra State Eligibility Test by January 29: SPPU
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Savitribai Phule Pune University

NASHIK: Savitribai Phule Pune University ( SPPU ) has extended the last date of filing online application forms for the Maharashtra State Eligibility Test (SET) till January 29.

University sources said that there was a technical glitch in the server last week, following which examinees were unable to fill up the forms online.

“The technical glitch has now been corrected by the varsity. Candidates faced problems while filling online application form due to the unexpected server crash and, thus, the last date for submitting applications has been extended by a week,” sources said.

Earlier the last date for online application was from January 1 to 22.

While filling the online form, candidates will have to make online payment. If there is any correction in the form, the candidates can make the same between January 31 and February 6.

The admit cards of the candidates will be available from June 18. The examination is slated to take place on June 28.

SPPU conducts SET for appointment of assistant professors. It is an equivalent examination of National Eligibility Test (NET) conducted by National Test Agency (NTA) but is valid in the respective states. In Maharashtra, the test is conducted by SPPU.

Title: From heart attack to infertility, noise pollution is silent killer
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nagpur: Bursting the myth that noise pollution only causes hearing trouble, city experts warn that high decibels can have an adverse impact on the human heart, psychology, digestive system and fertility.

The latest research done by scientists at the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (Neeri) reveals that noise levels exceed permissible standards of the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) all across the city.

TOI took expert opinions to know the impact of increasing noise pollution on public health. While adverse effect on hearing due to high decibels is quite known, medical experts highlighted the lesser-known health damages.

Stating that noise pollution is a “silent killer” and a public health crisis, noted ENT surgeon Dr Madan Kapre highlighted its multiple health impacts. “The least understood of them is noise-induced anxiety states which include tachycardia, blood pressure, sweating and restlessness. All increase with exposure to noise,” he said.

Honking also leads to fatal accidents, added Kapre. “Loud honking often causes startle reflex, due to which motorists lose control over vehicle. At Narendra Nagar bridge in Nagpur, a mother and a child met with a fatal accident due to this,” said Kapre.

Latest studies show that exposure to high pollution also results in infertility. “Not many are aware that high decibels lead to impotency and also miscarriage. It is also responsible for increased stress levels, anxiety disorder, acidity, ulcers and indigestion,” said ENT surgeon Dr Naresh Agrawal.

According to both the experts, lack of concentration is also an outcome of noise pollution. “A study conducted in local schools had revealed that index of learning is higher in schools which witness less noise pollution,” said Dr Kapre.

People living in railway tracks and crowded areas are more vulnerable to hearing problems. “Tinnitus (ringing in ears) is a common problem faced by those living near railway tracks,” said Dr Agrawal.

Citing another study carried out in Central Avenue Road, Dr Kapre said, “Shopkeepers based in congested areas are victims of noise-induced deafness. Apart from this, every Diwali I get at least half a dozen patients complaining of hearing problem due to firecrackers. Noise pollution is affecting all in different ways yet no one wants to talk about it.”

Title: State plans to allow establishments to run at night in Pune & Nagpur too: Deshmukh
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Anil Deshmukh

Nagpur: After Mumbai, the Maharashtra government plans to allow commercial establishments like malls to run throughout night in two more cities of Pune and Nagpur, home minister Anil Deshmukh said.

While interacting with TOI on Saturday, he said that the government would study the response in Mumbai and then implement the same pattern in next two phases, first in Pune and then in Nagpur.

Later during his media interaction, he spoke on several issues including many contentious ones facing the Maharashtra Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government. He said the government has sought legal opinion on National Investigation Agency’s (NIA) move to take over Koregaon-Bhima violence probe and then decide on the future course of action.

“Ideally they (Union Home Ministry) should have taken the state’s consent. Their move is completely unconstitutional. States like West Bengal and Chhattisgarh had also opposed the NIA’s move earlier. They (BJP) may want to protect their men, who were part of the conspiracy,” he said, adding that the probe against Sambhaji Bhide and Milind Ekbote was underway.

Stating that he had been receiving many representations from the NGOs and common people against implementation of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register for Citizens (NRC), Deshmukh asserted that NCP and Congress fully endorsed their views.

“We’re yet to talk to our third partner. Based on the consensus, we will take a decision to pass the resolution on the lines of Kerala and Punjab. Even if Congress leader Kapil Sibal had stated that the states are bound to implementation the Act, what if they’re unwilling to cooperate. Over 1,250 protests have taken place including in Nagpur.”

Explaining MVA’s stand on the mysterious death of judge HD Loya, the minister said he had received many complaints from the NGOs and individuals that they were possessing many proofs. “However, no one approached me till date. Even as the Supreme Court had prohibited hearing of any cases on the incident, we can always explore if new evidence comes across.”

Replying on whether the government would handover the probe of multi-crore irrigation scam to other agency from Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) following the demand by the petitioner Janmanch, the five-time minister said ACB was doing its job properly. “You should ask the chief minister of 72 hours-old government who had himself appointed the agency and recently endorsed its stand.”

Deliberating on threats faced by the government, he said the biggest one comes from the over 2.5 lakh unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) drones, which were unregistered till date, and from cyber-criminals. “You must have watched how the Iranian General Qassem Soleimani was killed by the US forces with the help of drones. In the past, UAVs are used against attacking Venezuela president and others. They’re having 10-20 kms range and have good payload capacity. With advancement in the technology, we need to think ahead of the enemy’s sinister plans to prevent the deadly attacks like 1993 bomb blasts and 2008 terror strike in Mumbai and 2002 Parliament attack,” he said.

Reiterating the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in the police functioning, the minister cited Chief Justice of India Sharad Bobde’s words of how it had helped the judiciary to read the thousands of documents while delivering key verdicts like on Ayodhya’s Ram Mandir. Agreeing with the concerns that prisons had become overcrowded, Deshmukh said those should be shifted outside the cities and expanded to accommodate the ever increasing number of inmates and those vacant places should be utilized for good projects.

Title: NIA taking over Elgar case has complicated matters: Tushar
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Tushar Kanti Bhattacharya, husband of Nagpur University professor Shoma Sen

Nagpur: “The wait has only got longer now,” says the weary 64-year old Tushar Kanti Bhattacharya after the National Investigation Agency on Friday took over investigations in the Elgar Parishad case in which his wife Shoma Sen has been jailed for 19 months.

Nagpur University professor Sen is among the three from Nagpur and one of the nine arrested in the case registered in Pune last year. The decision comes a couple of days before the bail plea in the charges framed by the state police is to be heard in Pune.

“It is slated for January 27. I plan to travel and also meet her. However, things have further complicated now,” says Bhattacharya.

Saying that the accused in Elgar Parishad case have now become a victim of political tug of war, Bhattacharya said, “Sharad Pawar had pressed for a special investigation team probe into the police action. Within a day, the case was transferred to NIA by the Centre. Those arrested in the case are suffering due to the political oneupmanship.”

The Pune police’s case was that inflammatory speeches at the December 31, 2017 Elgar Parishad led to violence in Koregaon Bhima the next day.

Relatives of those jailed are going through a lot of physical and emotional trauma. “Some days ago my blood pressure shot up. Travelling to Pune for the hearings leaves us weary,” says Bhattacharya.

Bhattacharya says subsistence has become difficult after his wife’s arrest. “Shoma was suspended by the university after her arrest. She retired from service while still in jail.

The university has not released her pension, according to Bhattacharya. “I have been requesting university officials to start it. Strangely, a communication from the higher education department refers to Shoma as suspended-retired employee. How can a retired employee be suspended as well,” he asks.

Bhattacharya said that five months ago the joint director of higher education asked director for a clarification if provisional pension could be released during pendency of a case. “Early this month, the director’s office told me that a reply will be sent within 15 days. Its been three weeks now,” he says.

Sen’s daughter Koel, who resides in Mumbai, said that Shoma is in “solitary confinement”. “No mattress has been provided to her and she has used two blankets instead. The light remains switched on throughout the night, she has got accustomed to it,” she says.

Koel too finds courts visits “distressing”. “On some occasions we are not even allowed to talk, on others the authorities are very generous,” she says.

Title: ‘Nashik has potential to become a tourism hub’
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nashik: The footfall of tourists has been increasing from the past five years and there is a huge potential in the city, said the president of the Travel Agents Association of Nashik (TAAN).

A delegation from TAAN will soon meet the state tourism minister Aditya Thackeray and discuss what needs to be done to further promote tourism in the city.

Speaking during the three-day tourism expo, which started on Friday, Rajendra Bakre said that the association has plans to develop Nashik as a tourism hub. “The tourism expo is a part of promotion and branding of the city to attract tourists,” he said.

He said that the association would like to capitalise on the increasing number of tourists in the city. “Nashik is not only a religious city, but it is also known for its pleasant climate. It has also emerged as the wine capital of the country and there are over 100 trekking sites in the district. Nashik is one of the four cities in the country where Kumbh Mela is held after every four years,” Bakre said.

He felt that government support is also equally important for the city to become a tourism hub. “There is a huge tourism potential and it needs a lot of branding and marketing of the city. We have already been making efforts to promote Nashik as a tourism hub. But efforts are needed from the government also, said Bakre.

Meanwhile, the tourism expo was inaugurated by the DCP Laxmikant Patil on Friday.

Over 50 travel companies put up their stalls presenting various tour options right from the USA, Europe to various domestic destinations.

TAAN has been conducting exhibitions every year, a month before the summer season begins. This is the 15th tourism expo being held in the city. “Early bookings help us get hotel rooms at lower rates and the benefits are passed on to tourists. Hence, they may get tour packages at reasonable rates,” added Bakre.

The travel companies, which participated in the expo were The Departures, Khanvel Resort, Nidhi Tours, Thomas Cook Ltd, Sukhmani Tours & Travels, Magic Mountain, Prasanna Holidays, Konkan Paryatan Vikas Sanstha, Tulip Holidays etc.

Title: Goa audition for Konkani singing contest on March 1
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

PANAJI: The fifth edition of the Konkani singing contest, SOAD which draws participation of budding singers from Goa, Mangaluru and Udipi will be held soon.

The contest is open to people singing in any Konkani dialect. Participants must be between 15 and 40 years old. Auditions in Goa are scheduled to be held at the directorate of art and culture hall, Panaji , at 9am on March 1. There will be eight rounds starting with auditions. Contestants entering the ‘Top 10’ round will perform live at Kalaangann.

Winners will be bestowed with the ‘ Ranni Kogul’ and ‘Ray Kogul’ titles along with a Rs 50,000 cash prize. They will also be appointed as Konkani youth ambassadors.

Title: Liquor smuggler killed in Vaishali police encounter
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Notorious liquor smuggler Baiju Mahto was killed in a police encounter in Vaishali district in the wee hours of Saturday. Baiju’s close aide Ashutosh Kumar, a resident of Premnagar under Lalganj police station in Vaishali district, was arrested.

Vaishali SP Gaurav Mangla said two pistols, three live and three empty cartridges and an SUV were seized from the spot. At least nine cases under Excise and Prohibition Act 2016 were lodged against Baiju with the Lalganj police station alone. Besides, other cases related to extortion, loot and murder were pending at Patepur, Bhagwanganj and Mahua police stations in the district. He was a resident of Pakri village in Vaishali district.

The encounter took place barely a few hours after state DGP Gupteshwar Pandey, in a review meeting at the Vaishali district headquarters on Friday, warned the “lax” and “lazy” police officers of stern disciplinary action.

Police said Baiju (40) along with his two associates opened fire on a police team which tried to intercept an SUV near Tinpulwa turning under Lalganj police station around 1am on Saturday. Lalganj SHO Sunil Kumar, who was leading the police team, had a narrow escape in the firing. The police returned the fire causing injuries to Baiju. He was rushed to Lalganj referral hospital from where doctors referred him to Hajipur Sadar hospital. However, he succumbed to his injuries on way to Hajipur. While one of Baiju’s associates managed to escape under the cover of darkness, his close aide Ashutosh Kumar from Premnagar in Vaishali district was arrested.

SP Mangla said that raids were on to nab the criminal, who had managed to escape. Police sources said Baiju was also involved in the attack on a former SHO of Lalganj police station about four years ago. Sources said Vaishali, of late, has turned into a safe zone for bootleggers.

This is perhaps the first occasion when a liquor smuggler had been killed in a police encounter in the state this year. Earlier, a suspected liquor smuggler, Munna, was killed in a police encounter under Barsoi police station in Katihar district in February 2018.

Munna’s killing had led to wide protest by the victim’s relatives and some local residents. The mob had vandalized the Barsoi police station. Munna was killed while sneaking into Katihar district from Raiganj in West Bengal on February 14, 2018.

The state was declared dry on April 4, 2016 under Bihar Excise and Prohibition Act. Under the law, manufacture, sale and consumption of liquor is banned in the state.

Title: Datke is city BJP chief; Gajbhiye to head dist
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pravin Datke being felicitated

Nagpur: Pravin Datke has been appointed as the city BJP president for three years while Arvind Gajbhiye is the new district president. Datke was the interim president since June 2019. BJP has also appointed new assembly constituency unit presidents in the city. The six assembly constituency unit presidents of Nagpur rural will be appointed next week.

The party has tried to give representation to all castes. Gajbhiye is a Dalit while his predecessor Rajiv Poddar was a Brahmin. Dalits feel under-represented in BJP and Gajbhiye has been given the charge to woo the community. The party had performed badly in the rural areas of the district in the recent assembly elections, winning only two out of six seats. Poddar himself had lost badly from Saoner. Gajbhiye was the general secretary of the district unit.

The six assembly unit presidents of the city are Vinod Kanhere (Nagpur West), Devendra Dasture (Nagpur South), Sanjay Chaudhari (Nagpur North), Kishor Palandurkar (Nagpur Central), Kishor Wankhede (Nagpur South-West) and Sanjay Awchat (Nagpur East). One is a Brahmin, three are Kunbis, one is a Kalar and one a Teli. Datke is an OBC belonging to the Barai community.

Significantly, BJP has not appointed a Dalit as the in-charge of Nagpur North unit. The constituency is reserved for SCs and has a large Dalit population. The new chief Chaudhari is a Kunbi.

While Datke’s election was a foregone conclusion, several persons were in the race for the district president’s post. They were Hingna MLA Sameer Meghe, Kamptee MLA Tekchand Sawarkar, former MLA Sudhir Parwe, senior leader Anandrao Raut and Gajbhiye.

Sources in BJP said that Gajbhiye’s name was finalized by Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari, former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis and former guardian minister Chandrashekhar Bawankule on Friday night. The formal announcement of the new presidents was made at a party function held at Geeta Mandir, Subhash Road.

Title: Sattari dy collector to inspect mining zones in Pissurlem
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Valpoi: Deputy collector of Sattari Mangaldas Gaonkar said he will visit Pissurlem and inspect the mining zones there along with Sattari mamlatdar Anil Sardesai, and will present a report to the higher authorities. At a recent meeting aggrieved villagers had complained to Gaonkar that the mining silt released into agricultural land has largely affected farming activity and that they should get compensation for the loss of crops, which is due from 2017.

tnn

Title: Goa: Army doctors get payout from builder for son’s death
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The military doctor couple who lost their four-and-a-half-year-old son in 2017, when he fell from their sixth-floor home due to a faulty grill in the naval officer’s colony in Dabolim, has received compensation of Rs 1.3 crore from NKG Infrastructure Ltd. The amount was paid by NKG infrastructure Ltd ( Panaji ) and Pradeep Kumar Garg on Wednesday, via demand draft.

The Vasco police have filed a chargesheet against all accused persons except the project manager of the Married Accomodation Project (MAP). Vasco PI informed the high court that a sanction was required from the ministry of defence. The ministry of defence took a decision not to grant sanction to prosecute the project manager, MAP before the courts under the Code of Criminal Procedure, but instead, to proceed under the Army Act, 1950.

Standing counsel for the central government representing the director general and project manager, MAP, stated that disciplinary proceedings have commenced against the errant officers, and pointed out that a tentative chargesheet has already been placed, and three hearings have taken place in the matter.

“Proceedings have to be expedited in a manner of this nature, so that justice is done to all parties involved,” stated the order passed by justices Mahesh Sonak and M S Jawalkar.

The child, Atharva Taralkar was playing near the window on the sixth floor of the flat at NOFRA-E, Dabolim, when the grill installed on the window dislodged and fell out, causing him to fall and succumb to his injuries in 2017.

His parents, Lt-Colonel Narendra Taralkar and Surgeon Lieutenant Trishna Taralkar , donated their son’s corneas.

Title: Bihar: 2 IPS officers, 1 havildar to get President’s medal
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Senior IPS officers Amit Kumar and Sunil Kumar Jha, along with havildar Uday Ram of 14th battalion of Bihar Military Police (BMP) have been selected for the President’s Police Medal for Distinguished Service.

Amit is ADG , law and order and Sunil is ADG, vigilance investigation bureau. Besides these three, seven others from Bihar have been selected for Police Medal for Gallantry and ten for Police Medal for Meritorious Service. The announcements were made on the eve of Republic Day on Saturday.

Those chosen for Police Medal for Gallantry are assistant sub-inspector Vivek Kumar and sub-inspectors Amrendra Kishore, Baijnath Kumar, Devraj Indra, Santosh Kumar Singh, Rupak Ranjan Singh and Pankaj Anand.

DIG (security) Ashok Kumar in special branch, Madhepura SP Sanjay Kumar , special vigilance unit ASI Shakeel Ahmad Khan, special task force SI Baijnath Kumar, ASI Kamlesh Kumar Pandey, BMP-14 constable Lal Baboo Yadav, constable Manish Kumar in DGP office, SIs Hanaullah Khan and Mohammad Irshad Alam of BMP-14 and ASI Chandan Pratap Singh posted at DIG office in Chhapra, Saran will get Police Medal for Meritorious Service.

ADG (headquarters) Jitendra Kumar issued the list of awardees from the state in the three categories and congratulated them on behalf of state police.

Police officers and personnel are selected for four category of medals from state police and paramilitary forces across the country.

Title: Mayor, others not invited for Patole meeting in Mumbai
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nagpur: Speaker Nana Patole has organized meetings on Monday in Mumbai to discuss two issues which were left undecided by the BJP-ruled Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and Devendra Fadnavis-led state government. The issues have financial implications on the cash-strapped NMC and may further escalate the growing tension between the BJP and Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government.

Patole wants to discuss 7th Pay Commission salary for NMC employees as well as the instalment for builders in building plan charges above Rs1 crore. Urban development minister Eknath Shinde and officials from urban development, finance and other departments are expected to attend the meetings.

The urban development department has asked the NMC chief to be present. No invitation has been issued for mayor Sandip Joshi, standing committee chairman Pradip Pohane or any other office bearer. As the new civic chief is yet to take charge and with Joshi calling an urgent general body meeting on Monday, the heads of town planning and finance departments are likely to go to Mumbai.

The office bearers of NMC’s only recognized union — Rashtriya Nagpur Corporation Employees Association — have been invited for the meeting. The association is led by the Congress and a delegation had discussed the 7th pay commission status with Patole, guardian minister Nitin Raut and Shinde earlier.

Union president Surendra Tingane told TOI that NMC employees were not given salary as per 7th Pay Commission as the previous government delayed its implementation. “The general body passed a resolution to implement it with effect from August 2019. The proposal is pending with the state government,” he said.

Tingane said the union will seek directives for arrears of 6th Pay Commission and 7th Pay Commission to be paid. “The 6th Pay Commission arrears from January 1, 2006 to November 30, 2010 is pending. NMC gave some amount in three instalments. Also, arrears of 7th Pay Commission from January 1, 2016 is pending,” he said.

The BJP-ruled NMC had declined to give arrears of both pay commissions due to the financial crisis. It would have incurred an additional burden of Rs20 crore per month.

The second issue of making provision for instalment in paying building plan charges of over Rs1 crore is pending at the NMC level. CREDAI is pressing for the demand since a year.

During the tenure of Virendra Kukreja, the standing committee had approved the provision in February 2019. Since then, the proposal is pending and yet to come before the general body.

If approved, the NMC will not get bulk amount from town planning department at one go.

For last few days, differences have cropped up between MVA government and BJP over formation of committee on Nag River Pollution Abatement Project and Raut’s plan to retain NIT’s planning authority status of Gunthewari areas.

Though elected from Sakoli in Bhandara district, Patole is a resident of the Nagpur from where he had lost the last Lok Sabha elections.

Title: Caste, money still play big role in elections, says Goa governor Satya Pal Malik
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Governor Satya Pal Malik felicitates North Goa collector R Menaka at the National Voter’s Day function held at... Read More

PANAJI: Despite improvements in the electoral process over the years, caste and money politics continue to play a major role in elections in the country, Goa Governor Satya Pal Malik said on Saturday.

“It (caste politics) is not visible but irrespective of the party, candidates are fielded on the basis of caste,” he said during the National Voter’s Day function at Kala Academy.

“Caste-based politics is a terrible thing and nothing else can stand in comparison to this. I have seen the trend broken only on two or three occasions. Once was in the elections after Indira Gandhi’s death, when it was broken due to the wave of nationalism that took over. The second was when Prime Minister Narendra Modi came to power. Nationalism broke this trend again,” Malik said, adding that it was difficult to put an end to caste politics.

‘Money power’ too is a big factor in elections, he said, adding that candidates spend up to Rs 1 crore to sway voters. “This is destroying the sanctity of the election process,” he said.

Malik credited former chief election commissioner T N Seshan for streamlining the electoral process by introducing central paramilitary forces for security, instead of local police during elections which helped put an end to booth-capturing, and added that the issue of people voting twice – at their place of work and their native village- has also been streamlined. Despite this, caste and money politics continues, he said.

“There’s no bigger empowerment than the vote,” he said, urging people to use their right wisely, and shame those who don’t.

He criticised the highly-educated in Mumbai who fail to exercise their franchise to vote, pointing out that it always records a low voting percentage.

“This is not the case in Goa, where the voting percentage is healthy,” he said.

Title: Nab robbers in two days or be ready to sit at HQ, police told
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nagpur: Miffed at the constant failure of the detection branch units in solving cases, including prevention of a robbery at Gopalkrishna Nagar on Saturday by three goons, the top brass of the Nagpur police took a decision to attach around three dozens of cops and officers of the detection branch unit of Sakkardara, Nandanvan and Hudkeshwar police stations to headquarters.

But, following the intervention of Zonal DCP Nirmala Devi S, they got two days’ respite. Now they have either to nab the three involved in the robbery or be ready to get replaced and sit at the headquarters.

The cops from Sakkardara, Wathoda, Nandanvan and Hudkeshwar police stations have not only failed to generate any inputs regarding the suspects but also failed to prevent the latest incident of Gopalkrishna Nagar despite all plans were in place and briefings done.

City police chief B K Upadhyay deployed seven police stations of Zone IV in the east and southern part of the city under DCP Nirmala between 4am and 7am. “We had already issued the order of their transfers but decided to defer the implemtntaion on the request of the DCP Nirmala for two days,” the CP said.

The city police have requested the NMC to keep street lights on till 6.30amas they are having difficulties in spotting suspects and vehicles in the CCTV cameras.

The Gopalkrishna Nagar robbery where Bebitai Urkunde, 50, was threatened with knife by the three robbers at 5.47am on Saturday was the fourth such kind of armed robbery. The three robbers fled with gold chain of Urkunde, worth Rs 12,000, after injuring her.

Cops spotted the trio on a bike at 5.30am but a miscalculation by an officer proved costly. While he directed colleagues to rush to Dighori naka, the goons took the Dighori bridge before sneaking into a lane and within minutes fled after robbing Urkunde.

Title: Man found murdered in front of house; kin, police in dark
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Victim Harish Patel

Nagpur: The family of a 32-year-old man, Harish Patel, woke up on Saturday to the horror of seeing his body in a pool of blood just opposite their house. Patel was found murdered in front of his house at Kachipura with several injuries of sharp weapons on his body and head smashed with heavy stone.

Patel, who had murdered one Yogesh Patta around a decade ago, had got settled with family after inheriting father’s business of food stalls near Shankar Nagar garden. He still had considerable domination in the locality. Police are still groping in dark about the motive and suspects behind the murder.

A neighbour and a kin, however, are learnt to be under police scanner. According to police, Patel suspected his wife’s close relation with a relative whom he had thrashed around a year ago. The relative had earned the ire of Patel after he had gone to see off his wife at Rewa in Madhya Pradesh against his wish. Patel had been nurturing hatred for the relative who was rounded up by crime branch for questioning after the murder.

Patel’s son Sujal said he had called up his father at midnight who said he might not come home. “Though father had said that he was not returning, still I went around trying to locate him at the eateries and bars but could not trace him. Later, I had gone to sleep,” he said.

It’s learnt Patel had a habit of consuming liquor daily with friends. On the evening before his murder, he had gone out with three of his friends in an auto-rickshaw for having liquor at Sitabuldi.

One of the friends, who was with Patel, said that he had left him near his house at 2am. “After dropping a friend near Chunabhatti, we had returned to Kachipura. Later, I had gone back home,” he said.

The mystery behind Patel’s murder has so far kept the cops on tenterhooks and family in the dark. Patel’s son Sujal said that he had named some suspects before police with whom his father either had a fight or quarrel in the past including a DJ player who was supposed to repay some money he had borrowed.

Bajaj Nagar police have registered an offence against unidentified persons. Police said around four persons are likely to be involved. “Cops have already quizzing some suspects but yet to get any breakthrough,” said a senior officer.

Title: Goa: Postal ballot for voters with disabilities, those over 80 years
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: In a move that is sure to bring relief to senior citizens and persons with disabilities (PwD), chief electoral officer Kunal has said that those above the age of 80 years and persons with physical disabilities will no longer have to go to the polling station to vote. Instead, they will be given the option of voting via postal ballot.

“A notification has recently been issued by the Commission of India by virtue of which senior citizens (above 80 years) and those with physical disabilities can be granted postal ballots if they request for it,” Kunal said. He was speaking recently at the national voter’s day programme held at Kala Academy, Panaji . This, Kunal said, is one of the most notable achievements as far as accessibility in the electoral process concerned.

In the 2019 general elections, wheelchairs were made available at every polling station in the state. “We were also successful in tagging 7,700 PwD voters in our electoral management system,” he said. Further he encouraged people to assist in tagging, saying this will help create more facilities for PwD voters.

Kunal also said that the elector’s verification programme has been carried out successfully throughout the state with cent percent results and that 19,000 entries have been found that required correction. There has only been a marginal increase in voters as compared to the last year, he said.

Chief secretary Parimal Rai said citizens should be proud as India is much ahead of even the likes of the US, where paper ballots are still used in elections. “This largest temple of democracy, this country of ours is far ahead of the rest,” Rai said, appealing to youngsters to register their names on the electoral rolls.

State election commissioner R K Srivastava said that besides being the largest democracy, India also has advanced electoral processes. “Many of our election related officials, including CEOs, are called upon by many other countries as independent election observers. This speaks volumes about the credibility we have achieved,” Srivastava said.

Election officials have also been engaged in training various election related officials abroad, he said.

Title: EPCA: Full genset ban in NCR next winter
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: Next winter, use of diesel generator (DG) sets will not be allowed in Noida, Ghaziabad and Greater Noida in Uttar Pradesh and Faridabad, Gurugram and Manesar in Haryana. This was decided in a meeting of the Supreme Court-appointed Environment Pollution (Prevention & Control) Authority ( EPCA ) with the authorities of the NCR states.

“We won’t allow anyone to use diesel generator sets in industrial as well as residential areas. We need to work with the authorities and industries department to decide the plan of action to ensure the ban is implemented,” EPCA chief Bhure Lal said, adding that he will meet Haryana and UP power agencies on January 30 to discuss the issue.

During the recent EPCA meeting, it was also debated on whether solar energy or gas-based generators could be used instead of the polluting DG sets. “Why can’t these industries be asked to use solar? Come back with an action plan,” panel member Sunita Narain told the authorities of UP and Haryana.

Officials said that solar battery backup for this magnitude of power requirement was not available for want of enough storage capacity. Some Haryana societies were using gas-based generators but supply across the whole of NCR still remained an issue.

“Priority is to get people off generators,” Narain said.

The UP and Haryana power authorities also submitted to the SC-appointed panel the current status of DG sets in the major towns and the action being taken by them. 2019 was the first time that a blanket ban on diesel generators had been announced in Ghaziabad, Noida, Greater Noida, Faridabad, Gurugram, Sonipat, Panipat and Bahadurgarh, apart from Delhi, during the winter pollution cycle. In the previous years, areas outside Delhi were exempted from the ban, which was first implemented in 2017, on account of poor power supply infrastructure.

Only gensets used for emergency and essential services, such as hospitals, and metro stations, are excluded from the ban. However, due to erratic power supply and lack of connection in some areas, it couldn’t be implemented in the NCR towns.

Many residential colonies and commercial establishments in NCR were given occupancy certificates without connecting them to the regular power supply.

Title: Irrigation scam IO gets Prez medal
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nagpur: DySP Milind Totre, posted at State Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB), Nagpur, will be presented Indian Police Medal for meritorious service on the Republic Day. He is also the investigation officer in the irrigation scam.

Totre, an officer of 1989-batch and a recipient of over 200 rewards, has probed several highly sensitive cases including Pintu Shirke murder. He had also served at the Atari border check post for the immigration department and spent several years in intelligence service.

Also, Chandrapur SP Maheshwar Reddy has been awarded the Indian Police Medal for gallantry along with nine others including SDPO Sameersingh Salve and API Mithu Jagdale for their services in Maoist-affected Gadchiroli.

Reddy had led the operation in Koparchi in sensitive Maharashtra-Chhattisgarh border in 2017 when the deputy commander of Maoists was killed.

In Nagpur city, ASI Battulal Pandey of crime branch too has been selected for Indian Police Medal for meritorious services.

Head constable Satish Ingle, Railway Protection Services (RPF), South East Central Railway (SECR), too has been honoured with the Indian Police Medal for meritorious service. He is posted at Kamptee outpost.

Title: Traffic drive in Futala ahead of Republic Day
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur city traffic police on Saturday penalized 21 two-wheeler riders — most of them youngsters — for driving on the wrong side and modifying silencers of their vehicles.

Led by deputy commissioner of police (traffic) Chinmay Pandit, traffic police personnel undertook the drive in and around Futala lake where motorists, especially two-wheeler riders, indulge in hooliganism every year in the run up to, and on Republic Day .

Pandit appealed to Nagpurians to not indulge in rash and negligent driving during Republic Day celebrations. He said that those caught flouting traffic rules and causing traffic nuisance will face action under the relevant sections of Motor Vehicles Act. “We will also detain vehicles of such errant motorists,” warned senior police inspector Jayesh Bhandarkar.

Since January 16, the police have booked 216 people for using fancy number plates and have penalized 129 two-wheeler riders for modifying silencers of bikes.

Title: Govt ‘conspiring’ to end our movement, kill us, allege Matri Sadan seers
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

dsdsd

Dehradun: Seers of Matri Sadan in Haridwar have expressed apprehension of a conspiracy by the state government to end the ongoing fast-unto-death by its woman seer Padmavati by using force and a possible attempt to kill her as well as the ashram chief Swami Shivanand Saraswati.

In an application given to Haridwar chief judicial magistrate (CJM) under CRPC’s section 39 clause 5, (which gives the public right to give information of certain offences), Brahmachari Dayanand of Matri Sadan claimed that two of its earlier seers – prof GD Agrawal and Swami Nigamanand – were “killed” in similar manners.

Haridwar SSP Senthil Abudai said, “As of now we are totally unaware of any such application from Matri Sadan to CJM. It would be inappropriate to comment on the matter without getting all details.”

Demanding the government act on its promises to clean and save the Ganga, 86-year-old IIT professor GD Agrawal, who was also a seer of Matri Sadan, had died on October 11, 2018, at AIIMS Rishikesh after fasting for 111 days. Swami Nigamanand, who went on a hunger strike on February 19, 2011 to save the river from pollution caused by illegal mining in the river bed, died on June 13 after fasting for 115 days. He was just 34.

At a press conference called at their ashram in Haridwar, Matri Sadan chief Swami Shivanand Saraswati said he had come to know of the plan through reliable sources.

Recently, Bihar water resource minister Sanjay Jha had also visited Matri Sadan showcasing support to woman seer Padmavati who hails from Bihar.

Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar had written to Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeking his intervention in meeting the demands of the seer “who is risking her life to save the Ganga”.

Padmavati, who hails from Nalanda district, has been fasting for 41 days.

Title: Task force rescues 9 child labourers from hotels, shops
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Uttarkashi: A district-level task force led by district magistrate Ashish Chauhan rescued nine child labourers from several hotels and shops in the city. The crackdown on commercial establishments was conducted under a two-day campaign (which ended on Friday) against child labour. During the drive, two hotel owners were also booked under Child Labour Act for recruiting children below 14 years of age. SS Rangar, district labour enforcement officer, told TOI, “We have rescued nine child labourers and have served notices to the owners of eight hotels and shops where child labours were found. Besides this, we have also lodged an FIR in the matter. A penalty of Rs 20,000 was imposed on two hotel owners who had employed children below 14 years of age.”

The official added that the task force will also launch a similar drive in other parts of the district.

Title: CIC fines U’khand forest dept for not providing info sought under RTI
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Dehradun: Chief Information Commissioner Shatrughan Singh has slapped a fine of Rs 5,000 on Public Information Officer (PIO) of the Uttarakhand forest department for not providing information sought under the RTI Act by a Haridwar-based social activist.

The CIC had passed the order on January 22. Speaking to TOI, the activist, Vinod Jain, said, “Last year, I had submitted evidence of financial irregularities committed in the cactus garden at the Dehradun zoo. Following which, I filed an RTI seeking details of the investigation but the forest department did not reply to my RTI for a year.”

The project was launched in the zoo in 2018 and Jain alleged that no tenders were given for the work that was worth over Rs 50 lakh.

“Through an RTI, I first found the exact money spent on the entire project, including building and procurement of cacti by the forest department. As per the information, Rs 10.65 lakh was spent on building the shed for the cactus garden, Rs 16.64 lakh was spent on buying cactus and succulent plants for the projects while Rs 12 lakh was used in other related work,” Jain said.

He added that “it came as a big surprise that no tender was invited for all these works in the zoo.” “I submitted all evidence to the forest department along with my affidavit. However, when I filed the RTI to know the follow-up action, the forest department did not give any details.”

In the CIC hearing, the PIO submitted that on May 13, 2019, the RTI application was received and on June 12, 2019, he was informed that the investigation is underway and after completion of the investigation he would be informed about the outcome.

During the hearing, when the PIO was asked if he would furnish any document such as a postal stamp or receipt to buttress his claim that a reply was posted, the PIO admitted that he had no evidence. The CIC then passed the order of Rs 5,000 fine to the PIO and instructed to provide all the details related to the RTI to the applicant within a stipulated time.

Even after repeated attempts by TOI, the PIO and senior forest department officials didn’t comment on the CIC order and reason for not responding to Jain’s RTI.

Title: Goa must identify wetlands by January 2021
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

The green body had pulled up the government authorities for ‘abdicating their responsibility’ in identifying w... Read More

PANAJI: The National Green Tribunal (NGT) has directed the state government to complete the process of identification of wetlands in the state by January 2021. Further, it has asked for a progress report to be submitted on a quarterly basis.

The state government had requested NGT for a one-year extension to identify the wetlands in the state.

Speaking to TOI, advocate general Devidas Pangam said, “NGT has given us a year to identify these wetlands.”

In an affidavit, the state government told NGT that work towards implementing the Wetland (Conservation and Management) Rules, 2017, has already commenced and that various committees have been constituted under the Goa State Wetland Authority (GSWA). Further, the government said the process of compiling information pertaining to pre-existing rights involves interaction with the local people which includes owners, tenants and other stakeholders.

The government also said that it is pertinent to note that unlike in other states, in the dry season, most wetlands in the state are utilised for agriculture and are temporary wetlands which support the extant flora and fauna including migratory birds while the water is used for various purposes downstream. Hence, this facultative system is unique to Goa and requires considerable amount of time for preparation of brief document, stakeholder consultations, enlisting ecosystem services and finding pre-existing rights in a definitive manner, it said.

“Accordingly, a decision was taken to appoint CSIR-NIO to complete the identification of the wetlands on account of their credentials which are beyond any doubt of integrity and it was of bonafide belief and understanding of GSWA that the Rules permit appointment of expert authorities for identification of wetlands,” the government said

NGT had pulled up government authorities for “abdicating their responsibility” in identifying wetlands in the state and had questioned the rationale behind engaging NIO for the task. “We get the distinct impression that the regulatory authorities in the state like the wetland authority, biodiversity and environment department are abdicating their responsibilities,” NGT had said.

Title: Kerala will get a new curriculum: CM
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan

PALAKKAD: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan has said that the state will implement a curriculum that is in tune with the times and guarantees employment and promotes entrepreneurship.

Inaugurating a super and mini version of fab labs and a startup incubator at Government Polytechnic College at Kanjikode on Saturday, the CM said: “We need to equip students with resources that enable them to meet global challenges of the new age. For that, they must get learning facilities of international standards and academic assignments of futuristic use.”

With this, the statewide networks of 20 fab labs were establishments that develop technical prototyping platforms for design fabrication technology.

Vijayan said that the Super Fab Lab he had opened with a remote will function at the Integrated Startup Complex (ISC) of the Kerala Startup Mission (KSUM) at Kalamassery is the world’s first such facility to function outside the US and is operated in collaboration with Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

“It will give India’s hardware industry a huge leap by allowing researchers, innovators and developers to do things beyond the purview of the state’s existing fab labs,” the CM said.

Vijayan pointed out: “The startup ecosystem is making giant strides across continents and in Kerala we are making big progress in the field of electronic hardware.”

Presiding over the meeting, water resources minister K Krishnankutty said that ‘precision farming’ can be one of the new subjects that can be introduced into the syllabus on technology.

Title: Polio vaccinators taken for NPR surveyor in UP, beaten and held hostage
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: A three-member team for administering polio drops was allegedly thrashed and held hostage after local residents mistook them for the National Population Register (NPR) data collection team. The incident occurred at Lisari Gate locality on Saturday. However, two of them, including a staff nurse, managed to free themselves and complained to police.

Lisari Gate station officer Prashant Kapil said, “We have received the complaint from the medical team and we are in the process of filing an FIR against the culprits for stopping public servants from performing their duty. This is not the first time that such an incident has happened in the area.”

According to one of victims Kabir Ahmad Khan, who is an officer of the immunization programme, “The incident occurred in Lakhipura locality of Lisari Gate area where a family opposed the administration of polio drops. As per rule, we have to enter the name of the non-consenting parents in the tally (yellow) register. The moment we asked their names, there was a strong protest and within no time, we were surrounded by a mob. We tried to explain them the purpose of our visit. We even showed them the vaccine box and our IDs, but they didn't listen to us and even manhandled one of our team members. They tore away the register and the local women even held hostage a woman staffer in our team. Later, senior staff along with the WHO field monitors also reached the spot and again tried to explain things to them.”

Khan said, “The NPR-NRC anxiety among them is obviously the main issue because one of the youths in the mob even told people not to reveal any details to us because he suspected we were the NPR data collectors . Ever since this issue came up, we have been facing very tough resistance from the local residents. But this time, they turned violent.”

Title: NGT slams UP govt for ignoring its order to notify Sanctuary
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Meerut: A day after TOI reported the intervention of MoEF asking UP government to notify Hastinapur Sanctuary, National Green Tribunal has in a strong worded order reprimanded the state government for having "not cared to comply with order of Tribunal despite of ample time having been given to them and they are still not taking steps for compliance of the order of the Tribunal."

Though the order came in a hearing on Friday but it was uploaded on NGT website on Saturday morning.

The two-judge bench of Justice Raghuvendra Rathore and Satyender Singh Garbyal got irked by request of the respondents' counsel seeking more time to implement May 2019 order.

Reprimanding the state officials, it said, "To our surprise, further time is being sought on behalf of the respondent to file reply to the execution application, what to say of filing the compliance report. It is clear case where officer of the State government has not cared to comply with order of Tribunal despite of ample time having been given to them."

The court mentioned about the MeEF letter to state government asking for notification that TOI has covered.

"We have also been informed by the Counsel for MoEF&CC that they have also reminded the State Government for doing the needful i.e. to issue Notification under the Wildlife Protection Act", the Tribunal observed.

Now Tribunal has given another 10 days time for compliance.

"In the aforesaid circumstances and in the interest of justice, 10 days time to respondents no. 6 and 7 ((Principal Secretary Forest and Wildlife and Principal Chief Conservator of Forest, UP Government) i.e. by 03.02.2020 for filing the status/compliance report, failing which respondents no. 6 and 7 shall remain present before the Tribunal on the next date of hearing."

In 1986, the government had issued a primary notification declaring Hastinapur forest area a sanctuary. However, no final government order notifying the 2,073 square-km area a protected zone has come from the government since then. Irked over it, the NGT had last year in May asked the forest department to explain to it the reason behind over 30 years of delay in proclaiming Hastinapur wildlife area as a protected sanctuary.

It gave six months to follow the order. Then, on December 18 last year, the NGT issued contempt cum execution notices to Union Ministry of Environment and Forest, UP government and others over non-implementation of its earlier order.

Title: Delhi: Yamuna immersion banned, no plan for Saraswati idols
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Idols made of PoP and plastic are insoluble and form a layer like concrete on the waterbed, not allowing groun... Read More

NEW DELHI: With Saraswati Puja coming up on Wednesday, many city residents have a unique worry. Where to immerse the idols ?

Last year, city authorities had stopped immersion of idols in the Yamuna and created artificial ponds all over the city for eco-friendly visarjan. Saraswati Puja, which coincides with Basant Panchami, is popular in Bengal, Odisha, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh, and is performed for a single day, however, is held on a much smaller scale in the city and there is no such preparation for it.

PK Pal of East Bengal Displaced Persons (EBDP) Association, an umbrella body for residents of CR Park, said no arrangements have been made by any authorities for artificial ponds. “We will go to Kalindi Kunj as some ponds are there. However, many others will immerse the idols in the river. As it is a smaller festival, authorities took no initiative,” Pal said.

According to Delhi Pollution Control Committee (DPCC), no preparations have been done in terms of keeping vigil at city ghats or preparing artificial ponds for the upcoming festival. “However, devotees can immerse clay idols with natural, biodegradable paint. No plastic or plaster of Paris (PoP) idols are allowed,” a DPCC official said.

Idols made of PoP and plastic are insoluble and form a layer like concrete on the waterbed, not allowing groundwater to recharge.

“Pollution of waterbodies due to immersion of PoP idols is a matter of concern . In addition to silting, toxic chemicals used in making idols tend to leach out and pose serious problems,” he said.

In the last festive season in 2019, there were 116 artificial ponds for idol immersion during Ganesh Chaturthi and 89 artificial ponds for Durga Pooja, to avoid immersion in Yamuna. “Due to the non-immersion of idols in the Yamuna, the quality of river water showed an improvement,” said a Delhi government official.

According to the NGT-appointed Yamuna monitoring committee, neither any directions have been issued on this particular puja immersion nor did the green court have mentioned anything about it in its order. “On principle, people should not pollute the river. We will put in our forthcoming report that other than the Ganesh and Durga festivals there are many community-based events like Saraswati Puja. DMs and environment and forest department may be directed to see that the river isn’t allowed to be made a receptacle. All bridges should have receptacles for such itinerant puja material which should be disposed of in a way that satisfies the larger community and undertaken by NGOs,” an monitoring committee member said.

According to another expert, the authorities, from next year, should make arrangements in localities for smaller festivals, too, so that no immersion takes place in the river and like in Ganesh and Durga Puja people have options for eco-friendly visarjan.

Title: Ganga Barrage looks crystal clear ahead of Yogi visit to flag off yatra
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Bijnor: Preparations for Ganga Yatra are in full swing here ahead of CM Yogi Adityanath’s visit on Monday, when he will flag off the journey. Bijnor is the first district in UP where the sacred river enters the state at Sabalgarh village. The yatra will end on January 31 in Kanpur.

Yogi will also address a public meeting at Ganga Barrage. A podium has being erected on the river bank. Experts are busy in preparing a helipad nearby where CM’s chopper will land. Initially, Yogi was to inaugurate the yatra at Sabalgarh village.

Meanwhile, all encroachers have been served notices to remove their stalls along the banks.

In a bid to clean up the river, the irrigation department has weeded out water hyacinths and dredged out all waste floating in the water. For a change, the river water appears to be crystal clear.

The banks have been decorated with paintings.

Hundreds of people are expected to participate in the programme. Tight security will be in place both on the ground and over the Ganga. Drones will be deployed to keep vigil. City’s superintendent of police Lakshmi Nivas Mishra said, “The entire area where the programme will be held will be cordoned off. No traffic will be allowed on Delhi Pauri national highway for one and a half hour while the CM is in the Barrage area.”

Around 22 additional SPs and circle officers, 50 SHOs, 300 sub-inspectors and 1,200 police and PAC personnel will be deployed in security zone. Additional force from districts in Bareilly zone have been called. Besides, fivc drones and 10 boats have been arranged to keep a vigil in the area, Mishra added.

According to district panchayat raj officer Satish Kumar, “State ministers, MPs and MLAs will spend the nights at villages during the five-day yatra and make villagers aware about the importance of this holy river. Besides development and sanitation schemes will be reviewed at these villages.”

Schools, anganwadi centres and panchayat buildings have been painted with slogans based on the Ganga and sanitation, Kumar added.

Bijnor district magistrate, Ramakant Pandey, on Friday, flagged off three LED vans to spread the message of Ganga Yatra in the district. These LED vans will also broadcast live Yogi’s programmes at different places.

Ganga passes through 26 districts in UP comprising 21 civic bodies and 1,026 village panchayats. It will end on January 31 in Kanpur.

Title: Facelift of choked Hapur road crossing caught in red tape
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Meerut: Hapur road, one of the most congested crossings in the city, will have to wait for its facelift as the project for beautification has been caught in an indefinite delay due to overlapping projects and lack of coordination between the government agencies, sources said.

A team of senior officials led by district magistrate Anil Dhingra, Meerut Development Authority (MDA) vice-chairman Rajesh Kumar Pandey and municipal commissioner Manoj Kumar had visited the spot in the last week of November, last year, and had claimed that the redesigning work will begin by first week of December.

But, it has been over two months past the stipulated time when the project was supposed to kickstart, but nothing happened on ground.

According to senior officials, the agency which is tasked with preparing the detailed project report had pegged the estimated cost of the project at Rs 5 crore which was earlier claimed to be 70 lakh when the project was mooted. “The agency which has prepared the report has estimated the project cost at Rs 5 crore. We are trying to curtail it,” MDA VC Pandey said.

Hapur road crossing is one of the areas in the city that witnesses maximum vehicular traffic. The heavy influx of vehicular traffic comes from Garh road, Hapur and several main arterial roads. The defunct traffic signals at the crossing add to the chaos as a handful of traffic constables try to hold the fort, especially during rush hours.

“Another reason of the delay is that the crossing also features in smart city project. The redesigning of crossing would have been done but the roads that lead to the crossing are not in good shape. Public work department has now taken up revamp of both roads and crossing,” MDA VC Pandey said, adding, “The project is ready and will soon get rid of all delays.”

Title: Koraput: Crocodiles presence in village triggers panic
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

One of the crocodiles basking in the sun near a pond in Bagderi village in Koraput district

KORAPUT: Villagers of Bagderi in Koraput’s Kundura block are living in fear as two crocodiles from the village pond have been venturing into the village in search of food for the past four days.

According to the villagers, the crocodiles move out of the pond between 1 pm and 2 pm and at night in search of food. Though the critters have not attacked any villager, people have blamed the forest department for not paying heed to their problem.

“On Wednesday, we sighted a crocodile ambling towards the village and informed the forest department,” said Arjun Nayak , a villager. Villagers spotted a crocodile dead near the pond on Thursday morning. “The reptile had probably died after being hit by some vehicle on Wednesday night. We are panicky now,” he added.

Villagers said children fear going to school because it is situated just 50 metres from the pond and the possibility of the crocodile venturing inside the school campus cannot be be ruled out. “Though we have informed the forest officials, little has been done to contain the crocodiles,” said Anant Majhi , another villager.

However, forest officials said the situation is being closely monitored and necessary steps are being taken to ensure that the crocodiles do not harm any villager. “During the winter, sometimes crocodiles come out to bask in the sun and we have deployed two of our staffs near the pond. Steps are being taken to protect the villagers,” said N P J Singh, divisional forest officer, Jeypore. Admitting that a crocodile has died after being hit by some unknown vehicle, the officer said a case of unnatural death has been registered and investigation is on.

Title: Again, Shirgao locals block ore transportation
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

BICHOLIM: Shirgao residents on Saturday again halted transportation of iron ore through the village. They demanded that mining company first pay their water bills of the last two years.

The residents had stopped transportation of the e-auctioned ore on Monday to protest the failure of the mining companies to pay their pending water bills, but Bicholim deputy collector Sachin Desai had called a special meeting and requested them to allow ore transportation, while assuring them that the mining company would clear the bills. The residents had agreed to the deputy collector’s request and transportation was allowed.

When the residents sought a copy of the minutes of the meeting at the deputy collector’s office on Friday, they found that the said resolution had not been passed. Following that, the irate villagers blocked the ore transportation on Saturday.

Shirgao deputy sarpanch Vijaya Mandrekar said that they won’t allow transportation of ore unless their water bills are paid.

Title: Tenali tense after YSRC workers throw eggs at ex-MLA Alapati
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Vijayawada: Tension prevailed at Tenali town in Guntur district on Saturday after YSRC workers hurled eggs and tomatoes at former MLA Alapati Rajendra Prasad and others, who were on a relay fast in support of Amaravati as state capital.

Two youths identified as Chunduru Gopi and Vadeswarapu Anish allegedly set on fire the tent of pro-Amaravati protesters.

However, a major mishap was averted as the alert protesters doused the fire in time even as part of the tent was burnt.

Tenali deputy superintendent of police Srilakshmi told TOI the police will register cases against the attackers after receiving a complaint.

She said once normalcy is restored in the town, police will initiate action against the persons involved.

People, who are in support of Amaravati, were staging protests ever since the capital shift announcement was made by the chief minister in the state assembly. Protesters under the banner of Amaravati Parirakshana Joint Action Committee have been sitting on fast at the protest venue near Tenali municipal office.

Title: Kala Academy’s open-air auditorium can be repaired, says expert
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Multiple layers of waterproofing has led to a dead load, the expert said

PANAJI: There is no need for Kala Academy’s open-air auditorium to be demolished, it can be repaired, IIT-Madras professor Radhakrisha Pillai said.

Pillai recently carried out an inspection of Kala Academy, following which a meeting was held on the institution’s structural audit. Based on reports by Goa Engineering College (GEC) and Mumbai-based consultancy firm GEM Engserv Pvt Ltd, he ascertained that the primary issue was that of multiple layers of waterproofing, which has led to a dead load.

At the meeting, Pillai spoke about using the cathodic protection technology to arrest further deterioration of steel. Though expensive, the technology works on the principle of electric current, by making the steel bars act as cathodes and uses zinc metal as anodes.
