This prevents steel from developing additional rust.

Pillai said this technology has been previously adopted in India and has proven to last for over 40 years. The only maintenance needed is that the zinc plates must be changed every 15-20 years, but this is a non-invasive and non-destructive maintenance measure, he said.

KG Guptha, who represented GEC at the meeting, said that in some cases there was over 80% corrosion. Pillai said such spots can be strengthened using measures such as retrofitting.

Guptha suggested the removal of the undesirable dead load from the waterproofing. He also said that to protect it from the rain, the open-air auditorium could be covered with tarpaulin sheets, like it was done in 2019.

Pillai said the National Centre for Safety of Heritage Structures (NCSHS) is willing to take up necessary works, with cooperation from the state government.

Members of the Charles Correa Foundation (CCF) requested KA (then) member secretary Gurudas Pilarenkar to appoint consultants from NCSHS. After deliberation, CCF resolved to give a proposal to take up work along with NCSHS by February 1. Pillai will give a report with a suggested repair methodology by February 29, after discussion with NCSHS coordinator Arun Menon.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Immigration told to check people coming from China
Content:
Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Following the Union health ministry’s directive to display advisory on coronavirus at 12 airports across the country, including Vizag, the Airports Authority of India (AAI) has issued a circular to immigration officials at the city airport to keep a strict vigil on passengers originating from China.“We have been asked to check all passengers arriving from any Chinese city for flu-like symptoms, like cold and cough. Such passengers won’t be allowed to enter the city till he or she gets the all-clear from health department officials. The airport director will also be informed,” an immigration official told TOI.Screening facilities have already been set up at major airports across the country including Delhi, Mumbai, Chennai, Hyderabad and Kolkata. Though there are no direct flights from China to the city, passengers often come to Vizag from Chinese cities via Singapore and Malaysia. Scoot Air connects Visakhapatnam and Singapore thrice a week, while Air Asia operates another thrice-a-week flight to Malaysia.“We have full details of both foreign and Indian passengers. So it won’t be a difficult task for us to trace the origin location of a passenger. However, it would have been better if they appoint a medical officer at the airport to check whether the passenger is suffering from cold and cough,” the immigration official added.In 2018-19, around 800 passengers came to Visakhapatnam from China or flew to China from the city, as per immigration department data.

Title: Women take to streets against CAA, NRC in Sambhal
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representational Image

BAREILLY: Over 100 women, who have been protesting against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the proposed National Register of Citizens in Sambhal , continued their sit-in on Saturday as well.

Terming CAA and NRC “undemocratic” and “anti-Muslim”, the women protesting at Pakka Bag Kheda in Nakhasa area raised slogans such as “hum leke rahenge azadi, CAA se azadi”, “RSS se azadi”, “Gandhi wali azadi”, demanding rollback of the law.

Local MP Shafiqur Rahman Barq, who visited the protesters, said that they would hoist the tricolour on Republic Day.

Extending his support to the women, Barq said, “The government wants to make Muslims second class citizens.” The SP leader said his party would raise the matter in Parliament.

On Saturday, women members of local MLA Iqbal Mahmood’s family joined the dharna.

Since the sit-in began, local intelligence unit and police department have been keeping a close tab on the protesters and people supporting them.

Barq said the sit-in would continue until the Centre withdraws CAA.

Title: Goa: Government primary schools to be given bilingual books
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The All Goa Government Recognised Unaided Schools Association (AGGRUSA) will distribute Konkani-to-English textbooks to government primary schools to help improve the English skills of students, the association’s secretary Vijay Shetti said. Every private school will contribute some sets of books , he said.

“The books have been prepared by a Mangaluru-based organisation. The picture-based books will help students learn words from Konkani to English. In most government schools, the English level of students needs drastic improvement. We hope these books help serve this purpose,” he said.

Since its formation in 2008, AGGRUSA has helped to draw the attention of the state government to private schools. Shetti, however, said there is still scope for better integration of private schools in Goa with the mainstream.

Title: Drunk driver creates traffic chaos
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Jaipur: Traffic jam and chaos witnessed on Saturday when a RSRTC bus entered in the wrong direction on one-way Vanasthali Road in the city. The driver was reported to be driving under the influence of alcohol. The police seized the bus and licence of the driver. According to ASI (traffic police) Bihari Lal, Vanasthali Road connects with Sindhi Camp and Sansar Chand Road. “The alcohol level of the driver was 147 mg of per 100 ml of blood. The bus was coming from Sikar and had 15 passengers.” tnn

Title: Tight security in Jaipur for Republic Day
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Cops review security measures at SMS Stadium on Saturday

JAIPUR: On the occasion of Republic Day , police has taken various measures to prevent any untoward incidents on Sunday with approximately 1,500 police personnel to be deployed in the city.

With a general alert being issued, cops will be keeping a constant vigil across the city and state.

Ajay Pal Lamba, Additional Commissioner of Police told TOI, “We are taking adequate measures to ensure that the Republic Day celebrations go unhindered. Four DCP rank officials will be monitoring the law and order situation and in each district there will be four Quick Reaction Team (QRT). Also for the main function at the SMS stadium, four QRTs each on all sides along with one emergency response team (ERT) will be deployed. Over 1,000 police personnel will be stationed across Jaipur.”

Additionally, to prevent any terrorist activity, a team of Anti-Terrorist Squad (ATS) will also be deployed.

Plainclothesmen will be stationed inside the parking areas as well as in the stadium. A constant watch will also be kept using CCTV cameras. “There a general alert issued though we do not have any specific information about any untoward situation. We will maintain a vigil and forces will be present at historical structures. Certain protocols which are followed on these days will be followed now as well”, said Umesh Mishra, ADG, Intelligence

CM Ashok Gehlot will also be present in multiple events for Republic Day including the one at SMS stadium. He will also hoist the flag at his official residence as pay his respects at Amar Jawan Jyoti.

Governor Kalraj Mishra will also be part of these celebrations and will hoist the flag at SMS stadium on Sunday morning.

Title: Women take to streets against CAA, NRC in Sambhal
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Bareilly: Over 100 women, who have been protesting against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the proposed National Register of Citizens in Sambhal, continued their sit-in on Saturday as well.

Terming CAA and NRC “undemocratic” and “anti-Muslim”, the women protesting at Pakka Bag Kheda in Nakhasa area raised slogans such as “hum leke rahenge azadi, CAA se azadi”, “RSS se azadi”, “Gandhi wali azadi”, demanding rollback of the law.

Local MP Shafiqur Rahman Barq, who visited the protesters, said that they would hoist the tricolour on Republic Day.

Extending his support to the women, Barq said, “The government wants to make Muslims second class citizens.” The SP leader said his party would raise the matter in Parliament.

On Saturday, women members of local MLA Iqbal Mahmood’s family joined the dharna.

Since the sit-in began, local intelligence unit and police department have been keeping a close tab on the protesters and people supporting them.

Barq said the sit-in would continue until the Centre withdraws CAA.

Title: Robbers rob family after taking them hostage at home
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Bareilly: A gang of thieves targeted a businessman’s house at Devmania village in Mitauli area of Lakhimpur Kheri district and robbed the family by taking them hostage at gunpoint on the intervening night of Friday and Saturday. Then gang comprising some six men decamped with cash and jewellery valued at Rs 3 lakh from the house.

Police are investigating the robbery and a team of forensic experts arrived on Saturday to collect evidence.

In his complaint, businessman Ranjeet Kumar said the family was sleeping when some armed robbers forced their way into his house and took all of them hostage at gunpoint. He alleged they thrashed all the women in the family and forced them to handover all the cash and jewellery. After spending nearly 30 minutes in the house, the robbers left with Rs 22,000 in cash and jewellery.

Before leaving , they locked all the members of the family in a room to prevent them from informing police or alerting villagers.

Anil Kumar, SHO of Mitauli police station, said, “We have filed an FIR against the unidentified robbers and we are trying to identify whether its the same gang that had committed robberies in other parts of the district. The accused will soon be arrested.”

Title: APATA meets airline officials
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Members of Andhra Pradesh Air Travellers’ Association ( APATA ) met SpiceJet CEO Sanjiv Gupta, SGM (operations) Rajesh H Singh and SGM (cargo sales) Sanjeev Sharma at the city airport on Saturday. Airport director Raja Kishore was also present at the meeting.

The purpose of the meat was to facilitate dedicated cargo flights from Visakhapatnam. APATA members told officials that there is huge potential in sea foods and pharmaceuticals from Visakhapatnam.

SpiceJet has already agreed to start more cargo liners from the city. The SpiceJet CEO requested MP MVV Satyanarayana to help get required permissions as they plan to start operations from February 15. tnn

Title: Delhi: Fog expected on Republic Day morning, rain likely on Tuesday
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

On Sunday partly cloudy sky is expected with moderate fog (File photo)

NEW DELHI: It was a chilly morning in the city with the minimum temperature dipping to 4.8 degrees Celsius , three notches below normal.

“The maximum temperature was recorded 21.4 degrees Celsius, a point below normal,” a MeT official said. He said that a fresh and active western disturbance was very likely to affect Western Himalayan region from Monday night onwards, in Punjab, Haryana and Rajasthan. “It may cause rain in Delhi-NCR on Tuesday. On Wednesday, too, light rain or drizzle could be expected in some parts of the city.”

Track the pollution level in your city

On Republic Day on Sunday, partly cloudy sky is expected with moderate fog — dense at isolated places — in the morning. The maximum and minimum temperatures would be around 22 and 7 degrees Celsius respectively.

“Delhi would witness moderate fog while some places in NCR may see heavy fog,” the official said.

The air quality, however, worsened from 151 — in the moderate category — on Friday, to 250 (poor) on Saturday.

An AQI between 0-50 is considered ‘good’, 51-100 ‘satisfactory’, 101-200 ‘moderate’, between 201 and 300 is classified as ‘poor’, between 301 and 400 is classified as ‘very poor’ and between 401 and 500 is ‘severe’ on the Central Pollution Control Board’s index.

Data according to Central Pollution Control Board’s central control room showed Delhi NCR’s average PM2.5 levels recorded at 118.6 micrograms per cubic metre at 7pm on Saturday. The average PM10 levels, at the same time also above the safe standards, were recorded at 213.8 micrograms per cubic metre, data showed. The ‘emergency’ benchmark for these pollutants under GRAP is, respectively, 300 and 500 micrograms per cubic metre while the safe standards are 60 and 100 micrograms per cubic metre.

MeT officials said the wind speed, which was 20-25km per hour on Friday, dipped to 10km per hour on Saturday and caused the air quality to worsen.

According to SAFAR, the AQI may deteriorate to the ‘very poor’ category by Sunday. “A fresh western disturbance is likely to bring marginal improvement in AQI from Monday onwards,” a SAFAR report stated.

Title: What should be done to ensure commuters are not inconvenienced?
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

With roads closure being implemented in Secunderabad Cantonment ahead of Republic Day, TOI asked readers about what they felt about such restrictions.

Though we welcome the decision of restrictions on the movement on defence roads in the interest of country's security, MoD should make alternate arrangements so that senior citizens and women do not suffer. People have to travel additional distances, especially at night. Did the MoD verify if the alternate roads are safe for late-night commute? The government needs to ensure that all the roads in the city are well-lit and under CCTV surveillance. Safety of citizens should also be taken into consideration.

- Dr GV Kumar

The areas that are curbed for civilian movements connect Bolarum and adjoining areas such as Sainikpuri, Neredmet, Kowkoor to the rest of the city. The arterial roads connecting one end of the city with the rest should not be closed on such short notice. A simple detour also amounts to large investment of time, fuel and effort. Instead of closing all the four arterial roads, they must open at least one, especially for working men, women and students. The alert being declared is always welcome in light of national security. But instead of blocking the roads completely, personnel must be deployed to check the ids of the commuters who are using the route that have been placed under alert.

- Deepesh Surana

While it is understandable that the certain roads may need to be closed due to high alert, it is baffling that the announcement is made on the day of the closure. I am sure the MoD must have understood the need to declare a high-alert situation in lieu of Republic Day well in advance. So then why are Cantonment authorities not informing citizens about road-closure at least a week before the implementation? This would not only help citizens plan accordingly for the days ahead, it would also give LMA the time to provide a list of alternate routes for commuters. The need to block certain roads in the interest of national security is understandable, but authorities must keep commuters abreast of the situation.

- Vidya Raju

While roads closures are not a new phenomenon in Cantonment areas, we must ask why we prefer these roads to the other city roads. Cantonment roads are considered to be safer for women due to the round-the-clock patrolling. The same level of security must also be extended to other roads in the city. The detour amounting to nearly 8kms can be made more comfortable by construction of fly-overs in appropriate places. Better urban planning is pertinent to avoid people facing inconvenience over the closure of a few roads.

- Nikhil Singh

Title: World Wetland Day celebration on Feb 1
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Panaji: The Goa State Wetland Authority (GSWA) will celebrate ‘World Wetlands Day’ on February 1 at the National Institute of Oceanography, Dona Paula. This year’s theme is ‘wetlands and biodiversity’. Minister of environment and GSWA chairperson Nilesh Cabral will be the chief guest. Mumbai-based limnologist Dr Pramod Salaskar will present his case study on the Powai lake.

As part of the celebrations, a host of competitions including essay writing, photography and poster making for differently-abled, will be held .

Entries for all the competitions must be submitted to the GSWA office on or before January 30.

The results of the competitions will be announced at the February 1 function. TNN

Title: Telugus in China want to send families back
Content: Visakhapatnam: Following the outbreak of coronavirus in China, panic has gripped the Indian community there, with most of them planning to send their families back home as soon as possible.There are also many people from the two Telugu states working in China, most of them in the IT sector. “Apprehensions from my Chinese colleagues are that the situation might worsen by the end of the month once the Chinese New Year festival is over and locals start coming back to their homes. I cannot move out of the country but I want to send my family back to India,” V Saikiran, a software engineer from Hyderabad, told STOI. Saikiran is presently based in Shanghai with his wife and two kids.As per 2018 data of ministry of external affairs, there are around 55,000 Indians working in China, of which around 2,000 are from the two Telugu states. The Chinese government has already imposed a travel lockdown in the country after the outbreak. Till Saturday afternoon, 41 persons have succumbed to the deadly disease while around 1,300 have been diagnosed to have contracted the virus.“The Chinese government is taking all necessary measures. But still, we are under severe trauma. Until and unless it’s absolutely essential, we are not allowing our family members to move out of the house,” said K Pravakar Rao, who works in Beijing.Meanwhile, India’s consulate general offices in Beijing and Shanghai have issued an advisory to Indians staying in China to avoid going to crowded places, not take raw meat, eat more green vegetables and wear masks while going out. The advisory also specifies the necessary action Indian residents need to take in case of any emergency.

Title: Gujarat: BPA gets honour for making polls inclusive
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

The symbols for ‘EVM’ and ‘VVPAT’ for the speech and hearing impaired that were devised by BPA experts

AHMEDABAD: In the 2019 general election, about 60,000 persons with disabilities (PwD) from Gujarat voted in the festival of democracy. According to experts, this was one of the highest turnouts for PwDs, largely due to several initiatives that made voting booths accessible to wheelchairs and facilitated transport at several places.

The inclusion needed more than that push. Dr Bhushan Punani, executive secretary of city-based Blind People’s Association (BPA), said awareness about the voting process was equally important. “We realized while devising a strategy that there was no sign language for electronic voting machines (EVM) and the voter verifiable paper audit trail (VVPAT) unit. We devised symbols for these, along with the voting process, the inking of the finger and the casting of votes. This was utilized across the country to increase awareness,” he said.

This was an initiativs that won the BPA honours at the 10th National Voters’ Day, celebrated by the Election Commission of India (ECI) on Saturday. Dr Punani was among the 20 awardees at the function. He received the award on behalf of the organization from President Ram Nath Kovind , in the category of Civil Services Organization .

“Another initiative implemented in Gujarat was the audio electoral roll or ballot papers. Once candidates for all 26 seats were announced by the ECI, we recorded details such as index number, name and party’s symbol for each constituency and circulated it among election officers. It was later circulated to voters with disabilities,” said Punani. “What we did not realize then was the fact that it also helped inform voters without formal education who had to solely rely on party symbols.”

For the first time, all officers on election duty were trained to make the elections more inclusive, said ECI officials.

Title: Drivers glued to their phones emerge as road safety hazard
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The use of cell phones while driving is emerging as a major road safety issue. The number of fatal and non-fatal accidents due to using mobile phones while driving in Visakhapatnam is on a rise. Driving while using phones not only endangers drivers but also other people on the road.

The city traffic police have been issuing nearly 1,200 challans to motorists every day. Of all the challans, between 70 and 100 are related to motorists using their phones while driving.

Speaking to STOI, MRK Raju, ACP (traffic) said, “Despite our awareness campaigns, some young motorists continue to flout traffic rules by driving while speaking on their phones.”

A report by the ministry of road transport and highways showed that in 2018, 7 motorists died and 70 suffered injuries while they were using their phones while driving. Most of those who died were riding two-wheelers.

City police commissioner RK Meena said, “Using mobile phones is integral to modern life, however, using phones while driving is a dangerous trend as motorists lose control over their vehicle as well as their surroundings.”

As per the current laws, if a motorist is found speaking on the phone while driving, a fine of Rs 1,000 will be imposed on them. However, in the coming days, the fine will go up to Rs 5,000, said a senior police official of the traffic wing.

“We are examining CCTV footage at traffic signals in the city to find violators and issue traffic challans to instill fear among violators,” the official said while adding that the new Motor Vehicles Act prescribes steep fines and harsher punishments for traffic violators.

Title: Mumbai: Mixed response to 24x7 test drive at malls, but food courts attract many
Content:
Oberoi Mall, Goregaon, at 2.50am.

MUMBAI: Whether it was a tipsy reveller or someone returning from a late night shift in need of some post-movie feeding, several bleary-eyed shops and eateries at city malls remained open beyond midnight hours for people to browse and dine during the test drive of the 24x7 functioning permit on Friday night.The first day first show of shops and restaurants being allowed to remain open till 3am drew a lukewarm response though. Given the lack of awareness about the plan suddenly coming into force two days before the proposed date of the night hours of January 26-27, the footfalls were few and far between despite malls pulling out all the stops—security measures, new recruits, discounts and even open-air movie screenings for free.The late night trial run of food courts and eateries seems to have resolved the long- standing dilemma of late night hunger pangs though. Even if shops and restaurants stayed shut at several malls, food courts did a fine job.Take, for instance, teenage brothers Fahad, Shadab, Fahim and Zayed who live in Pathanwadi. They entered Oberoi Mall in Goregaon at 2.30am for a snack. “On weekends we hang out in the room playing games but this gives us an outlet to step out and experience something different,” said the brothers.Devasish, an event manager who had just gotten off duty at Shanmukhananda Hall in Sion, made a stop at Infiniti Mall in Andheri with his family of five on their way back home in Kandivli. “My entire family is involved in events work. We have uncertain hours and it usually gets late by the time a program is done and we find ourselves scrambling for dinner. When I heard the food court here was to remain open, I thought it was a safe environment for us to come and find something proper to eat. On other days we either have to depend on late night stalls or make do with whatever’s at home,” said Devasish, as he dug into a slice of pizza.But there were many who sauntered into food courts or shops in the afterhours on Friday as they were surprised to find shutters up.Although some pubs and eateries at malls such as Phoenix Market City in Kurla or R City in Ghatkopar were brimming till early hours, only select places stayed open for late night shopping. Dashrath Rathod, a resident of Borivli, for instance, was among the 15-odd people who walked into a lifestyle store at Oberoi Mall after midnight and spent at least an hour with his wife, son and daughter in retail therapy.Meanwhile, very few made their way into malls like Phoenix Market City in Kurla or R City in Ghatkopar late at night, while the food courts and shopping outlets despite the permission to stay open decided to down shutters by 2.45am.Of the three malls that TOI visited in South Mumbai between Colaba and Lower Parel, only one shop seemed to stay open till the early hours and was visited by three patrons, generating a business of about Rs 8,500.Malls in Bhandup and Mulund had put up shutters by 10.30pm while the food court at Galleria, a shopping complex in Powai’s Hiranandani area, shut business by around 1.30am. “It does not make sense to keep eateries open late into the night. This will increase expenses while good footfalls are hard to come by even during the day,” said the owner of an Asian restaurant at Galleria.While most people TOI spoke to seemed upbeat about the perks of longer hours, a few managers of commercial establishments and even late night shoppers were wary of the impact on business in coming days, given the money and manpower needed.If a security guard at Galleria had concerns over how crime rates might spike following late night drinking, police, too, seemed sceptical. One of the 20 policemen parked at a Lower Parel mall said, “This policy is for the rich. See the number of youngsters who are out. We have to keep a close eye on everything to prevent mishaps.”Malls like Infiniti had recruited at least seven extra security guards. “Once the plan is activated we’ll have to be extra cautious. Not all shops will be open and we will have to constantly monitor the movement of people.”Phoenix Market City’s security manager, Ramesh Kharatmol said police had visited the mall and checked their preparedness while inspector M Patil from Kurla police station who had visited said, “We have given a list of security arrangements that has to be followed.”

Title: Jaipur: Woman found murdered at guest house in Sanganer
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Police officers take stock of situation at the guest house on Saturday

JAIPUR: A thirty-one-year-old woman found dead at a guest house in Sanganer on Saturday who had checked in with a 22-year-old man two days ago. The victim has been identified as Pooja Kanjar, a resident of Dooni in Tonk district.

Kanjar’s father rushed to Jaipur after being informed by police about his daughter’s murder . On the basis of her father’s complaint, the police registered an FIR against one Ramkalyan Gurjar under Section 302 of IPC for murder.

Assistant commissioner of police (Sanganer) Poonam Chand Vishnoi said it looked like the accused strangled her with her dupatta. She was found lying in the bed with dupatta tied around her neck. However, the cause of death will be ascertained after post-mortem. Both belonged to Tonk and knew each other for quite some time. However, they were not married. Gurjar left the guest house early morning and a search has been made to nab him, Vishnoi said. The police have also collected the photocopy of ID cards which they submitted to the guest house before checking in.

Guest house owner Rajendra Gujjar told TOI that they told the guest house staff that they were married and submitted their IDs to get the room on Thursday evening. “It did not look like that they had differences between them. But, we do not know what happened inside the room,” said Gujjar.

Gujjar said that on Friday morning, they left the room and told the staff that they would return in the evening asking them to keep the room reserved for them.

“They returned on Friday evening as they told the staff. But, the boy left the guest house at around 4.30 am. When our staff went to switch off the lights at around 5 am, he found that the door of the room was open and the girl was lying in the bed and the man had already left. He informed me and I immediately called the police,” said Gujjar.

Title: JDA plans to launch two more housing schemes
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Jaipur: After the Jaipur Development Authority’s (JDA) successful endeavour to attract buyers for its recent housing scheme, the civic body is planning to launch two more schemes soon.

The JDA has proposed to launch residential schemes near Muhana Mandi and Manipal University on city’s outskirts. The proposal of the schemes has been prepared.

According to the official source, one scheme proposed as ‘Priyadarshini’ will be launched near Muhana village in zone 11.

The civic body will develop 187 plots. The smallest plot size in this scheme will be 45 square metre. Plot size of 90 sqm and 50 sqm will also be developed in this scheme.

Similarly, another scheme named ‘Mohan Lal Sukhadia’ will be launched in Dahmi Khurd village of same zone where JDA will develop 214 plots.

The largest plot size in this scheme will be 162 sqm. The JDA will also develop plots of different sizes including 126 sqm, 90 sqm, 72 sqm and 45 sqm in this scheme.

In an attempt to fill its coffers, the JDA has planned to launch these schemes. A senior source said, “The proposal for these schemes is prepared and approved in the building planning committee (BPC) meeting.”

The civic body looks confident to sell its plots as it is receiving overwhelming response from residents for proposed Shiv Vihar housing scheme where 346 plots are proposed to be developed.

The civic body is receiving applications in large numbers as the last date is approaching.

A senior official said, “The civic body has received over 42,000 applications so far. The lottery for the scheme will be held on February 5.”

The civic body has fixed a reserve price of Rs 25,000 per square-metre in this scheme.

The plots, sized between 45 square metre to 220 square metre, will be developed in the colony. Officials were expecting good response as it is situated on the 200-Feet Road connecting Muhana and Gopalpura Road.

A senior official said, “The move is expected to boost revenue that will be utilised to develop infrastructure. As the market condition has improved, the JDA filled its coffers after auctioning plots in its old scheme.”

Title: ‘Coming out’ as Dalit: A story of reservation, representation
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Yashica Dutt

We need to look beyond the binaries of violence and reservation when it comes to Dalit community, said writer Yashica Dutt on Saturday at the 13th edition of the Jaipur Lit Fest (JLF).

Dutt, who “came out” as Dalit after she read scholar and Hyderabad University Rohith Vemula’s suicide note in January 2016, was speaking to author Raghav Chandra and journalist Pragya Tiwari, as they tackled questions around identity and representation.

“I was told to hide my caste from a very young age. I tried to pass off as an upper caste person and slowly, I perfected that act. But when I read Rohith Vemula’s letter, something changed inside me. I decided to use the privilege I had acquired to talk about the trauma that comes with hiding your identity for so long,” she said.

The session provided a critique of the socio-economic system, where “merit” is often used as an excuse to criticise affirmative actions like reservation. “A lot of people speak of quota system as a problematic concept. But they don’t question the reservation that comes with caste, class and network privilege,” Dutt added.

Chandra also agreed, saying that the system has favoured people from upper caste and class backgrounds. “Reservation is the right step, but it is not enough to correct thousands of years of historic discrimination,” he said.

In an indirect attack on the ruling dispensation, Dutt also spoke of “sanskritisation” of Dalit community, which is being co-opted by a “certain party.”

“I cannot speak for the 250 million Dalits in India but it’s clear that there are attempts to appropriate the community by giving them a sense of power. People are being promised a seat at the table, but that place would be at the foot of the table with no actual say,” she said.

Title: Doctors meet Visakhapatnam MP to secure funds
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Dr PV Sudhakar, principal of Andhra Medical College ( AMC ) as well as other faculty from King George Hospital ( KGH ) met Visakhapatnam MP MVV Satyanarayana on Saturday. The group sought the MP’s help on procuring funds for infrastructure work.

Dr Sudhakar sought the MP’s intervention in getting funds for the Tertiary Cancer Centre at KGH. He also requested the legislator to pursue the seven public sector units in the city for their funding of the CSR block.

“The seven PSUs have paid around Rs 24 crore so far for the construction of the CSR block. Rs 29 crore is pending. Unless at least Rs 12 crore is released to the contractor, work will not resume. The work for the CSR block has been stalled for around six months due to the lack of funds,” he added.

MP MVV Satyanarayana assured doctors that he will pursue the PSUs about releasing pending funds.

Title: Man held for using fake govt logo in Kolhapur
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Police have arrested a 32-year-old on Friday for allegedly cheating people by using fake logos of the state government and Government of India.

The accused identifed as Irfan Ashraf Nadaf is a resident of Rukdi village in Hatakanangale taluka. He has been remanded into three days police custody.

Police are currently looking for his accomplice, who has been identified as Jaya Kaambale. Accortding to the police, Nadaf and Kambale introduced themselves as the representatives of the government, used the fake logo and collected money from people for health scheme. The government officials lodged the complaint after they got to know.

Police had confiscated fake letterheads and few other documents from Nadaf.

Title: One arrested for private money lending
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Kolhapur: Police have arrested a man, a suspected private money lender, and registered four cases against seven other people for allegedly running a racket of private money lending .

Action was taken when Miraj based professional Sanjay Mirajkar lodged a complaint. According to the complaint, Mirajkar had borrowed Rs 51 lakh from the money lenders to start his own hotel and paid more than Rs 2 crore. However, he was continuously tortured and threatened by the money lenders, who demanded additional Rs 35 crore.

According to Mirajkar’s complaint, the money lenders threatened him. He left his house leaving a note, where he mentioned the names of the eight people and described how he was tortured. Following which his family lodged a missing complaint Police traced Mirajkar down and initiated action.

Title: Gujarat: DGP steps in to help autorickshaw driver
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Shivanand Jha

AHMEDABAD: The haplessness of common people while seeking services from the police came into sharp focus, in the case of an autorickshaw driver, whose complaint for the theft of his rickshaw, Krishnanagar police refused to take several time. The driver, Yogesh Baghel, 23, was finally forced to make a representation to DGP Shivanand Jha , who directed crime branch to take his complaint and investigate the alleged misconduct of police personnel of Krishnanagar police station.

According to the FIR lodged at crime branch, Baghel’s auto was stolen on November 26, when he and his father were at their native village in Uttar Pradesh . He was informed of the theft by his mother, Gulab.

The FIR states that Baghel then came to the city and went to Krishnanagar police station, where a plain clothes policeman told him that finding stolen rickshaws was not their work and he should find it himself. According to crime branch officials, on November 26, Baghel learned that Rambahadur Soni had stolen his auto, at the instance of one Baccha Singh of Thakkarnagar.

On November 27, Baghel again went to Krishnagar police station and told them that Soni had taken his rickshaw. The cops did nothing but made him sign a paper with something written on it. To make a living, Baghel then started driving a rented autorickshaw. On January 17, he saw Soni near Vijay Park and caught him. “He then called the police controll room on 100. A PCR van arrived and took both of them to Krishnanagar police station. They were taken to the D Staff office, where Soni told the cops that he had stolen the rickshaw at the instance of Baccha Singh and took the rickshaw to Unava on his instruction. Krishnagar police told Baghel to go to Unava and get the rickshaw,” a crime branch official said.

The FIR states that the next day he went to Unava but could not find the autorickshaw. “He then went to Unava police station and asked them to file an FIR, but they said the offence did not take place in their jurisdiction but in Krishnanagar,” a crime branch official said. According to the FIR, he went to Krishnagar police station twice, but his complaint was not registered. Baghel and his mother finally went to DGP Shivananad Jha and told him about the entire episode. “The DGP directed us to register an FIR. We will probe the case and strict action will be taken,” a crime branch official said.

Title: Jaipur Literature Festival: ‘Swachh Bharat Mission created behavioural change’
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Amitabh Kant at a session

The Centre may have declared rural India open defecation free on October 2, 2019, but the claim was countered at the Jaipur Literature Festival forcing Amitabh Kant, CEO of NITI Aayog to say that Swachh Bharat Mission (SBM) was not an infrastructure project or construction of toilets alone, but creating a massive people’s movement for ushering in a behavioural change.

While giving a low-down of SBM captured in the book “The Swachh Bharat Revolution: Four Pillars of India's Behavioural Transformation” by Parameswaran Iyer, secretary at the Department of Drinking Water and Sanitation, the bureaucrat said that rural sanitation coverage was 38% when the programme started in 2014 but within five years, the campaign has achieved 100% target, changing the behaviour of 550 million people.

But fellow panelist Namita Waikar, managing editor and co-founder of the People’s Archive of Rural India, drew attention to the fact that data does not reflect the ground realities. “I challenge you to walk into any slum area in any city, marginal areas of any village or the railway tracks, you will find shit there. We are not defecation free,” said Waikar.

Referring to the garbage problems that urban areas face, Kant said that the challenge is that in the next five decades, India has to create two Americas in an innovative and sustainable manner.

“For India, lot of lessons come from eastern part of the world like Singapore where waste use is minimised at the household level. A great example of that is what Indore and Bhopal have done. They have managed to reduce household waste by about 40-45% just by segregating at the household level. They have converted waste into methane and methane into gas that is used for public transportation.”

“This is the first government which has talked about 100 smart cities. The challenge would be how do we do compact dense urbanization. The days of sprawling urbanization are over. America had sprawling urbanisation when it had land and water all available and its cities were made for cars. American car companies bought over railways and destroyed them so that cars could be sold. But today most of the successful urbanization is compactness and denseness, so that you are able to use public transportation and not use individual cars,” added Kant.

Title: More orders in Nirbhaya case not required, says Delhi court
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

File photo of Nirbhaya rape case convicts. (PTI)

Title: Pay taxes or get your properties sealed, BMC warns defaulters
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Bareilly: The Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) is gearing up to launch a massive crackdown against defaulters of house, water and sewer taxes. BMC officials said initially, they would target 20 big defaulters each in 80 wards whose arrears are to the tunes of lakhs of rupee.

According to information from the BMC tax department, the civic body has identified around 10,000 big and small tax defaulters, including commercial and residential, across the city and has initiated the process of issuing notices to them. Their properties would be sealed if they failed to clear the taxes, officials said.

BMC chief tax officer Lalatesh Kumar Saxena said, “The process of identifying big tax defaulters having arrears in lakhs of rupees is currently underway. We are targeting 20 such defaulters in each ward. We have also initiated the process of serving notices, warning them that their properties will be sealed, if they fail to pay their dues at the earliest. We have to recover a collectively arrear of around Rs 40 crore from defaulters by March-end.”

Zonal officer, BMC tax department, Vipin Kuldeep said, “Around 10,000 tax defaulters (big and small) have been identified across the city, including commercials establishments such as restaurants, hotels, showrooms, godowns, shops, salons, cinema halls, residential properties, among others. Their properties have tax arrears ranging from Rs 1 lakh to Rs 15 lakh.”

Saxena added, “With the department gearing up to take action, defaulters have started clearing their dues, but most of them are yet not paying any heed to our warning. A few of them have paid initial amount. Last week, around Rs 30 lakh was recovered. The drive will be intensified by four teams comprising six members each.”

According to BMC sources, the taxes are main source of income for the civic body, and thus, the recovery of taxes is important. Non-payment of taxes hits maintenance and development works severely.

According to rules, BMC initially generates bills and sends it to defaulters, ssking payment of taxes within 15 days. In case of non-payment within the stipulated time, a demand notice is served and an additional 15 days is granted. However, if defaulters fail to pay their dues, the process of attachment of their property is initiated, according to BMC officials.

Title: Seminar to discuss ways to attract more foreign pupils
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: The Centre is working on a slew of measures, including fellowships for humanities students, relaxing visa norms and starting a basic English test to attract more foreign students.

To begin this, a two-day “Destination India” conference would be held at Symbiosis International University on January 28 and 29 to discuss how to attract more foreign students to India. It will be attended by all stakeholders, including members from the police and other parts of the civil society.

At the end of the conference, a road map would be prepared to make India an attractive destination for students abroad. “India ranks third in the list of countries sending their students abroad. But, when it comes to receiving foreign students, we rank 26th. We only have about 47,000 foreign students enrolled for formal education in India. The target is to take this number to 2 lakh by 2020,” Namrata Kumar, the deputy director general of Indian Council for Cultural Relations (ICCR), said.

She added that the number of foreign students was much higher than 47,000 as many come to India on tourist visas and take up informal education or a training programme. The agencies are finding it hard to keep a track of this and to ease out the mechanism and the ICCR is trying to centralize the entire data, Kumar said. “At present, individual universities or institutes might have this data. Many people come and join Yoga courses, or dance courses which again are informal. We need to collate this data so that we can provide a better experience for the students and when they go back to their countries, they become our brand ambassadors,” she said.

Pune, Bengaluru and Hyderabad attract the highest number of foreign students in the country, with the SPPU and Symbiosis International University each getting roughly 3,000 students a year, Kumar said.

She said many students coming from Africa or the middle-eastern countries had been facing problems with English and universities as well ICCR were conducting various courses to bridge the gap. “Yes, there are talks at the national-level about introducing an examination (of English),” Kumar said.

One of the major glitches was foreign students not being able to apply for internships or training programmes with their Indian counterparts, said Vidya Yeravdekar, the principal director of Symbiosis Society. While visa norms were strict across the world, talks were on at the national-level to chalk out how to relax visa norms for foreign students, an official said.

Title: Applications invited for land surveyor, draughtsman
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Puducherry: The Puducherry government has proposed to introduce the services of licensed land surveyor and land draughtsman to speed up patta transfers and to bring in accountability and transparency in the process, besides easing pressure on the government machinery.

Secretary (revenue) T Arun said the Puducherry Licensed Land Surveyors and Licensed Land Draughtsman Rules, 2019, will come into force with immediate effect and the government has initiated procedures to allot licenses for land surveyors and land draughtsman to prevent inordinate delay in patta transfers.

The government has invited applications from eligible candidates for obtaining licenses to become a qualified land surveyor and land draughtsman. The applicants should be a resident of the Union territory and must have cleared SSLC (Class X) from any recognised board/university. They should possess an ITI trade certificate in surveying or a diploma in civil engineering/architecture or a degree in civil engineering/architecture from any recognised board/university. They must have completed a minimum three months certificate course in electronic total station and global positioning system.

Arun said with the government notifying the rules, any qualified person can apply and obtain the license for land surveyor/land draughtsman from the licensing authority. The revenue department has also developed an application to help the public apply for demarcation of land.

Title: Party-hopping MLAs: Hearings on February 13, 14
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Rajesh Patnekar

PANAJI: Goa speaker Rajesh Patnekar will begin hearings in the two disqualification petitions filed by Congress and MGP against their MLAs who joined BJP. The speaker has scheduled the hearing for February 13 and 14 .

“You (MLAs and petitioners) are requested to take notice. In default of your appearance, either in person or through counsel, the petition shall be heard and determined in your absence,” the notice issued to petitioners and respondents said.

In May 2019, senior MGP functionary and former deputy chief minister Ramkrishna Dhavalikar filed a petition before the speaker seeking disqualification of deputy CM Manohar Ajgaonkar and PWD minister Deepak Pauskar, who quit MGP to join BJP in March 2019.

The MGP challenged their claim that two-thirds of MGP legislature party has merged with BJP. MGP had three MLAs in the 40-member House, and it has now been reduced to one.

Dhavalikar had said that the 10th schedule of the Constitution does not postulate such a merger, by which the members of the legislature party would meet at midnight and claim that a merger has taken place.

In August 2019, Congress filed a disqualification petition against their 10 rebel MLAs who joined BJP in July 2019. State Congress president Girish Chodankar had sought that the 10 MLAs be restrained from attending assembly proceedings and holding constitutional posts till the case is decided by the speaker.

On July 10, rebel Congress MLAs led by Chandrakant Kavalekar joined BJP claiming that the Congress Legislature Party had split. The remaining nine MLAs were Isidore Fernandes, Nilkanth Halarnkar, revenue minister Jennifer Monserrate, Antonio Fernandes , Francisco Silveira , Wilfred Dsa, Clafasio Dias, Filipe Rodrigues and Atanasio Monserrate.

Title: Husband of rape survivor booked for attempt to rape
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Bareilly: A rape survivor’s husband has been booked for allegedly barging into a house in an inebriated condition, thrashing and attempting to outrage the modesty of a woman there.

A complaint to the effect was lodged by the daughter-in-law of one of the men who was accused of raping the former’s wife.

According to Avnish Yadav, SHO of Bareilly Cantonment police station, told TOI, “The 35-year-old man had trespassed into the house of a married woman and attempted to rape her on Friday night He allegedly thrashed her after failing to rape her. The man was drunk. He also threatened to kill her. We have filed an FIR under IPC sections 354 (attempt to outrage the modesty of a woman), 452 (house trespass with intent to hurt), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) and 504 (intentional insult). We have detained the accused who was so drunk that he misbehaved with us as well. His wife had earlier registered a rape complaint against a few villagers and the investigation of that case is on.”

According to police, earlier, the man’s 32-year-old wife had filed a rape case against four identified and 35 unidentified people with the police on December 17. She had met the SSP of Bareilly and lodged a complaint, alleging that she was thrashed and gang-raped by Amit, Shambhu, Chaman, and Pushpendra. She alleged that her tormentors had shot a video of the assault and later forced her to cohabit with 35 others over a period of one year.

She had also alleged that one of the accused, Amit, stole Rs 50,000 from her house.

At that time, police had filed an FIR against the four named men and unidentified persons under IPC sections 376-D (gang-rape), 392 (robbery), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 506 (criminal intimidation) and provisions of the Information and Technology Act.

Later, several villagers staged a protest against the woman and claimed that she had filed a fake complaint because her husband had borrowed money from the people booked for gangrape.

Title: Notorious Bawaria gang leader arrested in Bareilly
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Bareilly: A joint team of the UP Special Task Force (STF) and Bareilly police on Saturday arrested the leader of notorious Bawaria gang, which had committed over 50 robberies in Bareilly, Rampur and other parts of the country.

According to police, Tavar Ali (45) was planning to commit another robbery in Bareilly. He was nabbed near the railway station in Kotwali area of Bareilly city at 3.30 am.

Ali was wanted by the police since 2017 after he committed nearly a dozen robberies in Bareilly and Rampur. UP DGP had announced a bounty of Rs 50,000 on him.

“Tavar Ali is a cunning criminal, who was always on the move. He doesn’t use a mobile phone which is why it was quite difficult to trace him. We had been searching for him for the past two years. During interrogation, Ali told that he has committed robberies in many states, including UP, Rajasthan, and Maharashtra. His gang members used to stay with the caravan of their tribe members and gather information about their target. We have sought their criminal history from other states. We are now searching for two persons whom Ali was going to meet in Bareilly,” SSP Bareilly Shailesh Pandey told TOI,

Ali was earlier arrested in 2018 by Rampur police and remained in jail till 2017. He is believed to be operating several Bawaria gangs who used to travel across the country and commit robberies. Ali used to operate under pseudo names in other states to conceal his identity.

Tavar Ali, who hails from Dera Singahi village in Bhuta area of Bareilly district, came into notice for the first time in 2010 when he committed a robbery in Rampur district.

After his arrest, police had booked him under the ‘Gangster Act’. After returning from jail in 2017, Ali again committed a string of robberies in several parts of Bareilly. His gang members were arrested, but he always managed to escape.

However, the STF team had an upper hand on him when he planned to return to Bareilly almost after a year.

Title: Loan waiver: BJP’s protest march on Jan 28
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Kolhapur: The district unit of Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is planning to take out a protest march January 28 demanding complete loan waiver for farmers.

The protest march will be carried out from the Dasara Chowk to collector’s office under the leadership of BJP state president Chandrakant Patil. A memorandum seeking complete loan waiver for farmers will be submitted to district collector Daulat Desai.

BJP leaders said that the loan waiver scheme launched by the current state government leaves out over 95% of the farmers from the region.

Title: Two killed as private van crashes into cane tractor
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Kolhapur: Two people were killed in a road accident when an Omni van carrying six family members crashed into sugarcane carrying tractor at Appachi wadi on Friday night.

Steven Alvares, regional transport officer, Kolhapur , told TOI that they have given reflector tapes to all such tractors. “We are not aware of the accident details yet. This season we are quite sure it will help reduce the accidents,” he said.

Alvares admitted that in the past, several incidents of road accidents have happened due to the non-availability of the reflective tapes. “The trailers which are carrying the sugarcane can shadow the reflectors; hence it is mandatory to hang a removable reflective cloth with radium on the sugarcane so that it can be visible from distance,” he said.

He said that they have already warned the sugar mills that they will be considered co-accused in such cases if the reflective tapes are found missing from the tractor. He added that police will file cases against the vehicle owners and farmers, who do not use the visible reflective stickers under the Motor Vehicle Act.

The transport official had earlier said that they will organise an enforcement drive across the district to identify the violators and impose fine on such vehicles.

Alvares on the road fatalities in the district said that in 2018 the number of road accidents were 940, while the number reduced to 930 the following year.

Title: Man assaulted by neighbours
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Poinguinim: Maria C Rebello, a resident of Mashem, Canacona complained to police that her neighbours Joaquim Lobo and his wife Sudha, committed criminal trespass, abused and assaulted her husband Anthony Rebello, 59, injuring him. Police have registered a case of assault and said the neighbours quarelled over a wooden fence installed by the complainants. TNN

Title: MPs offer support to govt’s decision on NPR
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: MPs from the state belonging to ruling LDF and opposition UDF extended support to the state government’s decision not to cooperate with the National Population Register (NPR) even while deciding to give assistance to Census. In a meeting of MPs convened here ahead of the upcoming Parliament session, CM Pinarayi Vijayan said that the state government will initiate measures to avoid confusion among people and political parties on the Census and NPR .

The CM also urged the MPs to exert pressure on the Centre to speed up the procedures for carrying out pre-investment activities with regard to the Thiruvananthapuram-Kasaragod semi high-speed rail corridor project, “for which the Centre has already given its in-principle approval”. The MPs should demand allocation of sufficient funds in the railway budget for the proposed Angamaly-Sabari railway line and put pressure on Centre to speed up the national highway development in the state, he said.

The CM sought the intervention of MPs for consideration of various suggestions and demands raised by the state finance minister in his memorandum to the Union finance minister in the backdrop of the state’s financial crisis, while preparing the Union budget 2020-21.

The memorandum has put forth various demands, including raising of state’s borrowing limit for the rebuilding initiative after the deluge Kerala confronted in 2018, a raise in the support price of rubber, an international Ayurveda research institute in Kannur, an AIIMS for Kerala and additional investment in Cochin Shipyard and FACT.

MPs were also told to exert pressure on the Centre for immediate release of Rs 1,600 crore to the state as compensation in connection with GST revenue the state should have received during the months of August and September 2019, and to oppose the move to privatize BPCL.

Ministers Thomas Isaac, G Sudhakaran and K Krishnankutty, chief secretary Tom Jose and planning board vice chairman V K Ramachandran also attended the meeting.

Title: Delay in ICCR scholarship money
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: The foreign students enrolled in educational institutes in the city under the Indian Council for Cultural Relations (ICCR) haven’t received their scholarship money on time.

The students will submit a letter to the authorities on Monday. “Many are surviving on bread, noodles. Some landlords have threatened eviction. I am to get Rs18,000 and Rs6,5000 as living and rent allowance respectively. I didn’t get it this month. Some have got only Rs10,000. The ones who joined in 2019-20 didn’t get rent allowance,” a student said seeking anonymity.

Students said, “For the academic year 2019-20, we haven’t received book allowance. ICCR Pune hasn’t paid for the thesis and dissertation expenses of some students.”

An ICCR official said, “There are around 800 students at Pune regional centre. About 80-90% have been given Rs10,000. A letter requesting funds has been mailed to the Delhi office.”

Title: Mother helps in calling off wedding of minor daughter
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Alwar: The mother of a 15-year-old girl in Alwar district’s Bansur stopped the wedding of her minor daughter on Saturday after learning that the girl’s brother had fixed her marriage.

The girl’s mother reached the SDM office and asked officials to stop her daughter’s wedding following which the tehsildar reached the spot.

“When we reached the venue, a function was underway and the family said it was just a celebration but no one was being married off. However seeing the girl, it appeared that a wedding was likely to happen. We got in writing from the brothers that they will not get the minor married till she became an adult. The girl also did not say anything about the wedding, but the mother alleged that the child had been threatened to remain silent by her brother,” said an official.

The officials also said legal action would taken against the family if it was found that they got the minor girl married off. According to sources, the girl’s marriage had been arranged with a 50-year-old man in return for Rs 8 lakh.

Title: Pune: Alternate day water supply leaves residents high & dry
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Residents from many parts within the civic body limits are unsatisfied with the alternate day water supply , that has been in vogue for two months now, and have demanded the restoration of daily supply.

But the civic administration claims that the water supply complaints have reduced in two months. Makrand Nikam, joint city engineer and chief of water supply department, said, “The number of complaints has reduced but their figures cannot be disclosed. We get complaints of water pipeline burst, contaminated water supply and others from various parts of the city which we quickly resolve.”

The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) had begun the alternate day water supply on November 25 claiming that it was a temporary measure undertaken to ensure equitable water supply. A review of it was awaited in two months, that is, on January 25.

The civic administration drew lot of flak from activists, organizations and opposition parties as the Pavana dam was 100% full while this measure was being implemented.

Chairman Santosh Kanase, of a housing society called Shri Ganesh Inspira, said, “We are partially dependent on borewells as the water supplied by PCMC is insufficient. We also have to purchase 2 to 3 water tankers daily to meet the needs of residents in 174 flats in the society. On weekends we need 4 to 5 tankers as water consumption is higher. We receive municipal water at low pressure. PCMC must provide water tankers at subsidized rates.”

Sachin Sanap, a resident of a housing society in Akurdi said they were somehow managing to meet their requirements from whatever water they got from the civic body as it was costly to purchase water tankers.

Prajakta Rudrawar , chairperson of Celestial society federation in Ravet, said, “There are 704 flats in around 22 housing societies in the federation that receive water supply at low pressure. In my society we have implemented water conservation measures to avoid purchasing water tankers”.

Rahul Deshpande, chairman, Anuprabha housing society of 11 flats in Pimple Nilakh said they purchase 2 to 3 water tankers per week.

Title: Delhi building collapse: Survivors recount horror
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Siddha Parveen (10) recalled hearing the roof beams creak a few days ago but no one thought much of it

NEW DELHI: There was a loud rumble and everything turned dark after that, recalled 10-year-old Siddha Parveen at the emergency unit of Jag Parvesh Hospital in east Delhi. For three years, she and her eight-year-old sister Busra had been going for tutorials to the ill-fated building in Bhajanpura whose roof collapsed on Saturday. Lying in the hospital bed, Siddha recalled hearing the roof beams creak a few days ago though no one thought much of it.

Siddha, Busra, Aarti and Uma Bharti were lucky they only suffered limb fractures and head injuries and did not lose their lives in the cave-in as their teacher and four others did. The teacher, Umesh, was giving them history lesson when debris rained down on them.

Aarti was panic-struck to find herself trapped in pieces of concrete from her waist down. “I could hear my classmates crying from under the debris,” she said. “But I couldn’t move my hand even to pull myself out of the pit. My life was probably saved because the cement portion that fell on me was wet and fresh.”

Umesh and his brother Shankar were running the tuition service in the building for three years. According to the families of the students, classes were held through the day, with each batch of students there for two hours. “It is the only tuition centre for children between the ages of 7 and 14 in the locality. Each batch has around 30 children,” disclosed Naveen Kumar, a teacher. “On Saturday, with most students having taken leave for Republic Day, the attendance was half.” Kumar himself had a close shave having just finished his classes and left the building when the roof crashed down.

Asif Khan, Siddha’s father, revealed that the tuition classes were earlier held in a nearby building, but had shifted to its current location three years ago. “We didn’t know that another floor was being illegally constructed,” Khan said. Chastened and relieved to have been spared more tragedy, the auto-rickshaw driver said, “From now on, rather than sending them to tuition centres, I will rather teach them at home with whatever knowledge I have.”

Title: Rajasthan: Dausa farmers’ stir over compensation enters third day
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Farmers protest in Dausa district on Saturday

JAIPUR: The Zameen Samadhi Satyagraha organised by the farmers whose lands were acquired by the Centre for the Bharatmala Delhi-Mumbai Expressway project entered third day in Dausa as they have been demanding a compensation four times the district level committee (DLC) rates or the market value of the land.

The farmers have been agitating under the banner Pradesh Kisan Sangharsh Samiti and would continue their agitation till their demands are not fulfilled. BJP MP Kirori Lal Meena had also joined the Satyagraha, which began in Dausa on Thursday, in support of the farmers.

"We met the chief minister ( Ashok Gehlot ). He had assured us that he would take up the matter with the centre. It has been 7 months since we met him, but nothing been done so far," said leader of Pradesh Kisan Sangharsh Samiti Himmat Singh . About 2,000 farmers in the state have been affected by the land acquisition. “The district level committee (DLC) rates for land acquisition have been fixed at a low rate, reducing it by 25% in 2018 in Rajasthan. We demand a compensation four times the DLC rates or market value of the land. In some places, they are giving it at 2 or 2.5 times the value,” he added. “In 2016, the BJP government issued a circular to dilute the Land Acquisition Act, 2013. That circular, which sought to reduce the compensation rates of farmers, must be annuled,” he added. Under Bharatmala project, Delhi-Mumbai Expressway will cross Alwar, Dausa, Sawai Madhopur, Kota and Jhalawar in Rajasthan. The Delhi-Mumbai Expressway project will pass through five states.

The 12-lane expressway will reduce the distance by 120km. Of the total distance, around 380km road will be developed in Rajasthan, 120km in Gujarat, 300km in Madhya Pradesh and 370 km in Maharashtra.

Title: CREDAI experts to help KMC develop plan for model roads
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Kolhapur: Experts from the Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India ( CREDAI ) will assist the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) to plan and construct four model-roads that will help in reducing the traffic congestion in the city.

The decision was taken after guardian minister Satej Patil conducted a meeting with CREDAI experts on Friday.

During the meeting, Patil asked the experts to come up with suggestions and recommendations on improving traffic condition in the city. He also told them that the administration is planning to develop three new bridges in the city as well as traffic signals at 12 different spots.

CREDAI experts recommended the construction of four major roads which were initially proposed in the municipal corporation’s development plan (DP), but were never built due to unknown reasons.

Vidyanand Bedekar, president of CREDAI, Kolhapur, said, “The construction of four roads — from Lishan Hotel Chowk to Kadamwadi, Shahu Sanskrutik Bhavan to Sugar Mill of Bawda, Sugar Mill to Khanvilkar Petrol Pump and Khanvilkar Petrol Pump to Shivaji Bridge — should be developed on priority. We are going to plan the model-roads which will be executed by the KMC and the state government. These roads will help to divert the traffic movement thereby easing the congestion in the internal parts of the city. Also, we have recommended connecting the smaller roads to the major ones properly. We will soon submit the plan along with the traffic movement study.”

The process of drafting the development plan for city roads is underway. Patil has asked the experts to take stock of the number of roads mentioned in the DP and the problems associated with the development of these roads.

In addition, Patil said that he will grant Rs 1.5 crore funds towards installing of the traffic signals at 12 places in the city. At present, 17 traffic signals operate in the city and most of them are located in the core areas. The fringe areas and suburbs do not have the traffic signalling system. Therefore, signals will now be installed on new roads.

Title: Ugandan woman held in Calangute murder case
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

CALANGUTE: A woman from Uganda, Minamu Hafusa , 22, was arrested on Saturday in connection with the alleged murder of Aldona resident Zeferino Barretto. Barretto was found dead at Saunta Vaddo, Calangute , on Friday morning.

Following investigations, Calangute police had zeroed in on the Ugandan as she had been spotted with Barretto in the hours before he was found dead. She was subsequently traced in Anjuna and was taken into custody by Anjuna police early Saturday morning.

Hafusa was later transferred to the custody of the Calangute police.

Calangute PI Nolasco Raposo told TOI that they would seek her remand in police custody for questioning on Sunday. Sources said Barretto worked as a waiter at a hotel in Guirim. Raposo said they would be able to ascertain the motive behind his murder and whether there were other persons involved only after the custodial interrogation of the Ugandan woman.

Speculation, however, was rife that the Aldona resident was murdered over a dispute over payments to the Ugandans for narcotic drugs.

Zeferino, 45, was found dead with his face smashed on Friday morning in a lane near the Baga bridge.

Title: Certificate course for site supervisors
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: The skill-training arm of Credai-Pune Metro will soon launch a three-day quality assurance certification course for site supervisors.

Credai Kushal — the training wing — is launching this programme in conjunction with the state real estate regulator, MahaRERA. Its aim is to upgrade the skills and knowledge of site supervising engineers to assure the quality of construction.

MahaRERA has recognized CREDAI Pune-Metro as a self-regulatory authority to handhold developers about the standard processes. Over 350 site engineers attended the introductory seminar on this course, organized recently at Credai-Pune Metro auditorium. Credai said the course would be recognized by Construction Skills Development Council, India (CSDCI).

Title: Over 1.30 lakh students to appear for HSC exam
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Kolhapur: Over 1.30 lakh students will appear for the Higher Secondary Certificate ( HSC ) exam scheduled from February 18. The practical exam is set to begin across the division — Kolhapur , Sangli, and Satara districts — from February 1.

The Maharashtra state board of secondary and higher secondary education (MSBSHSE) conducts the exam in arts, science, commerce streams as well as the minimum competency vocational course (MCVC) streams. The exam will conclude on March 18.

According to Kolhapur division board officials, ample arrangements have been made for the exam which will see appearance of 1,30,027 lakh students from the division. The exam will be held across 167 exam centres.

Akin to the last few years, students appearing for the board exam will get 10 minutes of reading time before they start writing the paper. The practice, which was being followed by the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) and Indian Certificate of Secondary Education (ICSE) board for several years, had received a positive response and had benefited the students.

Students will have be present in their respective halls at least 30 minutes before the commencement of the exam. They will be given answer sheets 20 minutes before the exam begins so that they can begin filling up their details. Students will get question paper 10 minutes before for the exam. During this time, they can go through the questions; however, they can only begin solving the paper only when the instructor informs them.

The Kolhapur division board official said that students can contact Kolhapur divisional office for any information regarding exam between 8 am and 5 pm.

Security arrangements have already been made for the exam. For example, video-graphing of sensitive exam centres has been done.

Title: 400 army job aspirants fall prey to ‘agents’
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The army headquarters recruiting zone, Pune, which covers five army recruitment offices in the state, has come across 400 instances of ‘ agents ’ extracting money from job aspirants in the past one year on the pretext of helping them secure admit cards for participation in army recruitment rallies.

The ‘agents’ operate despite the fact that enrolment for army recruitment rallies takes place through a dedicated website ‘joinindianarmy.nic.in’.

“The agents take advantage of the situation like poor internet penetration and connectivity issues in rural areas, which account for the bulk of aspirants, and lack of awareness about the recruitment process. They offer services to job aspirants for getting admit cards and, in some cases, even assure jobs in the army,” a senior recruiting zone officer told TOI.

“Once an aspirant accepts the offer, the agent fills the online form on behalf of the candidate with details of his email ID and cellphone number, instead of the candidate’s. The details of the admit card and alert are received at the agent’s email ID and cellphone and he seeks money from the candidate for handing over the admit card,” the officer said.

He said, “In the last one year, the five army recruitment offices in Maharashtra have come across 400 such instances through the grievance redressal mechanism. Some of these had to be resolved during the course of the recruitment rallies.”

To overcome the problem, the army has been conducting awareness drives through lectures and speeches at recruitment rallies, besides organising such events at schools and colleges. The army has made several motivational documentaries, flex boards, leaflets, calendars and other such publicity materials about its recruitment process which they distribute round the year and at every rally. A set of advisory related to recruitment procedure has been posted on ‘ joinindianarmy.nic.in ’.

Title: Rajasthan: Keep an eye on suspected coronavirus cases, hospitals told
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: All private and government hospitals have been put on alert across the state in the wake of novel coronavirus (nCoV), which has claimed 41 lives in China.Acting on the advisory sent by the Centre, the health department put its authorities on alert.The ministry has issued guidelines for surveillance and contact tracing, infection control, lab sample testing and clinical care.The Union health minister has urged passengers who have a travel history to China since January 1, 2020 to come forward for self-reporting to the nearest health facility if they experience any symptoms such as fever, cough and respiratory distress and also inform their treating doctor.However, the state is not among seven states where thermal screening is being done.The seven designated airports in New Delhi, Kolkata, Mumbai, Chennai, Bengaluru, Hyderabad and Kochi are conducting thermal screening for passengers who are arriving from China and Hong Kong.The state’s health department has written to all government and private hospitals to keep monitoring patients coming to them with symptoms of coronavirus disease.So far, no case has been reported but the health department is on alert.“We have directed our officials across the state to keep an eye on the patients coming to the hospital, even in private ones. In case, if any hospital reports a patient with symptoms of novel coronavirus, the health department should remain prepared to handle the situation,” a senior health department official said.An advisory on novel coronavirus has been issued mentioning that cluster of pneumoniawere being reported from Wuhan city, Hubei Province in China. Chinese authorities have identified it to be caused by a new type of coronavirus. Coronavirus are large family of viruses with some causing less severe disease such as common cold and others more severe diseases such as MERS and SARS.

Title: Tribal group opposes NPR-NRC exercise, calls Goa CM for debate
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: The Gakuved (Gawda, Kunbi, Velip, Dhangar) Federation, that works for the upliftment of the tribal community in Goa, has invited chief minister Pramod Sawant for an open debate and discussion on the CAA, NRC and NPR.

Expressing uncertainity about the fate of tribals if the NRC is implemented in Goa, general secretary of the federation Rupesh Soiru Velip said, “Goan tribals have seen with great shock and pain what happened to tribals of Assam due to the implementation of NRC. Out of the 19 lakh people in Assam who have lost citizenship of India, 13 lakh were poor tribals who had no documents to prove their citizenship. The government, instead of rushing to aid them, are plotting to send them to detention camps, where the fate of hunger and death awaits.

The federation is ready for an open debate and discussion on the CAA, NRC and NPR with the chief minister, Velip stated.

“If the chief minister and his government are really concerned about the development of the ST community, he should first declare and notify scheduled areas in the state of Goa as per the Vth schedule of the Constitution of India before March 31, 2020 as the implementation of the NPR will start from April onwards,” Velip stated. The CAA, NRC and NPR will together strip Goan tribals of our land , forest and agricultural rights, besides our voting rights and liberty, and that is why we are opposing it, he said.

“When the caste certificate (ST certificate) is itself proof that we are original citizens and settlers of this country, why do we need to prove it again now?” he said.

Title: Four pairs of trains to be suspended till Feb 11
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Bareilly: The Northern Railways (NR), due to ongoing maintenance work, has extended the suspension period of four pairs of trains (Up and Down) till February 11. Besides, one passenger train (64553) that runs between Moradabad and Anand Vihar will be short terminated at Ghaziabad from January 26 to February 11.

The suspended trains include Prayagraj-Bareilly Express (54377/78), Lucknow-Shahjahanpur passenger (64221/22), Moradabad-Chandausi passenger (54313/14) and Moradabad-Sambhal passenger (74301/02).

Earlier in December, the NR has issued a list of 12 pairs of express trains on Lucknow-Delhi and Lucknow-Chandigarh routes, movement of which will remain suspended till January 31. While, six trains were cancelled in November till February 2020 on Dehradun route as the track maintenance work is currently underway.

Now, as per fresh advisory, four pairs of passenger trains have been cancelled for 17 days.

“The competent authority has approved the further extension of passenger trains cancellation from January 26 to February 11 for the next 17 days due to infrastructural and maintenance work,” read the letter issued by NR.

Title: Pedestrian killed in hit-&-run, dumper driver held
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: A 46-year-old woman pedestrian was killed in a hit-and-run accident after a speeding dumper hit her from the rear while she was crossing the Vishrantwadi-Dhanorie Road via Maharana Pratap Chowk around 1pm on Friday.
