The Vishrantwadi police on Saturday arrested the dumper driver, Ramesh Tatya Pawar (26), of Lohegaon on the charge of causing death due to rash and negligent driving under the Indian Penal Code, along with sections of the Motor Vehicle Act.

The deceased has been identified as Yogita Chandan Sonawane, also from Lohegaon. “The dumper, which was speeding, was heading towards Vishrantwadi from Dhanorie when the driver lost control over the vehicle and hit Sonawane from behind. The woman was in the process of crossing the road,” assistant inspector Sachin Nikam of the Vishrantwadi police said.

Nikam said the passersby rushed Sonawane to a nearby hospital, where she was declared dead on arrival. “The doctors attributed multiple head injuries to be the cause of her death,” the officer said.

He said the police were apprised of the accident by the hospital authorities, following which their investigation started and the driver was arrested.

“Probe revealed the driver had abandoned the dumper and fled the spot after hitting the woman on Friday. He feared that the bystanders would physically assault him. We have seized the dumper for conducting inspection with the Regional Transport Office, Pune. The driver was arrested on Saturday,” Nikam said.

“We registered a suo moto case against the driver as Sonawane’s family members had gone to their native place in Osmanabad for performing her last rites,” Nikam said.

“Our investigation is on, and we are in the process of collecting more information about the deceased,” the officer said.

“We are yet to record the statements of her family members and other acquaintances,” the officer added.

Title: Yashwantgad: 17th century fort in ruins
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Yashwantgad, a heritage fort looked after by the government of Maharashtra, is a tiny remote village on the west coast of Maharashtra. This 17th century fort is one of the less-explored places in the state. Though the fort is partially in ruins, it is definitely a place worth visiting as it is surrounded by plush greenery and is built on the banks of Arjuna river. Nature lovers, history lovers, trekkers, explorers — Yashwantgad has a lot to offer to anyone who visits this less-explored destination.

How to reach

Located in the Nate village in Rajapur taluka of Ratnagiri district, Yashwantgad is located at a distance of 135km from Kolhapur city. It takes about three-and-a-half hours to reach this beach-side fort via Anuskura ghat- Rajapur- Nate route or the Ratnagiri- Adivare- Nate route. One can also visit the Ambolgad fort and Kasheli’s Kanakaditya temple en-route Yashwantgad.

Legend has it

The history of this fort dates back to 17th century. Anuj Devstalhi, a local guide at the fort, said “Both the forts — Yashwantgad and Ambolgad — were built during the time of Chhatrapati Shivaji to protect Konkan from enemies attacking through the coastal route or via backwaters. Yashwantgad is located on a creek next to Arjuna river backwaters while the Ambolgad is located on the sea front. It is believed that there was a hidden tunnel route to that connected Yashwantgad to Vijaydurg fort. It was used in times of crisis to escape from enemies. On Yashwantgad, one can see a 4 ft wide and 6 ft deep trench created to avoid direct attacks by the enemy. This fort still holds many structures, of which a 100 ft deep well from the Pandava era with caves within is the major attraction. Earlier, the fort had 17 bastions. Today, the fort is in a bad shape and is surrounded by trees and grass. It needs proper maintenance so that the heritage is protected. The fort is officially a ‘protected monument’ under the Maharashtra Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Sites and Remains Act, 1960.”

Flora and fauna

Yashwantgad offers stunning landscapes of the sea. It is a perfect mix of sun, sand, sea and nature. Monkeys, squirrels, birds and a variety of trees including mango, coconut, cashew, and banyan can be found in the vicinity of this fort. There are no food joints nearby, so visitors are recomended that they carry snacks and water with them.

Title: One Padma Bhushan and two Padma Shri for U’Khand this yr
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

fdfdfdfd

Dehradun: The Republic Day honours list which was announced on Saturday evening has the names of three persons from Uttarakhand who will receive the prestigious national awards of Padma Bhushan and Padma Shri by the President for their outstanding contribution in their respective fields.

Renowned environmentalist Anil Prakash Joshi, 64, founder of the Himalayan Environmental Studies and Conservation Organisation (HESCO), has been named for the Padma Bhushan award. Notably, Joshi had been conferred the Padma Shri in 2006 for his contribution in promoting indigenous technologies. Joshi has been involved in various initiatives like the ‘Gaon Bachao Andolan’ and has worked extensively with Himalayan communities. He has also been instrumental in drawing the attention of policy planners towards issues of the Himalayas by celebrating a ‘Himalaya Day’ every year. Among the Padma Shri awardees from the state is Kalyan Singh Rawat, 66, a retired government biology teacher from Karnprayag in Chamoli district, who has been instrumental in launching Maiti Aandolan under which more than five lakh saplings were planted across the state.

Plastic surgeon Dr Yogi Aeron, 82, has been providing medical services to people at his ‘Yogi’s Helping Hand’ clinic in Sahastradhara Road in Dehradun. In the past few decades, he has conducted some of the most critical surgeries in his field. He has been selected for the Padma Shri.

Title: Residents write to PMC, raise health concerns
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: A residents’ group has sent a letter to the civic body against keeping trucks carrying remains of dead animals parked outside the incinerator next to Naidu Hospital for long hours.

Sushma Date, a member of the Deccan Gymkhana Parisar Samiti, said, “The rotting flesh of animals in these trucks not only causes an unbearable stench in the area, but can be hazardous to the staffers and patients of Naidu Hospital as well as the employees working at the incinerator and the nearby dog pound.”

Samiti members said while it was understandable that Swachh Suvrekshan inspection was going on and sending the abattoir waste to the incinerator could be a temporary arrangement, it was still a health hazard to the people living and working in the area.

Date said the Samiti has requested the civic authorities to visit the area to take stock of the unsanitary conditions outside the incinerator. “The incinerator should only be used for the cremation of animal carcasses and not for slaughterhouse remains. The abattoir waste should be disposed off through the appropriate bio-medical waste system,” she added.

Dnyaneshwar Molak, joint commissioner and solid waste management head of the Pune Municipal Corporation, told TOI that there was no specification that the incinerator could not be used for incinerating slaughterhouse waste. “Due to the low capacity of this incinerator, the trucks carrying slaughterhouse waste have to stay parked outside the incinerator premises for a longer time,” he said.

Molak said the PMC had proposed to set up another animal carcasses’ incinerator in the city elsewhere, though the place was yet to be decided. “The proposed incinerator will not only have a higher capacity but will also be more advanced technologically,” he said.

Title: Kolhapur: Met department warns of drop in temperature in coming week
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

The weather report from the Met department added that on Sunday, the city will have a foggy morning.

KOLHAPUR: In its latest forecast, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) has said that the minimum and maximum temperatures in the city are likely to drop substantially in the coming week.

The IMD report said the maximum temperature in the city is likely to drop to 27 degrees celsius, while the minimum will be 15 degrees celsius by January 29.

On Saturday, the minimum temperature was at 18.3 degrees celsius — three degrees above normal. The maximum was 31.2 degrees celsius. The weather report from the Met department added that on Sunday, the city will have a foggy morning and partly cloudy skies later in the day.

According to the weather forecast, there will be a gradual drop in the maximum and minimum temperatures of the city as the week progresses.

Meanwhile, a weather report from the Regional Meteorological Centre, Mumbai, stated that weather was dry over the region. Minimum temperatures appreciably rose over Kutch and no large change in minimum temperatures was observed in the rest of the region. They were above normal in North Konkan, Madhya Maharashtra, Marathwada and Saurashtra and normal elsewhere in the region. It stated that 10 degrees celsius recorded at Naliya in Gujarat was the lowest minimum temperature in the region.

The weather forecast report from the centre said there will be a gradual rise in the minimum temperature over parts of north Madhya Maharashtra and Gujarat region over the next two days and no large change will be observed in the rest of the region. A fall in maximum and minimum temperatures is likely from January 27.

Title: Bareilly district court to keep roll of practising lawyers
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Bareilly: In the backdrop of the gunning down of an undertrial a Bijnor court last month, the district judge of Bareilly has issued a notice instructing to all lawyers practicing in the court to submit their details in a prescribed form latest by January 31 in order to prepare a roll of those practising there.

District judge Arun Kumar Mishra said a roll of practising lawyers would be prepared so that only those enrolled would be able to work in court. According to sources, close 1,600 lawyers are registered with the District Bar Association.

District government counsel Suneeti Pathak told TOI, “We have witnessed several incidents in the past when owing to rivalries, undertrials have been shot dead inside the courtroom after they were brought there from jail for a hearing. The recent incident took place in Bijnor court, where an undertrial was killed in front of the judge by three assailants.”

He added, “Now, each advocate registered with the district court will be issued an ID card and will be allowed to enter the court premises only after showing that.”

On December 17, three assailants, including two minors, had gunned down Shahnawaz Ansari, an accused in the double murder of BSP politician Ahsan Khan and his nephew in the courtroom. Ansari had been brought from Delhi’s Tihar jail.

After the murder, the Allahabad high court took suo motu cognizance of the incident inside the courtroom and summoned additional chief secretary (home) and director general of police, asking them to furnish a plan to strengthen security at courts’ premises across the state.

Earlier in February 2015, a dreaded gangster, Vicky Tyagi, was murdered inside the courtroom in Muzaffarnagar by a minor who had arrived there donning a lawyer’s robe.

Taking cognizance of such incidents, the Allahabad HC had issued directions to all courts across the state to prepare advocates’ roll as maintained in the high court.

Title: Patil to hoist flag, preamble reading in schools to start from R-day
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Kolhapur: District guardian minister Satej Patil will be hoisting the Indian flag to mark the 70th Republic day celebrations at Chhatrapati Shahu Stadium on Sunday.

Several teams are scheduled to carry out parade march which will be followed by adventurous activities and other police force activities. District collector Daulat Desai extended the R-day invitation to all the public.

An award ceremony is scheduled to be held and the awards will be given to the sportspersons, entrepreneurs and social workers by the guardian minister. A team of district officials has made the awardee list based on an individual’s work and contribution towards society.

The celebrations will be followed by Patil inaugurating the four centres that will be serving Shivbhojan Thali for Rs 10 to the masses.

Apart from the official celebrations, several schools, government, and private institutes will be having a flag hoisting ceremony.

Several citizens queue up popular joints to buy freshly-made jalebis to distribute among friends and families.

At Dasara Chowk, the public reading of ‘Preamble’ of the Indian Constitution will be carried out. Several activists, local leaders will take part in the event organised to create awareness of values, liberty, equality, and fraternity. The Preamble will also be read in the schools from Sunday onwards as per the decision of the state government.

BOX

Flag hoisting by 10th topper in a village

A village panchayat of Bhadwan from Ajara tehsil has decided to hoist the flag at the hands of a tenth standard topper girl Akshata Pandurang Patil. Sarpanch of the village Sanjay Patil came up with the idea. Last year, he hoisted the flag at the hands of a retired soldier.

Title: Fake calls for Sainik School admission
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Pune: Many parents have raised complaints about receiving phone calls from unknown callers, who put forth monetary demands to secure admission for their wards in Sainik School, Satara.

Most parents approached the school authorities but some raised their concerns on the school’s helpline number in the past few days.

“Parents are advised not to get cheated by fake calls from touts promising help in admission to Sainik Schools by increasing marks. The Sainik Schools Society, ministry of defence, does not make any calls related to admission nor does it authorize anyone on its behalf to do so. Please follow the developments only on the online portal of Sainik Schools Admission — sainikschooladmission.in," said the principal of the school in an advisory issued on the website.

The school conducted its entrance examination across the country in the first week of January.

A section of parents wondered, “How did these cheats get access to information which was submitted to the government? It’s a serious issue and the authorities concerned need to have counter measures,” said parents, who did not wish to be named.

“The callers told me that my son is short of 20 marks to secure admission in the school. He even quoted specific details about my son and was even aware about the examination centre. He then demanded Rs20,000 and sent his bank details and alternative mobile number. I received at least 20 calls in a day from the caller,” said a father.

Title: Hindu organisations demand NRC in Goa
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

PANAJI: Various Hindu organisations conducted a demonstration here on Saturday demanding the implementation of the National Registry of Citizens (NRC) in Goa, to “solve the increasing problems caused due to Bangladeshi infiltrators”.

Members of the outfits, assembled under the banner national Hindu movement (NHM), said there were more than five crore ‘Bangladeshi Muslim infiltrators’ living in India, and they were “causing a drain on the basic facilities and resources belonging to Indian citizens.”.

Hindu Janajagruti Samiti's Satyavijay Naik said Bangladeshis in Goa were involved in fish and vegetable trade, collection of scrap and even prostitution, and called for action against those supporting ‘Bangladeshi infiltrators’ involved in various trades in Goa, to publicise the photographs and lists of ‘infiltrators’, and to thoroughly check the background of candidates before employing them.

Title: Bareilly dist reports 167 malaria cases in Jan despite biting cold
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Bareilly: Bareilly district reported 167 malaria cases in January despite both maximum and minimum temperatures plunged several notches below normal, making mosquitoes inactive.

The number of positive cases is, however, slightly higher than January 2019 when 160 malaria cases were reported.

Of the 167 cases reported this month, 21 are of “deadly” malaria strain — plasmodium falciparum (PF) — while the remaining are a milder form of malaria — plasmodium vivax (PV). Health department officials said the number of deadly malaria cases reduced in comparison to the corresponding month the last year, which recorded 84 PF cases.

Meanwhile, the health department has received 16,000 long-lasting insecticide nets (LLINs), which accredited social health activists (Asha) and auxiliary nurse midwives (ANM) will distribute in PF-affected villages.

LLINs mosquito nets come with an insecticide coating that kills mosquito when it sits on the net. Officials said LLINs would be given on priority basis to those households whose maximum members were tested positive for malaria last year.

District malaria officer DR Singh said, “ANM and Asha workers will give one LLIN to a family. As thousands of people were tested positive for malaria last year, ANMs and Ashas will give preference to those households which reported a maximum number of malaria cases. LLINs will be distributed among families of pregnant women and children diagnosed with malaria last year.”

Singh added the distribution of LLINs would start in the first week of February.

Out of 16,000 LLINs, 5,000 each will be distributed in Majhagavan and Bhamora, which reported highest malaria cases, while 1,000 each will be given in Ramnagar, Faridpur, Kyara, Meerganj and Fatehganj West.

In Bareilly district, 46,717 malaria cases, including 12,141 PF cases, were detected in 2019. However, in 2018, 37,382 cases were reported.

Title: Vijai Sardesai to push for CAA debate in assembly
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Vijai Sardesai

PANAJI: Goa Forward Party president Vijai Sardesai on Saturday said that his party would put forth a demand asking speaker Rajesh Patnekar to allow debate on the “burning issue” of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in the assembly, especially since chief minister Pramod Sawant has agreed to participate in the debate.

Speaking to mediapersons, Sardesai said “I think we should have a debate on CAA. I think the government will give us a debate on CAA, as the CM himself has said it. What better forum then the legislative assembly for a debate,” he said. He also said that people in BJP “who are suffocating”, could also express themselves at the CAA debate in the assembly.

Title: Delhi coaching centres fire: No licence to run coaching centre, EDMC orders probe
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

A firefighter douses a fire that broke out at Delhi Transport Department office at Civil Lines in Delhi on Mon... Read More

NEW DELHI: The building whose roof collapsed and killed people in east Delhi on Saturday neither had its building plan approved nor was it licensed to run coaching classes inside. Preliminary investigation by a local civic official revealed that the building was 10-15 year old with an angled iron roof supported with stones. “It was an old roof,” the official said. “It wasn’t made of concrete and of the type no longer used in house construction.”

According to the official, such iron beam-stone roofs are weakened by moisture over the years, but said the actual cause of the collapse on Saturday will be determined only after a detailed probe.

The commissioner of East Delhi Municipal Corporation directed the deputy commissioner of Shahadra (north) to conduct an inquiry and submit the report by Monday. The site of the accident is in a Bhajanpura colony that was regularised in the 1990s. The fact that a regularised colony still had buildings without sanctioned plans raised doubts about the efficacy of the regularisation process.

Municipal officials refuted reports that a coaching centre operated out of the building. “We have been informed that a teacher provided tuition services from his home. All places where teaching takes place can’t be termed coaching centres,” insisted a civic official. EDMC mayor Anju Kamalkant said that a survey of coaching centres had been undertaken last year but did not cover the smaller tuition centres. “I have directed the entire area be scanned for other such weakened roofs,” she said, adding there were was no record of tuition centres.

Despite all the assessment exercises conducted after the fire in a coaching centre in Surat, Gujarat, took a toll of 22 lives in May 2019, Saturday’s ghastly incident appeared to show that not much had improved on the ground in Delhi and the capital’s students continued to risk their lives studying in dangerous structures.

Though teaching centres do not require any trade licence to operate, chapter 15 of Master Plan Delhi 2021 provides several categories of relaxations for non-residential activities in residential areas. While educational coaching is permitted as such an activity, conditions are clearly spelt out for minimum area requirement, approved construction, structural norms and fire safety.

“It is not as if MPD straightaway grants permission to people to run coaching centres in residential areas. A large number of conditions have to be fulfilled. But both the fire department and the local bodies have failed to crack down on large scale MPD violations," the official remarked.

Title: nCov: Three still placed in isolation in Mumbai
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Image used for representational purpose only

MUMBAI: Three persons suspected of having the 2019 novel coronavirus infection continued to be in isolation in civic-run Kasturba Hospital near Saat Rasta on Saturday despite two of them testing negative for the virus .

No new persons were placed under isolation in Mumbai or the Maharashtra, said health officials who were part of a high-powered review meeting held by chief minister Uddhav Thackeray , who has called another meeting on Monday.

BMC officials said there are government guidelines on how to handle patients, incubation and observation periods for the virus before discharging the two patients—a male Kalyan resident and a 31-year-old female from Nalasopara— who had fever-like symptoms on returning from China. “We will discharge the patients on the basis of guidelines.”

The laboratory diagnosis for the third person, a 65-year-old UK national who came from Hong Kong on January 10 and was admitted to Kasturba on Friday, wasn’t available till late on Saturday. Samples of people in isolation are sent to the National Institute of Virology , Pune. State officials said 2,056 passengers have been screened at the airport.

The CM asked health officials to be prepared to handle more samples for tests, if needed. As symptoms of the novel coronavirus and common cold are similar, he asked the department to prepare guidelines to identify the difference. A Maharashtra Communicable Diseases Prevention & Control Technical Committee team has begun work on these.

Title: R-Day CAA dissent blooms, mayor calls for ordered stir
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Kolkata: On Republic Day eve, anti-CAA protesters in Kolkata and Howrah went about their preparations for the D-Day when they will join a human chain in the first half and participate in cultural functions reflecting the Freedom struggle in the second. However, police have not given permission for the human chain as they do not want the general public to be inconvenienced by traffic restrictions. Mayor Firhad Hakim, too, expressed concern over attempts to block roads to protest against NRC and CAA. He instead called for a united voice from a single platform that would register a stronger protest.

“This is not the right approach. If somebody has to register his/her protests against NRC or CAA, they are welcome to join our platform. Our CM has been relentlessly airing her grievance against the anti-people policies adopted by the Centre,” Hakim said.

On Saturday afternoon, cops stepped in at the protest site near New Market and forced the protesters who have been squatting right in the middle of the road to shift the platform to a corner. Later, the deputy commissioner of the central division held a meeting with OCs of Burrabazar, Posta, Maidan and New Market police stations to chalk out a plan to prevent activists from blocking roads to hold agitations.

The agitators on Hogg Street vowed to carry on with the protests for at least four days more. At Park Circus, the protests in the Maidan entered the 12th day on Saturday and showed no signs of abating. The participants there and at Ekbalpore, Zakaria Street and Howrah’s Pilkhana are eager to usher in Republic Day with flag hoisting in the morning and then travel to the nearest point between Golpark and Shyambazar to join the human chain.

“The human chain is an innovative idea to send out a message that we are united in our fight against the draconian CAA and the proposed NRC and NPR,” said Irfan Ali Taj, one of the organizers of the sit-in at Zakaria Street.

At Nawab Ali Park in Ekbalpore, protesters plan to bring out a peace rally in the evening that will have participation from people of all faiths. “We want a dialogue with every section of the society. It is important that the right message is sent out that it is not any particular community but the Constitution which is being threatened,” said Arshad Parvez Khan, one of the organizers.

At Howrah’s Pilkahana, members of the civil society are invited to speak on CAA and NRC to the gathering in the evening. “People should have a clear idea what they are protesting against. This is why we are organising awareness camps almost on a daily basis,” said one of the organizers.

At Park Circus Maidan, where the sit-in started on January 7, cultural programmes are scheduled in the evening. “Several students, artists and intellectuals are expected to arrive in the evening. We are going to sing patriotic songs and make posters,” said one of the organizers.

Title: Rajasthan: Goods train derails, traffic disrupted for seven hours
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

JAIPUR: The rail traffic between Bhilwara-Udaipur was disrupted for more than seven hours when two wagons of a goods train derailed near Soniana station between Bhilwara-Udaipur on the Ajmer-Udaipur rail route.

This has also affected the electric engine speed trial from Madar (Ajmer) to Udaipur as the electric engine had to return back to Ajmer from Bhilwara.

According to the NWR officials the incident took place at 3.30 pm on Saturday when two wagons of the goods train derailed near Soniana Point near Bhilwara.

Due to this derailment four trains had to be diverted and some trains were rescheduled. The distruption on the rail route also caused invconvenice to several passengers at Ajmer, Bhilwara and Udaipur.

“Our train Udaipur-Haridwar express was operated through diverted route via Chanderia-Kota-Sawai Madhopur-Jaipur,” said Abhay Sharma, chief public relations officer, NWR.

Title: Rajasthan: Goods train derails, traffic disrupted for seven hours
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

JAIPUR: The rail traffic between Bhilwara-Udaipur was disrupted for more than seven hours when two wagons of a goods train derailed near Soniana station between Bhilwara-Udaipur on the Ajmer-Udaipur rail route.

This has also affected the electric engine speed trial from Madar (Ajmer) to Udaipur as the electric engine had to return back to Ajmer from Bhilwara.

According to the NWR officials the incident took place at 3.30 pm on Saturday when two wagons of the goods train derailed near Soniana Point near Bhilwara.

Due to this derailment four trains had to be diverted and some trains were rescheduled. The distruption on the rail route also caused invconvenice to several passengers at Ajmer, Bhilwara and Udaipur.

“Our train Udaipur-Haridwar express was operated through diverted route via Chanderia-Kota-Sawai Madhopur-Jaipur,” said Abhay Sharma, chief public relations officer, NWR.

Title: Rampur admin on alert after ulemas pass CAA resolution
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Rampur: The city of Rampur and its adjoining areas have been put on alert after ulemas passed a resolution against police and administrative officials demanding an immediate release of the anti-CAA protesters from jail.

The clerics and imams gathered at Jama Masjid during Friday prayers and set a deadline of January 29 and stated that if their demands were not met by then, they would decide their next course of action on January 30.

On Saturday, Rampur Jama Masjid committee secretary Mukarram Inayti said, “Women are gathering daily on the premises of Jama Masjid asking for the release of innocent protesters who were arrested during the anti-CAA protest on December 21, 2019, and sent to jail. We gave a memorandum to Rampur district magistrate, passed unanimously by clerics and if the people are not released from prison then protests, under the Constitution, will be carried out.”

Members of the Jama Masjid committee had met Rampur DM Aunjaneya Kumar Singh in this regard on Saturday. Later, inspector-general of police, Moradabad range, Ramit Sharma, went to Rampur and held a meeting with the local administration and police officers.

“We are in constant touch with police officers and our first priority is to release those protesters from the jail against whom no evidence was found. I think, we would be able to find a solution soon,” the DM said.

Title: Eight from Gujarat get Padma awards
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

(Left to right) Yazdi Karanjia, Gaffur Bilakhia and Shahbuddin Rathod

AHMEDABAD: It was a moment of elation for eight from Gujarat who were selected for Padma honours on the eve of the 70th Republic Day, on Saturday. The awardees said that the recognition will inspire them to work harder. While B V Doshi, selected for Padma Bhushan , could not be contacted, he had said in an earlier interview to TOI that his work is an extension of his life, philosophy, and dreams.

Prof Sudhir Jain, the founder-director of IIT-Gn, said that the prize is a great honour. “I am humbled. Much of my earthquake engineering work happened in Gujarat after 2001,” he said. “And I got a chance of institution building at IIT-Gn. Thus, I owe a lot to Gujarat.” He said the award was a recognition of his colleagues too.

Two stalwarts from performing arts have been selected for Padma awards. Shahbuddin Rathod, the renowned humourist from Thangadh , charted a new path in Gujarati dayro and narrative style. Yazdi Karanjia from Surat keeps the Parsi theatre tradition alive. “Today, the nation has appreciated me and my work in the fields of arts and culture,” Karanjia told TOI. “I humbly accept this and thank all my colleagues and family.”

Gaffur Bilakhia, a Vapi businessman, has been recognized for his contribution to trade and industries. Dr Gurdip Singh has been honoured for his contribution to medicine. Narayan J Joshi ‘Karayal’, the founder of Kachchi Sahitya Kala Sangh , works for the revival of Kachchi language.

Dr H M Desai, the vice-chancellor of Nadiad-based Dharmasinh Desai University (DDU), said that he will accept the award on the behalf of the entire staff of the university and the hospital his institution runs. “It’s collective work for excellence and we are hopeful that the recognition will bring focus to our initiatives,” he said.

Title: Cops crack bizman kidnap case, arrest 4
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Chennai: Police on Saturday solved the January 19 kidnap and extortion case of a businessman arresting four suspects. They seized Rs 3 lakh from the suspects.

The arrested were identified as Ganeshkumar, 32, of Thiruvottiyur, Anandaraj, 35, of Cheyyur in Kancheepuram district, and Mani, 28, and Perumal, 30, of Korukkupet. They were remanded in prison by a magistrate court.

Police said Suyambu, 50, a realtor from MKB Nagar, received a phone call a week ago and the person who spoke to him wanted him to construct a building at Vadaperumbakkam near Red Hills . Suyambu, who was out of town, later went to meet the caller and visit the site on his two-wheeler on January 19.

An investigation officer said that three men who showed him the plot allegedly took him in a car claiming that they would get the land documents from Koyambedu. However, when the car was near Koyambedu , they threatened Suyambu at knifepoint and demanded Rs 50 lakh to release him.

Suyambu was forced to call his friends and arrange the money. Later, the trio sent another person to receive Rs 6 lakh from Suyambu’s friend in Tondiarpet. After the money was received, the gang dropped Suyambu back at Vadaperumbakkam. Based on his complaint, the Red Hills police registered a case.

Title: CAA and NRC protests: Tongue in cheek, protesters drive home point with posters, memes
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Some of the posters that became an instant hit at protest venues and beyond

KOLKATA: Defiant protesters are not only taking part in night vigils and rallies to voice their angst against CAA and NRC , they are also using satire and tongue-in-cheek slogans to back their demonstrations, using humour as a form of resistance.

Some posters and memes are witty — Bure din wapas kardo (return the bad days), read one of the them, mocking the BJP slogan of acche din (good days) before the 2014 elections — while some others convey a serious message about the unity of the country — jab Hindu Muslim razi toh kya karega Nazi — sending a subtle message to politicians to refrain from divisive politics.

When PM Narendra Modi arrived in Kolkata on January 11, protesters blocked all thoroughfares so that Modi could not reach Raj Bhavan. One of them read: Raasta bondho. Desh meramoter kaaj cholche (The road is shut. Nation rebuilding is underway).

On January 10, a young law student arrived at an anti-CAA protest on Mayo Road with a poster that read azadi mera dulha hai (azadi is my groom), bringing back memories of Bhagat Singh, who had told the British “Azadi meri dulhan hai (azadi is my bride)”. Another student carried a poster that read “yahan tobacco chorna itna mushkil hai aur yeh kehte hain desh chhor do’ (it is so difficult to quit chewing tobacco and they demand us to leave the country). It poked fun at politicians in the ruling regime who threaten to send people to Pakistan when they disagree with their discourse.

“Humour helps to connect. It also reduces fear because you are not scared of something that you laugh at. This is important as fear is being used as a tool to push back the protesters,” said Sreya Sengupta, a student of Presidency University who has been tickling the funny bone with her posters at several protests.

Earlier, political humour and satire was the preserve of big writers but today, even ordinary citizens are taking a dig at politicians due to the changing political climate and internet. Protesters said every time politicians speak, they provide enough content either due to the faux pas, slogans or flawed understanding of the country and its people.

A young man in Kolkata started attending protests wearing symbols of most religions painted on his face and attires of most faiths after PM Modi in one of his political rallies in Jharkhand said the protesters can be identified by their attire. “I am Ram Bismil Singh Robert,” he says while holding aloft a poster saying “Pehchan Kaun? (identify who I am)”.

Many people also feel humour is an important release valve and coping mechanism under a “majoritarian rule”. “Using humour is also an attempt by citizens to counter balance prejudice and bigotry and poke fun at them,” said Prasanta Dasgupta, a political scientist.

Title: Four Surat girls among top 25 in country
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Nishi Shah

Surat: Four girls from the Diamond City secured rank among top 25 in the country as the Institute of Company Secretaries of India (ICSI) announced results for its Company Secretaries (CS) Foundation Course on Saturday. The exam was held in December 2019.

Nishi Shah, a resident of Bilimora, scored 330 marks out of 400 and secured All India Rank (AIR) 17. She is followed by Dhruvi Shah (AIR 19), Chhavishree Somani (AIR 20) and Afifakhantoon Dumasia (AIR 22).

“I made it a habit reading daily and that has helped. I was confident of score of over 300,” said Nishi. Her father Chetan works as manager in a plastic unit while mother is a practicing Ayurveda doctor. Nishi in second year BCom student at SPB English Medium College. She did her schooling in Bilimora and Navsari.

Total 109 students had appeared from the city of which 66 cleared the exam. “It is a good performance by CS students from the city. Like other professional courses, some of the best students are choosing CS for better career,” said an ICSI Surat chapter official.

Title: Four held for abducting RMC councillor
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Rudrapur: Nearly a week after police managed to rescue Rudrapur Municipal Corporation councillor Amit Mishra from Ghaziabad, four men have now been arrested for allegedly abducting him. Three other members of the gang are still on a run, say police officials.

SSP Barinderjit Singh said that police received a tip-off that seven accused were going from Baghpat to Baithak in Uttar Pradesh (UP) in two vehicles. The police teams cordoned off the area and blocked these two cars at an underpass at the peripheral expressway. While the police managed to nab four persons, three others managed to flee the spot.

The arrested have been identified as Rinku Kumar (30), a resident of Ganesh Nagar in Delhi; Chetan Kumar (32) of Trilokpuri in Delhi; Gautam Jatav (23) of Baghpat in Uttar Pradesh; and Abrar Ansari (24), of Fazalpur Mehraula in Rudrapur. Three other accused who are still on the loose are — Sandeep Kumar, Harendra Prakash, and Rohan Bhati. They all are Baghpat (UP) residents.

During investigation, the police found that the accused are history-sheeters and had looted two petrol pumps in UP and Uttarakhand in the first week of January. The police also recovered a double barrel gun and the car used for kidnapping the accused.

To recall, Mishra (alias Bittu), RMC councillor from Bhoot Bangla ward number 21, was kidnapped from Rampur Road on January 15 by six people, who intercepted his bike, overpowered him and pulled him into their car. They later demanded a ransom of Rs 20 lakh for his release.

According to police, the victim’s mother, Sarvesh Mishra, lodged a complaint with police on January 16. Several teams were immediately set up to ensure safe recovery of the victim. When the kidnappers realised that they were being followed by police, they escaped on the night of January 18 after freeing the victim at PVR Mall in Rajnagar Extension, Ghaziabad, from where police rescued the councillor.

Title: Nirbhaya parents and lawyer in Indore-Jan 25
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Indore: Parents of Nirbhaya claimed to have lost their faith on human rights organisations and said that international human rights bodies are more interested in protecting convicts than upholding rights of victims and their families.

“Did my girl (Nirbhaya) who died seven years ago not have any human rights or do I not have any human rights while I have been fighting for justice? Not even one organization had come to ask me how I am fighting till now. Government should help such families financially,” mother of Nirbhaya, Asha Devi told reporters on Saturday.

Asha Devi was in city along with her husband, Badrinath Singh and lawyer Seema Kushwaha for a flag hoisting ceremony on Republic Day.

Kushwaha added that people, who are talking about human rights of convicts, should study the definition of human rights as these convicts did extremely heinous crime.

“It has been seven years but crimes haven't decreased. Even though there were several amendments done, it has been useless. Government is insensitive towards the females which is 49% of the country’s population. We are hopeful that the Article 72 will be amended,” she added.

Asha Devi, who is hopeful that convicts will be executed on February 1, added that in a span of three decades she has seen only one rape convict being hanged and she has decided that she will continue to fight for rights of several other Nirbhayas.

“Each month 6500 rapes take place in our country how can it be expected that the country will progress if society is not safe how will country be safe? I want to see how much court gives right. I am expecting Supreme Court to come up with guidelines soon and it's not just one Nirbhaya but for several others,” said father of Nirbhaya.

Parents of Nirbhaya suggested that in case of rape, or gang rape the family shouldn’t hide the victim as it wasn't the fault of the girl but that of those criminals. Parents should support the girl and the society will support. They also urged not to differentiate between children on the basis of gender.

Title: ‘Govt must ensure locals get jobs at Mopa’
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Panaji: Questioning the efforts made by the state government to create employment opportunities in the state, Congress recently demanded that when the new international airport becomes operational at Mopa , local youth should be given employment at the airport.

Naik also attacked the government for not coming up with the IT Park at Dona Paula and in other parts of the state. “This has deprived our youth of gainful employment,” Naik said. TNN

Title: Owners’ pride: Constitution back in vogue, thanks to rising protest pitch
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Mudar Patherya’s copy of the Constitution; (L) Utsav Parekh keeps his copy on the centre table at his Sarat Bo... Read More

KOLKATA: At least two photo-lithographic reproductions of the Constitution of the Republic of India , which few in Kolkata knew about, have suddenly become the city’s most prized assets with people from all walks of life, castes, creeds and religions swearing to protect the Constitution and the values it upholds. One of the 1,000 photo-lithographic reproductions of the document is in the possession of a communications professional, and the other is with a businessman.

The two have, for over two-and-a-half decades, had the document that articulated the idea of India in its infancy. But never has the document been more relevant than now. In the past couple of months, the Constitution has emerged as the bedrock of protests against attempts to redefine India. On Sunday, women protesting at the multiple ‘Shaheen Baghs’ in the city will recite the Constitution, as will Christian priests and parishes in churches after the morning mass. Also on that day, which happens to be the 70th anniversary of the Constitution, 14 individuals, including actors Aparna Sen, Parambrata Chatterjee and Dhritiman Chatterjee, and singers Rupam Islam, Usha Uthup and Anjan Dutt, will recite segments of the Preamble for a video to be uploaded on social media. A student will conclude the video with the final two words, “this Constitution”.

“We had learned the Constitution in civics and knew the Preamble by heart as students. In the later years, few remember the words that encapsulated the idea of a nation. That was true till the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protests kicked off. The Preamble and the Constitution is suddenly in currency because people feel what the government is trying to push through is against the spirit of the Preamble,” said Mudar Patherya, who had bought the photo-lithograph for Rs 3,000 from antiquarian Rupnarayan Shastri in 1988.

He said the Constitution, to him, is like the Quran and the Preamble, the Surah al Fateha, which is effectively the essence of the holy book in a nutshell. It is the heart of the Quran, something that every Muslim gets to learn by heart as a child. “Just like the Surah al Fateha, the Preamble could take a lifetime to decode,” he explained.

To Utsav Parekh, who got the photo-lithograph in 1995, the Constitution is the genesis of how we live as citizens of India. “To me, this is a law book. It tells you what the Indian society is, how one should live, what are one’s rights, duties and obligations,” he said.

Parekh felt a churn is natural in a dynamic world. But if a change affects a large section of the population, one must be careful.

“The framers of the Constitution had foresight. For 70 years, it has been India’s guiding star. I hope it remains so for generations to come,” he said.

Patherya said a line in the Preamble — “Liberty of thought, expression, belief, faith and worship” — is its show-piece line that other countries should try to emulate.

Title: Naroda man loses Rs 45,000 to fraudsters
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Mahesh Panchal, a resident of Sharna Residency in Naroda, lodged complaint for cheating and offences under the IT Act at Naroda police station.

Panchal stated that he obtained a credit card of a private bank in October 2019. On October 24, he got a call from a person who identified himself as a bank employee. The man told Panchal that a verification procedure had to be done for the card to be activated. The man first took his card number and then the three digit CVV number.

The man then asked him for the one-time password (OTP) that was sent to his mobile phone, so that the card could be activated. According to the FIR, as Panchal gave him the OTP, Rs 45,907 was spent on the card.

Naroda police officials said they are tracing the number from which Panchal got the call and would soon arrest the perpetrator.

Title: Call to cut off northeast from India is jihad, says BJP’s spokesperson Sambit Patra
Content:
BJP's national spokesperson Sambit Patra

दोस्तों शाहीन बाग़ की असलियत देखें: १)असम को इंडिया से काट कर अलग करना हमारी ज़िम्मेदारी २)”Chicken Neck” मुसलमानो… https://t.co/d1U8FJMGL6 — Sambit Patra (@sambitswaraj) 1579930120000

NEW DELHI: The video clip of a controversial speech made by a JNU student at the AMU campus surfaced on social media on Friday night, triggering a row over Shaheen Bagh . BJP’s national spokesperson Sambit Patra shared the clip on Twitter on Saturday.Addressing a press conference later, he called it an “open call for jihad and finishing the sovereignty of the country.” Patra had initially said the speech was made at Shaheen Bagh but when corrected he said the venue didn’t make the issue less grave.In the video, the student, Sharjeel Imam — who had earlier figured in reports as one of the organisers of the Shaheen Bagh protest — is heard telling the crowd that Muslims can cut off the entire Northeast from the rest of India by blocking Chicken’s Neck (Siliguri Corridor) which has a predominantly Muslim population. “It was stated in the speech that cutting off Assam from India is our responsibility which means that it is the responsibility of Shaheen Bagh, and the thought process of Shaheen Bagh is to finish India’s sovereignty and cut off Assam and the Northeast from India,” Patra said calling the speech seditious.Amid clapping and chants of ‘Allahu Akbar’, Imam was seen talking about anti-CAA rallies. Giving the example of such rallies in Bihar, he said: “Every day, one or two big rallies are being organised. For example, in Kanhaiya Kumar’s rallies there were 5 lakh people. I have said it earlier also that if we have an organised group of 5 lakh people, we can permanently cut off Northeast from India. If not permanently, then for at least one or more months. Dump so much debris on the tracks and roads that they (government) will need one month to clear,” he says.“Cutting off Assam is our responsibility,” he exhorts the crowd. “Only when Assam is cut off from the country, they (government) will listen to us. You are aware of the condition of Muslims in Assam where CAA and NRC have been implemented. People are being pushed into detention centres. A bloodbath is going on there.” He expressed concern about the plight of Bengalis, irrespective of their faith, in Assam. “If we want to help Assam, we need to close the roads for Army and supplies. It can be cut off because the Chicken Neck is dominated by Muslims. It is the responsibility of leaders and scholars to put the anger of the public to productive use.”Highlighting this part of the speech, Patra asked whether productive use of anger referred to destroying the country and breaking it into multiple parts. “Rahul Gandhi and chief minister Arvind Kejriwal had four years ago backed the JNU ‘tukde-tukde gang’. The dream of the cousin brothers (Rahul and Kejriwal) is reflecting in Shaheen Bagh. Manish Sisodia stands with Shaheen Bagh,” Patra said, asking whether Rahul and Kejriwal would still stand with such a call.“Imam is one of the coordinators of the Shaheen Bagh protest. Rather than being just a geographical location that it was a few days ago, Shaheen Bagh has become a thought process which is being emulated across many places in the country,” Patra said.Patra alleged that Shaheen Bagh was overflowing with anti-nationals. “Shaheen Bagh is a poisonous idea,” he said adding that the protest site, which also has many children, is filling innocent hearts with hatred. “The conspiracy was clearly visible in the speech to cut off the Northeast from the rest of the country by using the predominantly Muslim population living in Chicken’s Neck,” he said. “This is a classical call for jihad,” stressed Patra, comparing the viral speech with attempts witnessed across the world to establish the Caliphate and destroy democracy.The BJP functionary also condemned the attack on journalists on Friday at the protest site.TOI tried to reach out to Imam but failed to elicit any response from him.

Title: Ahmedabad: Two of four-member burglar gang nabbed
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: City crime branch team busted a gang that was allegedly involved in several burglaries on Friday. Crime branch sources said they have nabbed two of the four gang members.

Navinchandra Darji and Amit alias Shyam, both residents of Jasodanagar Society, Savli, in Vadodara, for the theft of gold and cash, worth Rs 2,63,550.

They were arrested after intensive combing by police personnel and have criminal histories.

Crime branch officials said the gang has committed several burglaries in Paldi, Nava Vadaj, Navrangpura, Chandkheda, Satellite, Sola, Kankaria, Gurukul Road and Samarkham village of Anand district .

“We suspect the gang is involved more offences. We are questioning the accused. We have informed police stations across the city about their arrest and are hunting for the two absconding members of the gang,” said a crime branch official.

Crime branch sources said the thieves would recce commercial complexes in the day time and commit burglaries at night.

Title: Abducted 14-year-old girl’s kin gherao Varachha police station
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

SURAT: A group of family , friends and community members of a 14-year-old schoolgirl gheraoed Varachha police station on Saturday to demand that she be rescued from her abductors immediately.

The 70-odd people ended their demonstration after approximately 90 minutes when police officials assured them of strict action in the matter.

The family members submitted a memorandum at the office of district collector complaining of inaction by police, which also mentioned the role of accused Kamlesh Parmar, 25, and others in the abduction of the girl. The girl had left home on January 8 at 7am to go to school, but she neither reached school nor returned home.

The family had lodged a complaint of abduction at Varachha police station the same day against Kamlesh, who earlier lived in neighbouring house.

Police have booked Kamlesh Parmar for allegedly abducting the girl. Police found her documents in the house of a Parmar’s relative at Vashingpura village of Gir Somnath district in Saurashtra .

“My daughter’s Aadhaar Card, birth certificate and school leaving certificate were found in the house of Parmar’s elder sister, but police didn’t take any action against her. Police have specific information about people who had helped Parmar financially but they are not being nabbed,” father of the girl alleged.

“We are taking action to trace the girl and nab the accused. A team led by a police sub-inspector is in Saurashtra,” said C K Patel, assistant sub-inspector, A division.

Title: Protests at Jamia Millia Islamia: JCC says Imam not leading them
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Jamia Millia Islamia University students shout slogans during a protest demonstration against a new citizenshi... Read More

NEW DELHI: Jamia Coordination Committee (JCC), the group organising the protests at Jamia Millia Islamia , has condemned the attempts to portray Sharjeel Imam as their leader. A group of alumni of JNU’s Centre of Historical Studies (CHS), where Imam is a student, has also condemned his “divisive” statement.

In their statement, JCC said that since the beginning of the popular and leaderless movement, individuals have been repeatedly targeted by the state, media and the government “in a bid to delegitimise and break up the protests. Students from Jamia and AMU have been charged with baseless cases, locals have been accused of everything from bribery to terrorism, and hate campaigns have been initiated against different people.”

They said the latest attempt was to accuse Imam of sedition by presenting him as a “leader” of the movement.

“JCC wishes to state that neither Imam nor any other individual is a recognised as a “leader” in the ongoing protests, and any attempt to attach the broad movement to individual leaders is only a strategy to derail the movement. To the best of our knowledge, Imam is currently associated neither with the protests in Jamia nor with the one in Shaheen Bagh ,” JCC, comprising of multiple student groups of Jamia, said in its statement.

Stating that “while we do not agree with Imam’s political positions and do not endorse him in any way, we nevertheless stand in solidarity with him as he faces incarceration for an alleged act of sedition.”

At JNU, where Imam is currently enrolled as a student, 13 alumni and students of CHS in a signed statement said that “the Indian Constitution and its values are our beacon. We condemn this person’s attempt to misuse the anti-CAA protest — a democratic one at the core — to push a divisive agenda, as his alleged video suggests. JNU stands for a united and harmonious India.”

Title: New rules for medicos’ service bonds soon
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The public health department (PHD) is in the process of amending the rules, after it amended and notified a circular for executing bonds with modified terms of service for undergradudate and postgraduate students of Goa Medical College (GMC) and Goa Dental College (GDC)

Though the new guidelines that were included in the circular issued in April 2019 reduced the bond period from three years to one for post graduate students, the corresponding notification in the rules was not made.

“The rules for PG courses are being amended, but no rules were in force for undergraduates of GMC and GDC,” said an official.

The circular, with the new guidelines that were issued last year, mandated that undergraduate and postgraduate students serve a bond of one year for each programme.

“The reduction of the bond period from three years to one year has to be reflected in the rules,” he said.

Under the old rules, he said there was no provision to give an exemption from serving the bond but, ironically, in the past, many students left after completing their PG to take up further studies, but they didn’t come back to offer their services.

“Many students used further studies as an alibi to escape from serving their bond period. On being relieved, they would not come back even after completing their course,” he said.

Under the new guidelines, there is a provision to offer temporary relief from the bond, if any student wants to take up a course or pursue further studies after PG, but subject to the condition that the student gives in a bank guarantee.

“In case the student does not return to serve their bond period after completing his course, the bank guarantee stands forfeited with no notice,” he said.

There is also a provision to penalise students who resign without completing the course, or fail to serve the bond. MD/MS/Diploma/MDS student will be liable to pay a penalty of Rs 50 lakh, and students of MBBS/BDS/allied health sciences (AHS), Rs 10 lakh, on failure to put in the service.

Temporary exemption from the bond, however, shall not be granted for short term fellowship courses of less than one year, or to attend workshops or other training programmes.

Title: Why our love affair with cricket will never grow stale
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

What each of the panelists in the ‘Cricket: The Spirit of the Game’ session had in common was that neither of them could convert passion into competence. “I tried the hardest to the least effect,” said Gideon Haigh, widely regarded as the finest cricket writer of the day, and among the best in the history of the game. “As a child, I wanted to play cricket very badly. And that’s what happened as I grew up – I ended up playing it badly,” confessed Shashi Tharoor.

“Unlike my father, I had everything going for me; I had the best equipment, the best coaching. But I realised cricket doesn’t run in the blood,” admitted Rajdeep Sardesai.

Sardesai’s father, of course, was the famous Dilip, the first – and till date only – Goa-born cricketer to play for India. His story is full of the romance of cricket. “Before M S Dhoni there was Dilip Sardesai,” said the proud son of a batsman who loved playing in the Caribbean. “He didn’t see a cricket pitch till he was 17, and he learnt cricket from the village tailor, who himself learnt it from listening to the radio. His is a remarkable story.”

For Haigh, cricket is the gift that keeps on giving. “In some ways, I’m still that small boy experiencing for the first time that photo of Victor Trumper jumping out to drive – it’s a symbol of expressiveness, freedom, élan, elegance and athleticism,” he said, with more than a hint of nostalgia.

The career and life of Shane Warne, long retired but still as fascinating, also received an airing. “Growing up in Australia in the 1970s and 1980s, you were told by old stagers how magical leg-spin was, but you never saw it – and if you did see a leg-spinner, you would see him being smashed out of the park,” Haigh recalled.

“We didn’t believe it was still possible to see leg-spin but then this chap rolls up, and suddenly we see what we were always told leg-spin was – a species of magic. I feel blessed to have lived in the Warne era, to have seen what leg-spin was all about.” And how could a discussion on cricket today not mention Virat Kohli? Haigh spoke about his versatility and adaptability, and the fact that Kohli has not only succeeded in but dominated all formats of the game. “He is unique in the annals of the game – we’re living through the Kohli era.”

Still, cricket’s more than a game (to paraphrase C L R James). For Haigh, stepping on to the field is panacea to all the ills that afflict it. “It’s rejuvenating and reassuring to play it, to remind myself of the exquisite physical sensation of it, and the camaraderie,” he shared. And for Sardesai, a visit to the Mumbai maidan works wonders. “Whenever I feel depressed, I go back there, just to see the kids playing and their infectious energy. That will remain forever.”

Title: Chandigarh: Violating green norms to cost three industrial units Rs 1 lakh
Content:
The CPCC inspection revealed many units were not complying with the terms and conditions

CHANDIGARH: Chandigarh Pollution Control Committee (CPCC) has ordered three industrial units to pay Rs 1 lakh for violating environmental norms.“It is environmental compensation. Notices were issued to 104 units in the last two months and one was shut down. The CPCC inspects industrial units on randomly. Action is taken against units discharging waste water without treatment and emitting foul air. The action against industries causing pollution will continue,” said T C Nautiyal , member secretary, CPCC.Sources said the CPCC has issued closure notices to around 20 different units in Chandigarh in a year. Nautiyal, however, clarified notices would be revoked if industries comply with the rules.The CPCC inspection revealed many units were not complying with the terms and conditions. It had also ordered the electricity department to disconnect power supply of the unit that was recently shut down.The CPCC is a regulatory body granting consent to operate industrial units under Water (Prevention and Control of pollution) Act, 1974; Air (Prevention and Control of pollution) Act 1981 and under Environment (Protection) Act 1986. The consent is granted with certain terms and conditions that have to be followed by all industrial units.

Title: Padma Shri for PGI’s Dr Digambar Behera
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Digambar Behera

CHANDIGARH: Dr Digambar Behera , senior professor, department of pulmonary medicine, PGI, has been chosen for the Padma Shri award under the category of medicine this year.

Dr Behera was given extension for two years after he superannuated in 2018. He had also been nominated as the director of PGI in 2011, when he made it to the top three contenders.

Dr Behera, who belongs to a village in Cuttack, Odisha, comes from a middle-class family. His parents were not literate, and he was the first amongst two siblings to make it to the field of medicine. The journey for him till he made it to PGI has been tough. “I used to walk barefoot to attend my school located some 4-5 km away from home as I had no shoes. While studying I also used to help my father in agricultural activities,” said Dr Behera. There were times when the pulmonologist had to borrow coat during the winters when he was in PGI for his post-graduation.

Dr Behera has now come a long way. He is the chairman of the national task force of National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme. He is also the chairman of a few divisions of the ICMR-formed Indian Tuberculosis Research Consortium that conducts research and plans activities for new diagnosis and medicines for tuberculosis.

Having spent 42 years in PGI, Dr Behera gives the credit of his accomplishments to his teachers and the faculty of his department. “I had been inspired by my department head Prof S K Malik, who was wheelchair-bound. He used to give me research ideas related to the field. My first research was on chutta/homemade (reverse) smoking by fishermen in Odisha. It was known that it causes mouth cancer but nothing was done on its effect on lungs. I conducted lung and other function tests on them,” said Dr Behera.

Dr Behera believes that one should be determined, remain focused and work till one breathes his last. “I will be turning 67 soon. But this honour bestowed on me has encouraged me to work more towards TB elimination and lung cancer treatment.”

Box:

Last year, Prof Jagat Ram , director, PGI, was awarded Padma Shri. Prof Yogesh Chawla, former director, PGI, and Prof Amod Gupta, former sub dean, PGIMER, have also received Padma Shri earlier.

Title: Dateline Northeast: Time to move away from stereotypes
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

How does a writer from the Northeast – a straitjacketing descriptor that does no justice to its people – engage and interact with the mainstream? This was one of the topics touched upon in the session, ‘The Rivers, The Sky, The Self’, on day three of the Jaipur Literature Festival.

“I don’t have a problem with being slotted as a Northeastern writer – it’s better than being recognised as a Japanese and being asked for my passport!” said writer Easterine Kire, partly in jest. Indeed, Kire’s life and ancestry embodies the diversity that exists in the region; a grandmother from Meghalaya, a grand-uncle married into Mizoram. A Naga herself, she has friends from Manipur.

“I’m proud to be Northeastern but my Assamese identity is more important to me. Because, had I not learnt Assamese culture, I would not be here today,” shared poet and journalist Mridul Haloi.

Aruni Kashyap, writer, translator and teacher, described the region as “polyphonic”, but that polyphony doesn’t reflect in media reportage. “We don’t see that diversity of voices, and it’s similar to how ‘African’ writers are portrayed in the West – there are so many more voices, stories, representations from the Northeast,” he contended.

Then, of course, there are the conflicts that have, unhappily, blighted this corner of India. They have also, equally unfortunately, received too many column inches in the national media. Kire was blunt about her objections. “There’s one reviewer who’s unhappy that I don’t write about violence!

“Don’t use stereotypes to try and understand us, come to the Northeast to find out about our real selves, because the fake is destroying us.”

For pretty much every writer in the Northeast, the geography, and their ethnicity, forms a crucial part of their writings. Haloi’s relationship, for example, is more personal. “I have my own river, the Pagladia, with which I have spent a lot of time, on its banks. I believe the river can recognise me, and I talk to him,” he told the audience. “One day, it asked me, ‘Would you like to live with me?’ to which I replied, ‘I already am!’

“Whenever someone asks me about rivers, I am reminded of the Pagladia.” Indeed, rivers, Kire adds, are important to the imagination and soul of the people here.

Title: I’m nobody, who are you?
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Venu Chitale (left) at the BBC with George Orwell (standing, left)

BENGALURU: Facebook is the “high school reunion from Hell”. Twitter is the “hosepipe of hatred”. Instagram is “Twitter for people who can’t or won’t read”. WhatsApp is the “official disinformation channel”. These are all descriptions of social media – on social media. And the love-hate relationships that we have with this latest form of self-expression is both bewildering and addictive.

There have been reams written about the nature of our love for social media - the allure of self-presentation, the dopamine rush with every comment or like on a post, and the transformation of our very lives as social media performance.

All that is true – and social media is often depressing, frustrating, invidious. Women tend to face horrendous abuse and threats of rape and mutilation. Political arguments lose all nuance and turn into slugfests and shouting matches. Language is often vile. And the other aspect, that of one’s circle of friends and peers, turns on exclusivity, exotic holidays, the preciousness of precocious children – all leading to FOMO, the fear of missing out – a word that the Oxford Dictionary added way back in 2013.

But.

If you can accept that you will never have a life as interesting as your friends on Instagram or Facebook, that you will never know more than the economist or historian on Twitter, and you’re prepared to stay away from people you interact with on a regular basis in real life while on social media, there is so much scope for learning new things, to be entertained, to be amazed and to be provoked into thought.

It’s how you discover that the late Sultan Qaboos of Oman was a great fan of British light opera and Gilbert and Sullivan - and one of the reasons he led a coup against his father was that his father had stormed into his room and smashed his favourite record (The Pirates of Penzance). It’s finding out that both Gordon Greenidge and Vivian Richards made their test debuts here in this city, in 1974 – and Greenidge became the first West Indian to score a test century on debut while overseas. Or that we use the ‘x’ as the multiplication sign because of the efforts of a clergyman named William Oughtred , back in 1631. Or that the Marathi broadcaster and novelist Venu Chitale began her career at the BBC in 1940 as secretary to author George Orwell. Or that there is a kind of mollusc called the disco clam which uses a system of flashing lights to protect itself from predators. Its finding pictures of “beauties from Lucknow”, dating back to 1874. It’s finding out that Mary Burchell , an author of more than 110 Mills & Boon romance novels, used the money she made to save Jewish families from the Nazis before World War II.

And there’s subject-focused social media – virtual gatherings of old film fans, antiquarians, bibliophiles, mathematicians, astronomers, nature lovers – whose posts renew interest in things that you had hoped you’d left behind you, which went under the stultifying names of mathematics and biology and physics from your days in school or college; or bring to your attention films you should be seeing or books you should be reading - classics that no longer are on bestseller lists or the box office charts. And when you go from reading about books to reading them, and talking about them, from watching clips to watching a long forgotten classic that still retains its charm, your life is enriched.

Yes, posting a photo of yourself in exotic surroundings, looking as good as you can, artfully enhanced by tints and filters, and seeing the likes pour in can be immensely satisfying. So is making a smart remark about the state of the nation or the world, stimulating a comment chain a hundred posts long. But unless you’re a celebrity, with people waiting to engage with you, hanging on your every image or utterance, this is not going to happen. And when it does, it is usually accompanied by hateful remarks, ad-hominem insults, and general pettiness.

But if you are content with having fifty friends or followers – of which 40 may be bots, but are willing to follow hundreds of people who have interesting things to say, if you’re willing to prune your friends’ lists and following lists regularly and often, social media can be so rewarding. But if you keep trying to make that popular post, that viral video, that great selfie, you’ve just ended up “public, like a frog”, telling your name the livelong June, to an admiring – or otherwise – bog.

Title: SUDA seals Raghuvir Celeum Textile Market
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

A team of FSL experts, Surat police and DGVCL has started investigation into the textile market fire

SURAT: Surat Urban Development Authority (SUDA) sealed Raghuvir Celeum Textile Market on Puna-Kumbhariya Road here on Saturday.

SUDA officials said the structure of the textile market has become weak due to the massive fire that razed for more than 32 hours since Tuesday last. The entire market has been sealed for an indefinite period. A notice has been put up at the market to prevent entry of people.

Official sources said the building requires structural stability report from a government approved agency. SUDA chairman Banchhanidhi Pani told TOI, “The market has been sealed for an indefinite period, till structural stability of the building is established. The building may be demolished.”

The massive fire at Raghuvir Celeum Textile Market broke out on the early morning hours of January 21. The entire A and B wings of the market were gutted in the fire. It took more than 32 hours for the firefighters to extinguish the fire.

A team of Forensic Science Laboratory (FSL), city police and Dakshin Gujarat Vij Company Limited (DGVCL) have started a joint investigation into the textile market fire. FSL experts have collected samples from the spot and the entire building was videographed. The DGVCL has carried out MRI of electricity metres inside the building and transformers in that area to know about overloading and illegal drawing of power in the building.

Pani said, “We will know the exact cause of the fire once the FSL submit its report. Action will be taken against whoever is responsible for the fire.”

An officer of SUDA said, “Raghuvir Celeum Textile Market fire is not a normal incident. There are doubts over it. It appears to be someone’s mischief for taking benefit of insurance claim. The entire building was insured.”

Title: Man found dead near Mohali SSP’s house
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

MOHALI: The body of a 26-year-old man was found in a fountain at a park adjoining the official residence of Mohali SSP on Saturday.

Police suspect the man, Ashu, a resident of Mauli Jagran, drowned. Police said his family members told them he was a patient of epilepsy and an alcoholic. The fountain has 3.5ft deep water. Ashu is suspected to have fallen into the fountain at night. Rajesh Verma, the brother of the victim, said Ashu often used to get epileptic attacks. Verma said their father Harishankar, who used to sell ice in Phase 3B2, died about two months back. No foul play was alleged by family members, police said. Police-initiated inquest proceedings under Section 174 of the CrPC and handed over the body to the family after the post-mortem. The viscera was sent for chemical examination to ascertain the cause of death.

Title: GFP chief Vijai Sardesai wants FIRs filed in renewal of 88 mining leases
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Vijai Sardesai

PANAJI: President of Goa Forward Party ( GFP ) Vijai Sardesai on Saturday demanded that the state government should file an FIR on the recommendation of Goa Lokayukta in renewal of 88 mining leases.

Sardesai told mediapersons that based on Karnataka Lokayukta, BJP had asked its chief minister to resign in Karnataka. But in Goa, BJP is saying that Lokayukta report is only recommendary.

“This government has become thick skinned as they have 27 MLAs,” Sardesai said, adding, “100% FIR should be filed, and it goes without saying. If government does not file FIR then it is like a banana republic.”

On Thursday, chief minister Pramod Sawant had said that no charges of corruption have been made in the Lokayukta report on renewal of mining leases against former chief minister Laxmikant Parsekar or any of the officers named in it.

Sawant had said that as there was a need for resumption of mines, the then government had decided to renew the 88 leases.

Lokayukta justice P K Misra had recommended to the state government to conduct a CBI inquiry and file an FIR against Parsekar, former mines secretary Pawan Kumar Sain and former mines director Prasanna Acharya for alleged “corruption” and “criminal conspiracy” in renewing leases of 88 mines between November 2014 and January 2015.

Misra had also said that Sain and Acharya should not hold any offices.

Soon after Lokayukta submitted the report to the state government, Sawant had said that it was only a recommendatory body and it was for the government to act on it.

“The government has a right to accept or reject it. After studying the report, the government will take necessary action,” he had told TOI on Tuesday.

Title: Van runs over two-year-old boy near Gummidipoondi
Content:
This story is from January 26, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A two-year-old boy was run over by a private van near Gummidipoondi on Friday evening.

The deceased Rishwanth had accompanied his mother Gayathri, 26, to pick up her niece’s daughter Sathvika, 4, coming from school in a van. As the van used to drop her at Siru Puzhal Pet near Gummidipoondi, Gayathri was waiting for her. Soon after the van arrived, Gayathri rushed towards the door holding Rishwanth. Sathvika came out greeting Rishwanth and Gayathri, who took Sathvika on her lap but failed to focus on Rishwanth.

Witnesses said the boy walked towards the rear wheel of the van and when the driver moved the vehicle, he ran over the child killing him on the spot. Stunned, Gayathri raised an alarm and neighbours rushed the boy to the Ponneri Government Hospital where he was declared brought dead.

Police said Rishwanth was the son of Shanmugam, 36, and Gayathri from Reddypalayam near Kavarapettai in Gummidipoondi. They lived as a joint family with Shanmugam’s brother Haridoss and his wife. The incident happened when Gayathri had gone to receive Haridoss’ daughter, Sathvika, an LKG student, who came from school in the van hired to drop students.

The Kavarapettai police registered a case and arrested van driver Balamurugan of Thumbakkam near Gummidipoondi. He was booked under IPC Section 304 (A) (death caused due to negligent driving).

Title: Delhi assembly elections 2020: In Delhi, people are doing better due to subsidies, says Arvind Kejriwal
Content:
AAP convenor and Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: Attacking Union home minister Amit Shah, Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Saturday said that Shah remembered his party workers only during elections while it was he who was reducing their electricity bills and helping their children get equality education.“There is price rise all over the country but in Delhi people are doing better due to reduced electricity and water charges and free bus services for women,” he added.Addressing the residents of DDA flats in Greater Kailash, Kejriwal urged them to vote for AAP . He said: “For the first time an honest government is in power. Give us an opportunity to change politics.”In his address where he announced luxury buses, an app to use buses effectively and colony marshals, the CM also responded to Shah, who has been on the offensive against Delhi government in his election rallies. “Amit Shah is making fun of Delhi’s people. He said that Kejriwal hasn’t put any CCTV cameras anywhere. The next day the local RWA sent him the footage of his speech. He later said that our government has only put a few cameras. We have put 2 lakh CCTV cameras and we will now install 10 lakh cameras,” Kejriwal said.He also asked Shah why the central government hadn’t placed any cameras. Stating that there is an “education revolution” in Delhi, Kejriwal said: “We have improved school buildings and our schools got 96% pass results, which were better than private schools for the first time in the history. Shah can abuse me or our party but shouldn’t break the confidence of our students, teachers and parents, who have worked hard.” He also challenged BJP to improve a school under the MCD.Kejriwal added: “We have worked hard to improve the city. But if you vote for someone else, then our work will take a hit. Forget about the party you support, but vote for us for the welfare of your kids.”He urged the audience not to vote on the basis of religion or caste.He added that like an elder son of a family, he has taken the responsibility to educate the young, pay for electricity and medical bills and to send the elderly for pilgrimage.Reiterating his promises from his guarantee card, Kejriwal said that “the free electricity scheme will continue and there will be no power cuts. In the next five years, you will get clean water for 24 hours. We will clean up the Yamuna and improve transport by adding 11,000 buses.”Using humour, Kejriwal said that his cough was back due to pollution and he will take efforts to reduce pollution.Before Kejriwal’s arrival, Greater Kailash MLA, Saurabh Bharadwaj, said: “This is the first time an election is being fought on the basis of work. We will solve many problems in the next five years.”
